Sweet

title: Frontier
body: In International law. That portion of the territory of any country which lies close along the border line of an-other country, and so “fronts” or faces it

title: Fruges
body: In the civil law. Anything produced from vines, underwood, chalk-pits, stone-quarries. Dig. 50, 16, 77

title: Fruit
body: The produce of a tree or plant which contains the seed or is used for food

title: Frumentum
body: In the civil law. Grain. That which grows ln an ear. Dig. 50, 16, 77

title: Frumgyld
body: Sax. The first payment made to the kindred of a slain person in rec-ompense for his murder. Blount

title: Frussura
body: A breaking; plowing. Cowell

title: Frustrum Terrs
body: A piece or par-cel of land lying by Itself. Co. Litt. 5b

title: Frutectum
body: In old records. A place overgrown with shrubs and; bushes. Spel-man; Blonnt

title: Frutos
body: in Spanish law. Fruits; products; produce; grains; profits, white. New Recop. h. 1, tit. 7, c. 5. § 2

title: Frymith
body: In old English law. The affording harbor and entertainment ■ to any one

title: Frythe
body: Sax. In old English law. A plain between woods. Co. Lltt. 5b

title: Fuage, Focage
body: Hearth money. A tax laid upon each fire-place or hearth. An imposition of a shilling for every hearth, levied by Edward III. in the dukedom of Aquitaine. Spelman; 1 Bl. Comm. 324

title: Fuer
body: In old English law. Flight. It is of two kinds: (1) Fuer in fnit. or in facto, where a person does apparently and corporally flee; (2) fuer in leg. or in lege

title: Fuero
body: In Spanish law. A law; a code

title: Fuga Gatallorum
body: In old English law. A drove of cattle. Blount

title: Fugacia
body: A chase. Blount

title: Fugam Fecit
body: Lat. He has made flight; he fled. A clause inserted in an ln-qulsltion, in old English law', meaning that a person indicted for treason or felony had fled. The effect of this is to make the party forfeit his goods absolutely, aud the profits of his lnnds until he has been pardoned or acquitted

title: Fugator
body: In old English law. A priv-ilege to hunt. Blount

title: Fugitate
body: In Scotch practice. To outlaw, by the sentence of a court; to out-law for non-appearance in a criminal case. 2 Alls. Crim. Pr. 350

title: Fugitive
body: one who flees; always nsed ln law with the implication of a flight, evd-sion, or escape from some duty or penalty or from the consequences of a misdeed

title: Fugitivus
body: In the clvil law. A fugl-tive: a runaway slave. Dig. 11, 4; Cod. 6

title: Fugues
body: Fr. In medical jurlspru-dence. Ambulatory automatism. See Au-tomatism

title: Full
body: Ample; complete; i>erfect: ma-ture; not wanting in any essential quallty. Mobile School Com’rs v. Putnam, 44 Ala. 537; Reed v. Hazleton, 37 Kan. 321, 15 Pac. 177; Quinn v. Donovan, 85 111. 195

title: Fullum Aquje
body: A fleam, or stream of water. Blount

title: Fully Administered
body: The English equivalent of the Latin phrase “plene admin-istravit;" being a plea by nn executor or ad-minlstrator that he has completely and legally disposed of ail the assets of the estate, and has nothing left out of which a new claim could be satisfied. See Ryans v. Boogher, 169 Mo. 673, 69 S. W. 1048

title: Fumage
body: In old English iaw. The same as fuage, or smoke farthings. 1 Bl. Comm. 324. See Fuage

title: Function
body: office; duty; fulfillment of a definite end or set of ends by the correct adjustment of means. The occupation of an office. By the performance of its duties, the officer is said to fill hls function. Dig. 32, 65, 1. See State v. Hyde, 121 Ind. 20, 22 N. E. 644

title: Functional Disease
body: In medical jurisprudence, one which prevents, ob-structs, or interferes with the due perforin-ance of its special functions by any organ of the body, without anatomical defect or ab-normality in the organ itself. See Higbee v. Guardian Mut. L. Ins. Co., 66 Barb. (N. Y.) 472. Distinguished from “organic” disease, which is due to some injury to, or lesion or malformation in, the organ in question

title: Functionary
body: A public officer or employs. An oflicer of a private corporation is also sometimes so called

title: Functus Officio
body: Lat. Having ful-fllled the function, discharged the ofiice, or accomplished the purpose, and therefore of no further force or authority. Applied to an officer whose term lias expired, and who has consequently no further official authority; and also to an instrument, power, agency, etc., which has fulfilled the purpose of Its creation, and is therefore of no further vlr-tue or effect

title: Fundamental Error
body: See Ebbob

title: Fundamental Law
body: The law which determines the constitution of government in a state, and prescribes and regulates the manner of its exercise; the organic law of a state; the constitution

title: Fundamus
body: we found. ' one of the words by which a corporation may be created ln England. 1 Bl. Comm. 473; 3 Steph. Comm. 173

title: Fundatio
body: Lat. A founding or foun-dation. Particularly applied to the creation and endowment of corporations. As applied to eleemosynary corporations such as colleges and hospitals, lt is said that "fundatio incipient” is the incorporation or grant of cor-porate powers, while “fundatio perflciens" is the endowment or grant or gift of funds or revenues. Dartmouth College v. Woodward, 4 wheat. 667, 4 L. Ed. 629

title: Fundator
body: A founder, (q. v

title: Fundi Patrimoniales
body: Lands of inheritance

title: Funditores
body: Pioneers. Jacob

title: Fundus
body: In tbe civil and old English law. Land; land or ground generally; land

title: Funeral Expenses
body: Money expend-ed in procuring the interment of a corpse

title: Fungible Things
body: Movable goods which may be estimated and replaced accord-ing to welght, measure, and number. Things belonging to a class, which do not have to be dealt with in specie

title: Fungibiles Res
body: Lat. In the civil law. Fungible things. See that title

title: Furandi Animus
body: Lat. An tnten-tion of stealing

title: Furca
body: In old English law. A fork. A gallows or gibbet. Bract, fol. 56

title: Furigeldum
body: A fine or mulct paid for theft

title: Furiosity
body: In Scotch law. Madness, as distinguished from fatuity or Idiocy

title: Furiosus
body: Lat. Au insane man; a madman; a lunatic

title: Furlingus
body: A furlong, or a furrow one-eighth part of a mile long. Co. Litt 5b

title: Furlong
body: A measure of length, be-lng forty poles, or one-eighth of a mile

title: Furlough
body: Leave of absence; especially, leave given to a military or naval of* ficer, or soldier or seaman, to be absent from service for a certain time. Also the document granting leave of absence

title: Furnage
body: See Fobnaoium; Four

title: Furnish
body: To supply; provide; pro-vlde for use. Delp v. Brewing Co., 123 Pa. 42, 15 Atl. 871; wyatt v. Larimer & W. Irr. Co., 1 Colo. App. 480, 29 Pac. 906. As used in the liquor laws, “furnish” means to pro-vide In any way, and lncludes giving as well as selling. State v. Freeman, 27 Vt. 520; State v. Tague, 76 Vt. 118, 56 Atl. 535

title: Furniture
body: This term includes that whlch furnishes, or with which anything is furnished or supplied; whatever must be supplied to a house, a room, or the like, to make it habitable, convenient, or agreeable; goods, vessels, utensils, and other append-ages necessary or convenient for housekeep-lng; whatever Is added to the interior of a house or apartment, for use or convenience. Bell v. Golding, 27 Ind. 173

title: Furst And Fondung
body: In old Eng-lish law. Time to advise or take counsel, Jacob

title: Further
body: In most of Its uses ln law, this term means additlonal, though occas-sionully it may mean any, future, or othe-. See London & S. F. Bank v. Parrott, 125 Cal. 472, 58 Pac. 164, 73 Am. St. Rep. 64; Httchings v. Van Brunt, 38 N. Y. 338; Fifty Associates v. Howland, 5 Cush. (Mass.) 218; o’Fallon v. Nicholson, 56 Mo. 238; Pennsylvania Co. v. Loughlin, 139 Pa. 612, 21 Atl. 163

title: Furtive
body: In old English law. Stealth-lly; by stealth. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 38, § 3

title: Fustigatio
body: In old English law. A heating with sticks or clubs; oue of the an-cient kinds of punishment of malefactors. Bract fol. 104b, lib. 3, tr. 1, c. 6

title: Fustis
body: In old English law. A staff, used in making livery of seisin. Bract, fol. 40

title: Future Debt
body: In Scotch law. A debt which is created, bnt which will not he-come due till a future day. 1 Bell, Comm

title: Future Estate
body: See Estate

title: Futures
body: This term has grown out of those purely speculative transactions, in which there ls a nominal contract of sale for

title: Futuri
body: Lat. Those who are to be. Part of the commencement of old deeds. "Sciant prcesentes et futuri, quod ego talis, dedi et concessi,” etc., (Let all men now living and to come know that I, A. B., have, etc.) Bract, fol. 34b

title: Fust
body: or FUST. A Celtic word, meaning a wood or forest

title: Fyhtwite
body: one of the fines incurred for homicide

title: Fyke
body: A bow-net for catching fish. Pub. St Mass. 1882, p. 1291

title: Fyle
body: In old Scotch law. To defile; to declare foul or defiled. Hence, to find a prisoner guilty

title: Fylit
body: In old Scotch practlce. Fyled; found guilty. See Fruc

title: Fyrd
body: £>ax. In Anglo-Saxon law. The military array or land force of the whole country. Contribution to the fyrd was one of the imposts forming tbe trinoda necessitas. (Also spelled “ferd” and “flrd.”

title: Gabel
body: An excise; a tax on movables; a rent, custom, or service. Co. Litt. 213. —Land gabel. See Land

title: Gabella
body: The Law Latin form of “gabel,” (q. v

title: Gablatores
body: Persons who paid gabel, rent, or tribute. Domesday; Cowell

title: Gablum
body: A rent; a tax. Domesday; Du Cange. The gable-end of a house. Cow-ell

title: Gabulus Denakiorum
body: Rent paid ln money. Seld. Tlt. Hon. 321

title: Gaffoldgild
body: The payment of cus-tom or tribute. Scott

title: Gaffoldland
body: Property subject to the gaffoldgild, or liable to be taxed. Scott

title: Gafol
body: The same word as "gabel” or “gavel.” Rent; tax; interest of money

title: Gager De Deliverance
body: In old

title: Gager Del Ley
body: wager of law, (q. v

title: Gain
body: Profits; winnings; Increment of value, Gray v. Darlington, 15 wall. 65, 21

title: Gainage
body: The gain or profit of tilled or planted land, raised by cultivating it; and the draught, plow, and furniture for carrying on the work of tillage by the baser klnd of sokemen or villeins. Bract. 1. 1. c. 9

title: Gainery
body: Tillage, or the profit arising from lt, or from the beasts employed therein

title: Gainor
body: In old English law. A soke-man ; one who occupied or cultivated arable land, old Nat. Brev. fol. 12

title: Gajum
body: A thick wood. Spelman

title: Gale
body: The payment of a rent, tax, duty, or annuity

title: Galea
body: In old records. A piratical ves-sel; a galley

title: Galenes
body: In old Scotch law. Amends or compensation for slaughter. Bell

title: Galli-Halfpence
body: A kind of coin which, with susklns and doltkins, was for-bidden <by St. 3 Hen. V. c. 1

title: Gallon
body: A llquid measure, containing 231 cublc Inches, or four qunrts. The im-perial gallon contalns about 277, and the ale gallon 282, cublc inches. Hollender v. Ma-gone (C. C.) 38 Fed. 914; Nichols v. Beard (C. C.) 15 Fed. 437

title: Gallows
body: A scaffold; a beam laid over either one or two posts, from which malefactors are hanged

title: Gamacta
body: In old European law. A stroke or blow. Spelman

title: Gamalis
body: A child born ln lawful wed-lock ; also one born to betrothed but unmarried parents. Spelman

title: Gamble
body: To game or play at a game for money. Buckley v. o’NIel, 113 Mass. 193. 38 Am. Rep. 460. The word “gamble” ls per-haps the most apt and substantial to convey

title: Game
body: 1. Birds and beasts of a wild nature, obtained by fowling and hunting. Bacon, Abr. See Coolidge v. Choate, 11 Metc. (Mass.) 79. The term is said to include (in England) hares, pheasauts, partridges, gronse, heath or moor game, black game, and bus-tards. Brown. See 1 & 2 wm. IV. c. 32

title: Gaming
body: The act or practice of play* ing games for stakes or wagers; gambling; the playing at any game of hazard. An agreement between two 6r more persons to play together at a game of chance for a stake or wager which is to become the property of the winner, and to which all contribute. In re Stewart (D. C.) 21 Fed. 398; People v. Todd, 51 Hun, 446, 4 N. Y. Supp. 25; State v. Shaw, 39 Mlnn. 153, 39 N. W. 305; State v. Morgan, 133 N. C. 743, 45 S. E. 1033

title: Ganancial Property
body: In Spanish

title: Ganancias
body: In Spanish law. Gains or profits resulting from the employment of property held by husband and wife in com-mon. white, New Recop. b. 1, tlt 7, c. 5

title: Gang-Week
body: The time when the bounds of the parish are lustrated or gone over by the parish officers,—rogation week. Enc. Lond

title: Gangiatori
body: Officers in ancient times whose business it was to examine weights and measures. Skene

title: Gaol
body: A prison for temporary confinement; a jail; a place for the confinement of offenders against the law

title: Gaol Delivery
body: In criminal law. The delivery or clearing of a gaol of the prls-oners confined therein, by trying them

title: Garantia
body: or GARANTIA. A warranty. Spelman

title: Garantie
body: In French law. This word corresponds to warranty or covenants for title in English law. In the case of a sale this garantie extends to two thlngs: (1) Peaceful possesslon of the thing sold; and (2) absence of undiscloscd defects, (difauts caches.) Brown

title: Garathinx
body: In old Lombardic law. A gift; a free or absolute gift; a gift of the whole of a thing. Spelman

title: Garauntor
body: L. Fr. In old English law. A warrantor of land; a vouchee; one bound by a warranty to defend the title and seisin of his alienee, or, on default thereof, and on eviction of the tenant, to give him other lands of equal value. Britt, c. 75

title: Garba
body: In old English law. A bundle or sheaf. Blada in gorbis, corn or grain in sheaves. Reg. orig. 96; Bract, fol. 209

title: Garbaleb Decims
body: In Scotch law. Tlthes of corn, (grain.) Bell

title: Garble
body: In Engllsh statutes. To sort or cull out the good from the bad in spices, drugs, etc. Cowell

title: Garciones
body: Servants who follow a camp. wals. 242

title: Garde
body: or GARDE. L. Fr. wardship; care; custody; also the ward of a city

title: Gardein
body: A keeper; a guardian

title: Garden
body: A small piece of land, appropriated to the cultivation of herbs, fruits, flowers, or vegetables. People v. Greeuburgh. 57 N. Y. 550; Ferry v. Livingston, 115 U. S. 542, 6 Sup. Ct. 175, 29 L. Ed. 489

title: Gardia
body: L. Fr. Custody; wardship

title: Gardianus
body: In old Engllsh law. A guardian, defender, or protector. In feudal law, gardio. Spelman

title: Gardinum
body: In old English law. A garden. Reg. orig. lb, 2

title: Garene
body: L. Fr. A warren; a prlvi-leged place for keeping animals

title: Garnestura
body: In old English law. Victuals, arms, and other Implements of war, necessary for the defense of a town or castle. Mat. Par. 1250

title: Garnishment
body: In the process of attachment. A warning to a person ln whose hands the effects of another are attached not to pay the money or deliver the property of the defendant ln hls hands to him, but to ap-pear and auswer the plalntlfTs sult. Drake. Attachin. S 451; National Bank of wllmlng-ton v. Furtick. 2 Marv. (Del.) 35, 42 Atl. 479, 44 L. R. A. 115, 69 Am. St. Rep. 99; Georgia & A. Ry. Co. v. Stollenwerck, 122 Ala. 539, 25 South. 258; Jeary v. American Exch. Bank, 2 Neb. (Unof.) G57. 89 N. W. 772

title: Garnistura
body: In old English law. Garniture; whatever is necessary for the for-tification of a city or camp, or for the orna-ment of a thing. 8 Rymer, 328; Du Cange; Cowell; Blount

title: Garroting
body: A method of inflicting the death penalty on convicted criminals prac-tised in Spain, Portugal, aud some Spauish-American countries, consistiug in strangula-tion by means of an iron collar which is mechanically tightened about the neck of the sufferer, sometimes with the variation that a sharpened screw is made to advance from the back of the apparatus and pierce the base of the brain. Also, popularly, any form of strangling resorted to to overcome resist-ance or induce unconsciousness, especially as a concomitant to highway robbery

title: Garsumme
body: In old English law. An amerciament or fine. Cowell

title: Garter
body: A string or ribbon by which tlie stocking is held upon the leg. The mark of the highest order of English knighthood, ranking next after the nobility. This milita-ry order of knighthood is said to have been first instituted by Richard I., at the siege of Acre, where he caused twenty-six kDights who firmly stood by him to wear thongs of blue leather about their legs. It is also said to have been perfected by Edward III. and to have received some alterations, which were

title: Garytour
body: In old Scotch law. ward-er. 1 Pltc. Crim. Tr. pt 1, p. 8

title: Gastaldus
body: A temporary governor of the country. Blount. A bailiff or steward. Spelman

title: Gastel
body: L. Fr. wastel; wastel bread; the finest sort of wheat bread. Britt c. 30 i rfelham

title: Gastine
body: L. Fr. waste or nncultivat-ed ground. Brltt. c. 57

title: Gaudies
body: A term used in the English universities to denote double commons

title: Gauge
body: The measure of width of a rail-way, fixed, with some exceptions, at 4 feet 8% Inches in Great Britain and America, and 5 feet 3 inches in Ireland

title: Gaugeator
body: A gauger. Lowell

title: Gauger
body: A surveying officer under the customs, excise, and internal revenue laws, appointed to examine all tuns, pipes, bogs-heads, barrels and tierces of wine, oil, and other liquids, aud to give them a mark of allowance, as containing lawful measure. There are also private gaugers In large sea-port towns, who are licensed by government to perform the same duties. Rapal. & L

title: Gaugetum
body: A gauge or gauging; a measure of the contents of any vessel

title: Gavel
body: ln English law. Custom; tribute ; toll; yearly rent; paymeut of revenue; of which there were anciently several sorts; as gavel-corn, gavel-malt, oat-garcl, garel-fodder, etc. Termes de la Ley; Cowell; Co. Litt. 142a

title: Gavelet
body: An ancient and special kind of cessavit, used in Kent and London for the recovery of rent, obsolete. The statute of gavelet is 10 Edw. II. 2 Reeve, Eng. I4tw, c. 12, p. 298. See Emig v. Cunningham, 62 Md. 460

title: Gavelkind
body: A species of socage ten-ure common ln Kent, In England, where the lands desceud to all the sons, or heirs of the nearest degree, together; may be disposed of by will; do not escheat for felony; may be aliened by the heir at the age of fifteen; and dower and curtesy is given of half the land. Stim. Law Gloss

title: Gaveller
body: An officer of the English crown having the general management of the mines, pits, and quarries ln the Forest of Dean and Hundred of St. Brlavel’s, subject, ln some respects, to the control of the com-mlssioners of woods and forests. Ile grants gales to free miners in their proper order, accepts surrenders of gales, and keeps the registers required by the acts. There is a deputy-gaveller, who appears to exercise most of the gaveller’s functions. Sweet

title: Gazette
body: The official publication of the English government, also called the “Lon-don Gazette.” It ls evidence of acts of state, and of everythlng done by the king ln hls political capacity, orders of adjudica-tlon in bankruptcy are required to be pttb-llshed therein; and the production of a copy of the “Gazette,” containing a copy of tlie order of adjudication, is evidence of the fact Mozley & whitley

title: Gebocged
body: An Anglo-Saxon term, meaning “conveyed.”

title: Gebocian
body: In Saxon law. To convey; to transfer boc land, (book-land or land held by charter.) The grantor was said to gebo-cjan the alienee. See 1 Reeve. Eng. Law, 10

title: Geburscript
body: In old English law. Neighborhood or adjoining district. CowelL

title: Geburus
body: In old English law. A country neighbor; an inhabitant of the same geb-urscript, or village. Cowell

title: Geld
body: In Saxon law. Money or tribute. A mulct, compensation, value, price. Angeld was the single valne of a thing; twigeld, doable value, etc. So, weregeld was the val-ue of a man slain; orfgeld, that of a beast Brown. •

title: Geldabujs
body: In old English law. Tax-able ; geldable

title: Geld Able
body: Liable to pay geld; liable to be taxed. Kelham

title: Gelding
body: A horse that has been cas-trated, and which is thus distinguished from the horse ln hls natural and unaltered con

title: Gemma
body: Lat. In the civll law. A gem; a precious stone. Gems were distin-guished by their transparency; such as ein-eralds, chrysolites, amethysts. Dig. 34, 2, 19, 17

title: Gemot
body: In Saxon law. A meeting or moot; a convention; a public assemblage. These were of several sorts, such, as the witena-gemot, or meeting of the wise men; the folc-gemot, or general assembly of the people; the shire-gemot, or county court; the burg-gemot, or borough court; the hundred-gemot, or hundred court; the hali-gemot, or court-baron; the hal-mote, a convention of citizens in thelr public hall; the holy-mote, or holy court; the swein-gcmotc, or forest court; the ward-mote, or ward court, whar-ton; Cunningham

title: Genearch
body: The head of a family

title: Geneath
body: In Saxon law. A villein, or agricultural tenant, (villanus villicus;) a hind or farmer, (flrmarius rusticus.) Spelman

title: Gener
body: Lat. In the civil law. A son-in-law; a da ugh ter’8 husband. (Filiae vir.) Dig. 38, 10, 4, 6

title: General
body: Pertaining to, or designat-ing, the genus or class, as distinguished from that which characterizes the species or indi-vidual. Universal, not particularized; as op-posed to special. Principal or central; as opposed to local, open or available to all, as opposed to select, obtaining commonly, or recognized universally; as opposed to par-ticular. Universal or unbounded; as oppos-ed to limited. Comprehending the whole, or directed to the whole; as distinguished from anything applying to or designed for a por-tion only

title: Generale
body: The usual commons ln a religious house, distinguished from pietan-tin, which on extraordinary occasions were allowed beyond the commons. Cowell

title: Generals Of Orders
body: Chiefs of the several orders of monks, friars, and other religious societies

title: Generatio
body: The lssue or offspring of a mother-monastery. Cowell

title: Generation
body: May mean either a de-gree of removal in computing descents, or a single succession of living beings ln natural descent McMillan v. School Committee, 107 N. C. 609, 12 S. E. 330, 10 L. R. A. 823

title: Generosus
body: Lat Gentleman; a gentleman. Spelman

title: Geniculum
body: A degree of consanguin-ity. Spelman

title: Gens
body: Lat. In Roman law. A tribe or clan; a group of families, connected by com-mon descent and bearing the same name, be-ing all free-born and of free ancestors, and in possession of full civic rights

title: Gentes
body: Lat People. Contra omnes gentes, against all people. Bract, fol. 37b. words used In the clause of warranty in old deeds

title: Gentiles
body: In Roman law. The members of a gens or common tribe

title: Gentleman
body: In English law. A person of superior birth

title: Gentlewoman
body: A woman of birth above the common, or equal to that of a gen-tleman; an addition of a woman's state or degree

title: Gentoo Law
body: See Hindu Law

title: Genuine
body: As applied to notes, bonds, and other .written Instruments, this term means that they are truly what they pur-port to be, and that they are not false, forged, fictitious, simulated, spurious, or counterfeit. Baldwin v. Van Deusen, 37 N. Y. 492; Smelt-zer v. white, 92 U. 8. 392, 23 L. Ed. 508; Dow v. Spenny, 29 Mo. 390; Cox v. Northwestern Stage Co., 1 Idaho, 379

title: Genus
body: In the civil law. A general class or dlvision, comprising several species. In toto jure generi per speciem derogatnr, et illud potisaimum habetur quod ad speciem directum eat, throughout the law, the species takes from the genus, and that is most par-ticularly regarded which refers to the species. Dig. 50, 17, 80

title: George-Noble
body: An English gold coin, valne 6s. 8d

title: Gerechtsbode
body: In old New York law. A conrt messenger or constable. o’Cal-iaghan, New Neth. 322

title: Gerefa
body: In Saxon law. Greve, reve, or reeve; a ministerial oflicer of high antiq-ulty in England; answering to the grave or graf (grafio) of the early continental nations. The term was applied to various grades of officers, from the seitre-gerefa, shirc-grefe, or shire-rere, who had charge of the county, (and whose title aud office have been perpetuated in the modern “sheriff,”) down to the tun-gerefa, or town-reeve, and lower. Burrill

title: Gerens
body: Bearing. Gerens datum, bear-lug date. l’Ld. Raym. 336; Hob. 19

title: Germanus
body: Lat. Descended of the same stock, or from the same couple of an-cestors; of the whole or full blood. Mackeld. Rom. Law, f 145

title: Germen Terra
body: Lat. A sprout of the earth. A young tree, so called

title: Gerontocomi
body: In the civil law. offl-cers appointed to manage hospitals for the aged poor

title: Gerontocomium
body: In the civil law. An institution or hospital for taking care of the old. Cod. 1, 3, 46, 1; Calvin

title: Gerrymander
body: A name given to the process of dividing a stnte or other territory into the authorized civil or political divl-sions, but with such a geographical arrange-ment as to accomplish a sinister or unlawful purpose, as, for instance, to secure a majority for a given political party in districts where the result would be otherwise if they were divided according to obvious natural lines, or to arrange school districts so that children of certain religions or nationalities shall be brought within one district and those of a different religion or nationality in another district. State v. whitford, 54 wis. 150, 11 N. W. 424

title: Gersumarius
body: In old English law. Finable; liable to be amerced at the discre-tion of the lord of a manor. Cowell

title: Gersume
body: In old English law. Ex-pense; reward; compensation; wealth. It ls also used for a flne or compensation for an offense. 2 Mon. Angl. 973

title: Gest
body: In Saxon law. A guest A name given to a stranger on the second night of his entertainment ln another’s house. Twa-night gest

title: Gestation, Utero-Gestation
body: In medical jurisprudence. The time during which a female, who has conceived, carries the embryo or foetus in her uterus.

title: Gestio
body: In the civil law. Behavior or conduct

title: Gestor
body: In the civil law. one who acts for another, or transacts another’s busi-ness. Calvin

title: Gestu Et Fama
body: An ancient and ob-solete writ resorted to when a person’s good behavior was impeached. Lamb. Eir. 1. 4, c. 14

title: Gestum
body: Lat. In Roman law. A deed or act; a thing done. Some writers affected to make a distinction between “gcstum” and “factum:* But the best authorities pro-nouuced this subtile and indefensible. Dig. 50, 16, 58

title: Gevillouris
body: In old Scotch law. Gaolers. 1 Pitc. Crim. Tr. pt. 2, p. 234

title: Ge Win Ed A
body: In Saxon law. The ancient convention of the people to decide a cause

title: Gewitnessa
body: In Saxon and old Eng-iish law. The giving of evidence

title: Gewrite
body: In Saxon law. Deeds or charters; writings. 1 Reeve, Eng. Law, 10

title: Gibbet
body: A gallows; the post on which malefactors are hanged, or on which their bodies are exposed. It differs from a common gallows, in that it consists of one perpendicular post, from the top of which pro-ceeds one arm, except it be a double gibbet, which is formed in the shape of the Roman capital T. Enc. Loud

title: Gift
body: A voluntary conveyance of land, or transfer of goods, from one person to an-other. made gratuitously, and not upon auy consideration of blood or money. 2 Bl. Comm. 440 ; 2 Steph. Comm. 102; 2 Kent, Comm. 437. And see Ingram v. Colgan, 106 Cal. 113, 38 Pac. 315, 28 L. R. A. 187, 40 Am. St. Rep. 221; Gray v. Barton, 55 N. Y. 72, 14 Am. Rep. 181; williamson v. Johnson, 62 Vt. 378, 20 Atl. 279, 9 L. R. A. 277, 22 Am. St. Rep. 117; Flanders v. Blandy, 45 ohio St. 113, 12 N. E. 321

title: Gifta Aqua
body: The stream of water to a mill. Mon. Angl. tom. 3

title: Giftoman
body: In Swedish law. The right to dispose of a woman in marriage; or the person possessing such right,—her father, if living, or, if he be dead, the mother

title: Gild
body: In Saxon law. A tax or tribute. Spelman

title: Gilda Mercatoria
body: A gild mer-ebant, or merchant gild; a gild, corporation, or company of merchants. 10 Coke, 30

title: Gildable
body: In old English law. Tax-able, tributary, or contributory; liable to pay tax or tribute. Cowell; Blount

title: Gildo
body: In Saxon law. Members of a gild or decennary, oftener spelled "con-gildo.” Du Cange; Spelman

title: Gilour
body: L. Fr. A cheat or deceiver. Applied ln Britton to those who sold false or spurious things for good, as pewter for sil-ver or laten for gold. Britt c. 15

title: Girante
body: An Italian word, which sig-nifles the drawer of a bill. It is derived from “girare,” to draw

title: Girth
body: In Saxon aud old English law. A measure of length, equal to one yard, de-iived from the girth or circumference of a man's body

title: Girth And Sanctuary
body: In old

title: Gisement
body: L. Fr. Agistment; cattle taken in to graze at a certain price; also the money received for grazing cattle

title: Giber
body: L. Fr. To lie. Gist en le bouche, lt lies in the mouth. Le action bien gist, the action well lies. Qisant, lying

title: Gisetaker
body: An agister; a person who takes cattle to graze

title: Gisle
body: In Saxon law. A pledge. Fred-gisle, a pledge of peace. Qislebert, an lllus-trious pledge

title: Gist
body: In pleadlng. The essential ground or object of the actlon in point of law, with-ont which there would be no cause of action. Gould, Pl. c. 4, S 12; Hathaway v. Rlce, 19 Vt. 102

title: Give
body: 1. To transfer or yleld to, or be-stow upon, another, one of the operatlve words in deeds of conveyance of real property, importing at common law, a warranty or covenant for qulet enjoyment durlng the lifetime of the grantor. Mack v. Patchin, 29 How. Prac. (N. Y.) 23; Young v. Hargrave, 7 ohio, 69, pt 2; Dow v. Lewis, 4 Gray (Mass.) 473

title: Giver
body: A donor; he who makes a glft

title: Giving In Payment
body: In Louisiana law. A phrase (translating the Fr. “Ration en payement”) which signifies the delivery and acceptance of real or personal property in satisfaction of a debt, Instead of a payment in money. See Civil Code La. art 2655

title: Giving Rings
body: A ceremony anciently performed In England by serjeants at law at the time of their appointment. The rlngs were inscribed with a motto, generally ln Latin

title: Gladiolus
body: A little sword or dagger; a kind of sedge. Mat. Paris

title: Gladius
body: Lat. A sword. An ancient emblem of defense. Hence the ancient earls or comites (the klng’s attendants, advisers, and associates in his government) were made by being girt with swords, (gladio succincti

title: Glaive
body: A sword, lance, or horseman's staff, one of tbe weapons allowed ln a trlal by combat

title: Glans
body: In the clvll law. Acorns or nuts of the oak or other trees. In a larger sense, all fruits of trees

title: Glass-Men
body: A term used In St. 1 Jac

title: Glavea
body: A hand dart Cowell

title: Gleaning
body: The gathering of grain aft-er reapers, or of grain left ungathered by reapers. Held not to be a right at common law. 1 H. Bl. 51

title: Gleba
body: A turf, sod, or clod of earth. The soil or ground; cultivated land in gen-eral. Church land, (solum et dos ecclesi#.) Spelman. See Glebe

title: Glebje Ascriptitoi
body: Villein-socmen, who could not be removed from the land while they did the service due. Bract, c. 7; 1 Reeve, Eng. Law, 269

title: Glebarix
body: Turfs dug out of the grouud. Cowell

title: Glebe
body: In ecclesiastical law. The

title: Gliscywa
body: In Saxon law. A frater-ulty

title: Glomerells
body: Commissioners appointed to determine differences between scholars ln a school or university and the townsmen of the place. Jacob

title: Glos
body: Lat. In the civil law. A husband’s sister. Dig. 38, 10, 4, 6

title: Gloss
body: An lnterpretation, consisting of one or more words, interlinear or marginal; an annotation, explanation, or comment on any passage in the text of a work, for pur-poses of elucidation or amplification. Par-ticularly applled to the comments on the Corpus Juris

title: Glossa
body: Lat. A gloss, explanation, or interpretation. The gloss# ot the Roman law are brief illustrative comments or annotations on the text of Justinian’s collections, made by the professors who taught or lec-tured on them about the twelfth century, (especially at the law school of Bologna,) and were hence called “glossators.” These glosses were at first inserted in the text with the words to which they referred, nnd were call-ed “gloss# interlincarcsbut afterwards they were placed in the margin, partly at the aide, and partly under the text, and called “gloss# marginales” A selection of them wns made by Accuraius, between A. D. 1220 and 1200. under the tltle of “Clossa Ordin-aria“ which is of the greatest authority. Mackeld. Rom. Law, $ 90

title: Glossator
body: In the civil law. A commentator or annotator. A term applied to the professors and teachers of the Roman law in the twelfth century, at the head of whom was Irnerius. Mackeld. Rom. Law, S 90

title: Gloucester, Statute Of
body: The

title: Glove Silver
body: Extraordinary re-wards formerly given to officers of courts, etc.; money formerly given by the sheriff of a county in which no offenders are left for execution to the clerk of assize and judges’ officers. Jacob

title: Gloves
body: It was an ancient custom on a maiden assize, when there was no offender to be tried, for the sheriff to present the judge with a pair of white gloves. It is an immemorial custom to remove the glove from the right hand on taking oath, wharton

title: Glyn
body: YN. A hollow between two mountains; a valley or glen. Co. Lltt. 5b

title: Goat, Gote
body: In old English law. A contrivance or structure for draining waters out of the land into the sea. Callis describee goats as “usual engines erected and built with portcullises and doors of timber and stone or brick. Invented first ln Lower Ger-mnny." Callis, Sewers, (91.) 112, 113. Cow-ell defines “gote,” a ditch, eewer, or gutter

title: God And My Country
body: The an

title: God-Bote
body: An ecclesiastical or church flne paid for crimes and offenses committed against God. Cowell

title: God-Gild
body: That which is offered to God or his service. Jacob

title: Goging-Stole
body: An old form of the word “cucking-stool," (q. v.) Cowell

title: Going
body: In various compound phrases (as those which follow) thls term lmplies elther motlon, progress, active operation, or present and continuous validlty and efficacy

title: Golda
body: A mlne. Blount A slnk or passage for water. Cowell

title: Goldwit
body: A mulct or flne In gold

title: Goliardus
body: L. Lat. A jester, buf-foon, or juggler. Spelman, voc. “Goliar-densis

title: Gomashtah
body: In Hindu law. An agent; a steward; a confidential factor; a representative

title: Gonorrhcea
body: In medical jurlsprud-ence. A venereal disease, characterized by a purulent inflammation of the urethra

title: Good
body: 1. Valld; sufliclent in law; effectual ; unobjectionable

title: Goodright, Goodtitle
body: Tbe flctl-tious plaintiff in the old action of ejectment, most frequently called “John Doe,” was some-times called “Goodright” or “Goodtitle.”

title: Goods
body: In oontraots. The term “goods" Is not so wide as “chattels,” for it applies to Inanimate objects, and does not in-clude animals or chattels real, as a lease for years of house or land, which “chattels” does Include. Co. Litt. 118; St. Joseph Hydraulic Co. v. wilson, 133 Ind. 465, 33 N. E. 113

title: Goole
body: In oid English law. A breach in a bank or sea wall, or a passage worn by the flux and reflux of the sea. St. 16 & 17 Car. II. c. 11

title: Gors
body: E, or GORS. A wear, pool, or pit of water. Termes de la Ley

title: Gore
body: In old English law, a small, nar-row slip of ground. Cowell. In modem laud law, a small triangular piece of land, such as may be left between surveys which do not close. In some of the New England states (as, Maine and Vermont) the term is applied to a subdivision of a county, having a scanty population and for that reason not organized as a town

title: Gossifred
body: In canon law. Compa-teruity; spiritual affinity

title: Gout
body: In medical jurisprudence. An inflammation of the fibrous nnd ligamentous parts of the joints, characterized or caused by an excess of uric acid in the blood; usually, but not invariably, occurring in the joints of the feet, and then specifically called “poda-gra.”

title: Government
body: I. The regulation, re-straint, supervision, or control which is ex

title: Governor
body: The title of the chief ex-ecutive in each of the states and territories of the United States; and also of the chief

title: Grace
body: This word is commonly used in contradistinction to “right” Thus, in SL 22 Edw. III., the lord chancellor was instructed to take cognizance of matters of grace, being such subjects of equity jurisdiction as were exclusively matters of equity. Brown

title: Grace, Days Of
body: Time of indulgence granted to an acceptor or maker for the pay-ment of hls bill of exchange or note. It was originally a gratuitous favor, (hence the name,) but custom has rendered lt a legal right

title: Gradatim
body: In old English law. By degrees or steps; step by step; from one de-gree to another. Bract fol. 64

title: Gradus
body: In the civll and old English law. A measure of space. A degree of rela-tlonship

title: Gradus Parentels
body: A pedigree; a tuble of relationship

title: Graffarius
body: In old English law. A graffer, notary, or scrivener. St. 5 Hen. VIIL c. 1

title: Graffer
body: A notary or scrivener. See St 5 Hen. VIIL c. 1. The word is a corrup-tion of the French “greffler” (q. v

title: Graffium
body: A writing-book, register, or cartulary of deeds and evidences. Cowell

title: Grafio
body: A baron, inferior to a count. A fiscal judge. An advocate. Spelman; Cow-ell

title: Graft
body: A term used in equity to deuote the confirmation, by relation back, of the right of a mortgagee in premises to which, at the making of the mortgage, the mortgag-or had only an imperfect title, but to which the latter has since acquired a good title

title: Grain
body: In Troy weight, the twenty-fourth part of a pennyweight Any kind of corn sown in the ground

title: Grainage
body: An ancient duty in London under which the twentieth part of salt lm-ported by aliens was taken

title: Grammar School
body: In England, this term designates a school in which such in-struction is given as will prepare the stu-dent to enter a college or university, and in this sense the phrase was used in the Massa-chusetts colonial act of 1647, requiring every town containing a hundred householders to set up a “grammar school.” See Jenkins v. Andover, 108 Mass. 97. But in modern Amer-lcan usage the term denotes a school, inter-mediate between the primary school and the high school, in which English grammar and other studies of that grade are taught

title: Grammatophylacium
body: (Gneco-Lat.) In the civll law. A place for keeping writings or records. Dig. 48, 19, 9, 6

title: Gramme
body: The unit of weight In the metric system. The gramme is the weight of a cubic centimeter of distilled water at the temperature of 4° C. It is equal to 15.4341 grains troy, or 5.6481 drachms avoirdupois

title: Granatarius
body: In old English law. An officer havlng charge of a granary. Fleta, llb. 2, c. 82, { 1; Id. c. 84

title: Grand
body: As to grand “Assize,” “Bill of Sale," “Cape,” “Distress,” “Jury," “Larceny," and “Serjeanty,” see those titles

title: Grand Coutumier
body: A collection of customs, laws, and forms of procedure ln use in early times ln France. See Couru-M1EB

title: Grand Days
body: In English practice. Certain days in the terms, which are solemn-ly kept in the inns of court and chancery, viz., Candlemas day lu Hilary term, Ascen-sion day in Easter, St John the Baptist's day in Trinity, and All Saints in Mlchael-mas; which are dies non juridid. Termes de la Ley; Cowell; Blonnt They are days Bet apart for peculiar festivity; the members of the respective inns being on such occasions regaled at thelr dinner in the hall, with more than usual sumptuousness. Holthouse

title: Grandchild
body: The child of one’s child

title: Grandfather
body: The father of either of one's parents

title: Grandmother
body: The mother of either of one’s parents

title: Grange
body: A farm furnished with barns, granaries, stables, and all conveniences for husbandry. Co. Litt 5a

title: Grangearius
body: A keeper of a grange or farm

title: Grangia
body: A grange. Co. Lltt 5a

title: Grant
body: A generic term applicable to all transfers of real property. 3 washb. Real Prop. 181, 353

title: Grantee
body: The persou to whom a grant ls made

title: Grantor
body: The person by whom a grant is made

title: Grantz
body: In old English law. Noble-men or grandees. Jacoh

title: Grass Hearth
body: In old records. The grazing or turning up the earth with a plow. The name of a customary service for inferior tenants to bring their plows, and do one day’s work for their lords. Cowell

title: Grass Week
body: Rogation week, so call-ed anciently ln the inns of court and chan-cery

title: Grass Widow
body: A slang term for a woman separated from her husband by aban-donment or prolonged absence; a woman living apart from her husband, webster

title: Grassum
body: or GRASSUM. A fine paid upon the transfer of a copyhold estate

title: Gratification
body: A gratuity; a recompense or reward for services or benefits, given voluntarily, without solicitation or promise

title: Gratis
body: Freely; gratuitously; without reward or consideration

title: Gratis Dictum
body: A voluntary asser-tlon; a statement which a party is not legal-ly hound to make, or in which he is not held to precise accuracy. 2 Kent, Comm. 486, Medbury v. watson, 6 Metc. (Mass.) 260, 39 Am. Dec. 726

title: Grava
body: In old English law. A grove; a small wood; a coppice or thicket Co. Litt. 4b

title: Gravamen
body: The burden or gist of a charge; the grievance or injury specially complained of

title: Gravatio
body: In old English law. An ao-cusation or Impeachment Leg. Ethel, c. 19

title: Grave
body: A sepulcher. A place where a dead body is interred

title: Graveyard
body: A cemetery; a place for the interment of dead bodies; sometimes defined in statutes as a place where a minimum number of persons (as “six or more”) are buried. See Stockton v. weber, 98 Cal. 433, 33 Pac. 832

title: Gravis
body: Grievous; great Ad grave damnum, to the grievous damage. 11 Coke, 40

title: Gravius
body: A graf; a chief magistrate or officer. A term derived from the more ancient “grafio:' and used ln combination with various other words, os an official title in Germany; as Margravius, Rheingravius, Landgravius, etc. Spelman

title: Great
body: As used in various compound le-gal terms, this word generally means ex-traordlnary, that ls, exceeding the common or ordinary measure or standard, ln respect to physical size, or Importance, dignity, etc. See Gulf, etc., R. Co. v. Smith, 87 Tex. 348, 28

title: Gree
body: Satisfaction for an offense com-mitted or injury done. Cowell

title: Greek Kalends
body: A colloquial ex-pression to signify a time indefinitely remote, there heing no *such division of time known to the Greeks

title: Green Cloth
body: In English law. A board or court of justice held in the counting-house of the king’s (or queen’s) household, and composed of the lord steward and infe-rlor officers. It takes lts name from the green cloth spread over the board at whlch it ls held, wharton; Cowell

title: Green Silver
body: A feudal custom in the manor of writtel, ln Essex, where every tenant whose front door opens to Greenbury shall pay a half-penny yearly to the lord, by the name of “green silver” or “rent” Cow-elL

title: Green Wax
body: In English law. The name of the estreats in the exchequer, delivered to the sheriff under the seal of that court which was impressed upon green wax

title: Greenback
body: The popular and almost exclusive name applied to all United States treasury Issues. It is not applied to any oth-er species of paper currency; and, when em-ployed in testimony by way of description, is as certain ns the phrase “treasury notes.” Hickey v. State, 23 Ind. 23. And see U. S. v. Howell (D. C.) G4 Fed. 114; Spencer v. Prlndle, 28 Cal. 276; Levy v. State, 79 Ala. 261

title: Greenhew
body: In forest law. The same as vert, (q. v.) Termes de la Ley

title: Greffiers
body: In French law. Regis-trars, or cierks of the courts. They are officials attached to the courts to assist the Judg-es in their duties. They keep the minutes, write out the judgments, orders, and other decisions given by the tribunals, and deliver copies thereof to applicants

title: Gregorian Code
body: The code or collection of constitutions made by the Roman jurist Gregorius. See Codex Gregorianus

title: Gregorian Epoch
body: The time from which the Gregorian calendar or computation dates; i. e., from the year 1582

title: Gremio
body: In Spanish law. A guild; an association of workmen, artificers, or mer-chants following the same trade or business; designed to protect and further the interests of their craft

title: Gremium
body: Lat The bosom or breast; hence, derivatively, safeguard or protection. In English law, an estate which ls in abey-ance ls said to be in gremio legis; that is, in the protection or keeping of the law

title: Grenville Act
body: The statute 10 Geo. III. c. 16, by which the jurisdiction over par-11a men tary election petitions was transferred from the whole house of commons to select committees Repealed by 9 Geo. IV. c. 22. ll

title: Gressume
body: In Engllsh law. A customary fine due from a copyhold tenant on

title: Gretna Green Marriage
body: A

title: Greva
body: In old records. The sea shore, sand, or heach. 2 Mon. Angl. 625; Cowell

title: Grieved
body: Aggrieved. 3 East, 22

title: Grith
body: In Saxon law. Peace; protection

title: Groat
body: An English sllver coin (value four pence) Issued from the fourteenth to the seventeenth century. See Reg. v. Con-nell, 1 Car. & K. 191

title: Grocer
body: In old English law. A mer-chant or trader who engrossed all vendible merchandise; an engrosser. St. 37 Edw. III. c. 5. See Exgbosseb

title: Grog-Shop
body: A liqnor saloon, bar-room, or dram-shop; a place where intoxi-cating liquor is sold to be drunk on the premises. See Leesburg v. Putnam, 103 Ga. 110, 29 S. E. 602

title: Gronna
body: In old records. A deep hoI-low or pit; a bog or miry place. Cowell

title: Groom Of The Stole
body: In England. An officer of the royal household, who has charge of the klng’s w’ardrobe

title: Groom Porter
body: Formerly an officer belonging to the royal household. Jacoh

title: Gross
body: Great; culpable. General. Ab-solute or entire. A thlng in gross exists in its own right, and not as an appendage to another thing

title: Grosse Avanture
body: Fr. In Freuch marine law. The contract of bottomry. Drd, Mar. llv. 3, tlt 5

title: Grosse Bois
body: Timber. Cowell

title: Grossement
body: L. Fr. Largely, great-ly. (Jrossemcnt enseint, big with chlld. Plowd. 76

title: Grossome
body: In old English law. A flne, or sum of money paid for a lease. Plowd. 270, 271. Supposed to be a corrup-tion of gersuma, (q. v.) See Gbessume

title: Ground
body: 1. Soli; earth; a portion of the earth’s surface appropriated to prlvate use and under cultivatlon or susceptible of cultivation

title: Groundage
body: A custom or tribute paid for the standing of shipping in port. Jacob

title: Growing Crop
body: A crop must be considered and treated as a growing crop from the time the seed Is deposited in the ground, as at that time the seed loses the qualities of a chattel, and becomes a part of the free

title: Growth Half-Penny
body: A rate paid ln some places for the tithe of every fat beast, ox, or other unfruitful cattle. Clayt 92

title: Grub Stake
body: In mining law. A con-tract between two parties by which one un-dertakes to furnish the necessary provisions, tools, and other supplies, and the other to prospect for and locate mineral lands and stake out mining claims thereon, the lnterest ln the property thus acquired inuring to the benefit of both parties, either equally or in such proportions as their agreement may fix Such contracts create a qualified or special partnership.. See Berry v. wood-burn, 107 Cal. 512, 40 Pac. 804; Hartney v. Gosling, 10 wyo. 346, 68 Pac. 1118, 98 Am. St. Rep. 1005; Meylette ▼. Brennan, 20 Colo. 242, 88 Pac. 75

title: G Uadi A
body: In old European law. A pledge. Spelman; Calvin. A custom. Spel-man. Spelled also “wadla

title: Guarantee
body: He to whom a guaran-ty is made. This word ls also used, as a noun, to denote the contract of guaranty or the obligation of a guarantor, and, as a verb, to denote the action of assuming the responsibilities of a guarantor. But on the general principle of legal orthography,—that the title of the person to whom the actlon passes over should end in “ee,” as “donee," “grantee,” “payee,” “bailee,” “drawee,” etc., —it seems better to use this word only as thecorrelative of “guarantor," and to spell the verb, and also the name of the contract, “guaranty

title: Guarentigio
body: In Spanish law. A wrltten authorization to a court to enforce the performance of an agreement in the same manner as if lt had been decreed upon regular legal proceedings

title: Guarantor
body: He who makes a guaranty

title: Guardage
body: A state of wardship

title: Guardian
body: A guardian is a person lawfully invested with the power, and char-ged with the duty, of taking care of the person and managing the property and rights of another person, who, for some pe-culiarlty of status, or defect of age, under-standing, or self-control, is considered in-capable of administering his own affairs. Bass v. Cook, 4 Port. (Ala.) 392; Sparhawk v. Allen, 21 N. H. 27; Burger v. Frakes, 67 Iowa, 460, 23 N. W, 746

title: Guardianship
body: The office, duty, or authority of a guardian. Also the relation subsisting between guardian and ward

title: Guardianus
body: A guardian, warden, or keeper. Spelman

title: Guarnimentum
body: In old European law. A provlslon of necessary things. Spel-man. A furnishing or garnishment

title: Guastald
body: one who had the custody of the royal mansions

title: Guerpi, Guerpy
body: L. Fr. Abaudon-ed; left; deserted. Britt c. 33

title: Guerilla Party
body: In military law. An independent body of marauders or armed men, not regularly or organically connected with the armies'of either belligerent, who carry on a species of irregular war, chlefly by depredation and massacre

title: Guest
body: A traveler who lodges at an inn pr tavern with the consent of the keeper. Bac. Abr. “Inns,” C, 5; 8 Coke, 32; Mc-Daniels v. Robinson, 20 Vt. 316. 62 Am. Dec. 574; Johnson v. Reynolds, 3 Kan. 261

title: Guest-Taker
body: An agister; one who took cattle in to feed in the royal forests. CowelL

title: Guet
body: In old French law. watch, ord. Mar. liv. 4, tlt 6

title: Guia
body: In Spanish law. A right of way for narrow carts, white, New Recop. L 2, c. 6, | 1

title: Guidage
body: In old English law. That which was given for safe conduct through a strange territory, or another’s territory. Cowell

title: Guide-Plate
body: An iron or steel plate to he attached to a rail for the pnrpose ot guldlng to their place on the rail wheels thrown ofT the track. Pub. St Mass. 1882, p. 1291

title: Guidon De La Mer
body: The name of a treatise on maritime law, by an unknown author, supposed to have been written about 1671 at Rouen, and considered, in continental Europe, as a work of high authority

title: Guild
body: A voluntary association of persons pursuing the same trade, art, profession, or business, such as printers, goldsmiths, wool merchants, etc., united under a distinct organization of their own. analogous to that of a corporation, regulating the affairs of their trade or business by thelr own laws and rules, and aiming, by co-operation and organization, to protect and promote the in-terests of their common vocation. In medieval history these fraternities or guilds played an important part ln the government of some states; as at Florence, in the thirteenth and following centuries, where they chose the council of government of the city. But with the growth of cities and the ad-vance in the organization of municipal gov-ernment, thelr importance and prestige has declined. The place of meeting of a guild, or assoclatlon of guilds, was called the “Guildhall.” The word Is said to be derived from the Anglo-Saxon “gild” or “geld,” a tax or tribute, because each member of the society was required to pay a tax towards its support

title: Guildhall
body: The hall or place of meeting of a guild, or gild

title: Guillotine
body: An instrument for decap-itation, used in France for the infliction of the death penalty on convicted criminals, consisting, essentially, of a heavy and weight-ed knife-blade moving perpendicularly be-tween grooved posts, which ls made to fall from a considerable height upon the neck of the sufferer, immovably fixed ln position to receive the impact

title: Guilt
body: In criminal law. That quality whlch imparts criminality to a motive or act, and renders the person amenable to punislj,-ment by the law

title: Guilty
body: Havlng committed a crime or tort; the word used by a prisoner In plead-lng to an indictment when he confesses the crime of which he is charged, and by the jury in convicting. Com. v. waiter, 83 Pa. 108, 24 Am. Rep. 154; Jessie v. State, 28 Miss. 106; State ▼. white, 25 wis. 359

title: Guinea
body: A coin formerly issued by the English mint, but all these coins were called in ln the time of wm. IV. The word now means only the sum of £1. Is., ln whlch denomination the fees of counsel are always given

title: Gule Of August
body: The first of August, being the day of St. Peter ad Vincula

title: Gules
body: The heraldic name of the color usually called “red.” The word ls derlved from the Arabic word “pule," a rose, and was probably Introduced hy the Crusaders. Gnles is denoted iu engravings by numerous perpendicular lines. Heralds who blazoned

title: Gurges
body: Lat. Properly a whirlpool, but in old English law and conveyanclng, a deep plt filled wlth water, distlngulshed from “stagnum,” whlch was a shallow pool or pond. Co. Litt. 6; Johnson v. Rayner, 6 Gray (Mass.) 107

title: Gurgites
body: wears. Jacob

title: Guti
body: Jutes; one of the three natlons who migrated from Germany to Britain at an early perlod. According to Spelman, they established themselves chlefly ln Kent and the Isle of wight

title: Gutter
body: The dlmlnudve of a sewer. Callis, Sew. (80,) 100. In modern law, an open ditch or conduit designed to allow the passage of water from one point to another ln a certaln dlrectlon, whether for purposes of dralnage, lrrlgatlon, or otherwise, war-ren v. Henly, 31 Iowa, 31; willis v. State, 27 Neb. 98, 42 N. W. 920

title: Gwabr Merghed
body: Maid's fee. A Brltlsh word signifying a customary fine payable to lords of some manors on marriage of the tenant’s daughters, or otherwlse on thelr committing incontinence. Cowell

title: Gwalstow
body: A place of execution. Jacob

title: Gwayf
body: walf, or walved; that whlch has been stolen and afterwards dropped ln the hlghway for fear of a dlscovery. Cowell

title: Gylput
body: The name of a court which was held every three weeks ln the llberty or hundred of Pathbew ln warwlck. Jacob

title: Gyltwite
body: Sax. Compensation for fraud or trespass. Cowell

title: Gynsgooragy
body: r GYNSGOORAGY. Gov-ernment by a woman; a state in whlch women are legally capable of the supreme command; e. g., ln Great Brltaln and Spain

title: Gyrovagi
body: wandering monks

title: Gyves
body: Fetters or shackles for the legs

title: Have
body: or HAVE. Lat A form of the salutatory expression “Ave,” (hail,) ln the titles of the constitutions of the Theodosian and Justinlanean Codes. Calvin; Spelman

title: Habeas Corpora Juratorum
body: A writ commanding the sheriff to bring up the persons of jurors, and, if need were, to distrain them of their lands and goods, in order to Insure or compel thelr attendance ln court on tbe day of trial of a cause. It ls-sued from the Common Pleas, and served the same purpose as a distringas juratores ln the Klng’s Bench. It was abolished by tbe C. L. P. Act, 1852, | 104. Brown.

title: Habeas Cobpus
body: Lat. (You have the body.) The name given to a variety of writs, (of which these were anciently the em-phatlc words,) havlng for their object to bring a party before a court or Judge. In common usage, aud whenever these words are used alone, they are understood to mean the habeas corpus ad subjiciendum, (see infra

title: Habendum
body: Lat. In conveyancing. Tiie clanse usually following the granting part of the premises of a deed, which defines the extent of the ownership in the thing granted to be held and enjoyed by the gran-tee. 3 washb. Real Prop. 437; New York Indians v. U. S., 170 U. S. 1, 18 Sup. Ct. 531, 42 L. Ed. 927; Clapp v. Byrnes, 3 App. Dlv. 284, 38 N. V. Supp. 1063; Milier v. Graham

title: Habentes Homines
body: In old Eng-llsh law. Rich men; literally, having men. The same with fees ting-men, (q. v.) Cowell

title: Habentia
body: Riches, Mon. Angl. t 1, 100

title: Habere
body: Lat. In the civU law. To have. Sometimes distinguished from tenere, (to hdld,) and possidere, (to possess;) habere referring to the right, tenere to the fact, and possidere to both. Calvin

title: Habere Facias Fossessionem
body: Lat. That you cause to have possession. The name of the process commonly resorted to by the successful party in an action of ejectment, for the purpose of being placed by the sheriff ln tbe actual possession of the land recovered. It is commonly termed sim-ply “habere facias:* or “hab. fa.**

title: Habere Facias Seisinam
body: L. Lat

title: Habere Facias Visum
body: Lat. That you cause to have a view. A writ to cause the sherifT to take a view of lands or tenements

title: Habere Licere
body: Lat. In Roman law. To allow [one] to have [possession.] This phrase denoted the duty of the seller of property to allow the purchaser to have the possession and enjoyment. For a breach of this duty, an actio ex empto might be main-tained

title: Haberjects
body: A cloth of a mixed color. Magna Charta, c. 26

title: Habeto Tibi Res Tuas
body: Lat. Have or take your effects to yourself, one of the old Roman forms of divorcing a wife. Cal* vin

title: Habilis
body: Lat. Fit; suitable; active; useful, (of a servant.) Proved; authentic, (of Book of Saints.) Fixed; stable, (of au-thority of the king.) Du Cange

title: Habit
body: A disposition or condition of the body or mind acquired by custom or a usual repetitlon of the same act or function. Knlckerbocker L. Ins. Co. v. Foley, 105 U. S. 354, 26 L. Ed. 1055; Conner v. Citizens’ St. R. Co., 146 Ind. 430, 45 N. E. 662; State v. Skil

title: Habitable Repair
body: A covenant by a lessee to “pat the premlses into habitable repair” binds bim to pat them into such a state that they may he occupied, not only wlth safety, but with reasonable comfort, for tbe purposes for which they are taken. Miller v. McCardell, 19 R. I. 304, 33 Ati. 445, 30 L. R. A. 682

title: Habitancy
body: Settled dwelling ln a given place; fixed and permanent residence there. This term is more cpmprehenslve than “domicile,” for one may he domiciled ln a given place though he does not spend the greater portion of hls time there, or though he may be absent for long periods. It is also more comprehensive than “residence,” for one mny reslde in a given place only tem-porarlly or for short periods on the occasion of repeated visits. Bnt in neither case could he properly be called an “inhabitant” of that place or be said to have hls “habitancy” there. See Atkinson v. washington & Jef-ferson College, 54 W. Va. 32, 46 S. B. 253; Hairston v. Hairston, 27 Miss. 711, 61 Am. Dec. 530; Abington v. North Bridgewater, 23 Pick. (Mass.) 170. And see Domicile; Resi-dencs

title: Habitant
body: Fr. In French and Ca-nadian law. A resident tenant; a settler; a tenant who kept hearth and home on the selgniory

title: Habitatio
body: Lat In the civU law. The right of dwelling; the right of free resi-dence in another’s house. Inst. 2, 5; Dig. 7,8

title: Habitation
body: In tbe civil law. Tbe

title: Habitual Criminal
body: By statute in several states, one who ls convicted of a felony, having been previously convicted of any crime (or twice so convicted), or who is convicted of a misdemeanor and has previous-ly (in New York) been five times convicted of a misdemeanor. Crim. Code N. Y. 1903, § 510; Rev. SL Utah, 1898, g 4067. In a more gen-erai sense, one made subject to police sur-veillance and arrest on suspicion, on account of his previous criminal record and absence of honest employment

title: Habitual Drunkard
body: A person given to ebriety or the excessive use of in-toxicating drink, who has lost the power or the will, by frequent indulgence, to control his appetite for it Ludwick v. Com., 18 Pa. 174; Gourlay v. Gourlay, 16 R. I. 705, 19 Atl. 142; Miskey’s Appeal, 107 Pa. 626; Richards v. Richards, 19 UL App. 467; Mc-Bee v. McBee, 22 Or. 329, 29 Pac. 887, 29 Am. St. Rep. 613

title: Hable
body: L. Fr. In old English law. A port or harbor; a station for ships. St. 27 Hen. VI. c. 3

title: Hacienda
body: Iu Spanish law. The pub-lic domaln; the royal estate; the aggregate wealth of the state. The science of admin-isterlng the national wealth; public economy. Also an estate or farm belonging to a private person

title: Hackney Carriages
body: Carriages plying for hire In the street. The driver is liable for negligently losing baggage. Mas-terson v. Short, 33 How. Prac. (N. Y.) 486

title: Hadbote
body: In Saxon law. A recompense or satisfaction for the violation of holy orders, or violence offered to persons in holy orders. Cowell; Blount

title: Haderunga
body: In old English law. Hatred; ill will; prejudice, or partiality. Spelman; Cowell

title: Hadgonel
body: In old English law. A tax or mulct. Jacob

title: Hjec Est Gonventio
body: Lat This ls an agreement, words with which agree-ments anciently commenced. Yearb. H. 6 Edw. II. 191

title: Hjeo Est Finalis Conoordia
body: L

title: Hjereda
body: In Gothlc law. A tribunal answering to the Engllsh court-leet

title: Hjerede Abducto
body: An anclent writ that lay for the lord, who, bavlng by right the wardship of bis tenant under age, could not obtaln his person, the same being carried

title: Hjerede Deliberando Alteri Qui Habet Custodium Terrie
body: An

title: Hjerede Rapto
body: An ancient wrlt that lay for the ravishment ot the lord's ward. Reg. orlg. 163

title: Hjeredes
body: Lat In the clvll law. Heirs. The plural of ftaeres, (q. v

title: Hsredipeta
body: Lat. In old English law. A seeker of an Inheritance; hence, the next heir to lands

title: Hjereditas
body: In Roman law. The

title: Hjeres
body: In Roman law. The heir, or universal successor ln the event of death. The helr is he who actively or passively suc-eeeds to the entire property of the estate-leaver. He ls not only the successor to the rights and claims, but also to the estate-leav-er’s debts, and in relation to his estate is to be regarded as the Identical person of the estate-leaver, inasmuch as he represents him ln all hls active and passive relations to his estate. Mackeld. Rom. Law, $ 651

title: Hafne
body: A haven or port Cowell

title: Haga
body: A house in a city or borough. Scott

title: Hagia
body: A hedge. Mon. Angl. tom. 2, p. 273

title: Hagne
body: A little hand gun. SL 33 Hen. VIII. c. 6

title: Hagnebut
body: A hand-gun of a larger description than the hagne. St 2 & 3 Edw

title: Hata
body: In old English law. A park inclosed. Cowell

title: Haiebote
body: In old Engllsh law. A permission or lioerty to take thorns, etc., to make or repair hedges. Blount

title: Haul
body: In Scotch law. whole; the whole. “All and halll” are common words ln conveyances. 1 Bell, App. Cas. 499

title: Haimsuckbn
body: In Scotch law. The crime of assaulting a person in his own house. Belt

title: Half
body: A moiety; one of two equal parts of anything susceptible of division. Prentiss v. Brewer, 17 wis. 644, 86 Am. Dec. 730; Hartford Iron Min. Co. v. Cambridge Min. Co., 80 Mich. 491, 45 N. W. 351; Cogan v. Cook, 22 Minn. 142; Dart v. Barbour, 32 Mlch. 272. Used in law in various compound terms, in substantially the same sense, as follows

title: Halifax Law
body: A synonym for lynch law, or the summary (and unauthorized) trlal of a person accused of crime and the lnfllc-tlon of death upon him; from the name of the parish of Halifax, ln England, where an-dently this form of private Justlce was prac-tlsed by the free burghers ln tHe case of per-sons accused of stealing; also called “gibbet law.”

title: Haligemot
body: In Saxon law. The meeting of a ball, (conventus aulce,) that is, a lord’s court; a court of a manor, or court-baron. Spelman. So called from the hall, where the tenants or freemen met, and jus-tice was administered. Crabb, Eng. Law, 26

title: Haltmas
body: In English law. The feast of All Sainis, on the 1st of November; one of the cross-quarters of the year, was computed from Hallmas to Candlemas, whar-ton

title: Hall
body: A bulldlug or room of conslder-able size, used as a place for the meeting of public assemblies, conventions, courts, etc

title: Hallage
body: In old Engllsh law. A fee or toll due for goods or merchandise vended in a hall. Jacob

title: Hallazco
body: In Spanish law. The'flnd-ing and taking possesslon of something whlch previously had no owner, and which thus becomes the property of the first occupant. Las Partidas, 3, 5, 28; 5, 48, 49 ; 5, 20, 50

title: Halle-Gemote
body: In Saxon law. Hali-gemot, (q. v

title: Hallucination
body: In medical juris-prudence. A trick or deceit of the senses; a morbld error either of the sense of sight or that of hearlng, or posslbly of the other senses; a psychological state, such as would be produced naturally by an act of sense-per-ceptlon, attrlhuted confidently, but mistaken-ly, to something which has no objective exlst-ence; as, when the patient imagines that he sees an object when there ls none, or hears a voice or other sound when nothing strikes his ear. See Staples v. wellington, 58 Me. 459; Foster v. Dickerson, 64 VL 233, 24 Atl. 257; McNett v. Cooper (C. C.) 13 Fed. 590; People v. Krist, 168 N. Y. 19, 60 N. E. 1057

title: Halmote
body: See Haligemot

title: Halymote
body: A holy or ecclesiastical court

title: Halywercfolk
body: Sax, In old Eng-lish law. Tenants who held land by the service of repairing or defending a church or monument, whereby they were exempted from feudal and military services

title: Hama
body: In old Engllsh law. A hook; an engine with which a house on fire is pulled down. Yel. 60

title: Hambling
body: In forest law. The hox-ing or hock-sinewing of dogs; an old mode of laming or disabling dogs. Termes de la Ley

title: Hamesecken
body: In Scotch law. The violent entering into a man’s house without license or against the peace, and the seeking and assaulting him there. Skene de Verb. Sign.; 2 Forb. Inst. 139

title: Hamfare
body: (Sax. From ham, a house.) In Saxon law. An assault made in a house; a breach of the peace in a private house

title: Hamlet
body: A small village; a part or member of a vlll. It Is the dlmlnudve of “/tarn,” a vlllage. Cowell. See Rex. v. Mor-ris, 4 Term, 552

title: Hamma
body: A close joining to a house; a croft; a little meadow. Cowell

title: Hammer
body: Metaphorically, a forced sale or sale at public auction. “To bring to the hammer,” to put up for sale at auction. “Sold under the hammer,” sold by an oflicer of the law or by an auctioneer

title: Hamsocne
body: In Saxon law. The right of security nnd privacy in a man’s house. Du Cange. The breach of this privilege by a forcible entry of a house is breach of the peace. Du Cange

title: Hanaper
body: A hamper or basket in which were kept the writs of the court of chaucery relating to the business of a subject, and their returns. 8 Bl. Comm. 49. According to others, the fees accruing on writs, etc., were there kept. Spelman; Du Cange

title: Hand
body: A measure of length equal to four inches, used in measuring the height ot horses. A person's signature

title: Hand Down
body: An appellate court ls sold to “haud down" Its decislon in a . case, when the opinion ls prepared and filed for transmission to the court below

title: Hand-Fasting
body: In old Engllsh law. Betrothment

title: Hand-Grith
body: In old Engllsh law. Peace or protection given by the king with his own hand

title: Hand Money
body: Money paid ln hand to bind a bargaln; earnest money

title: Handbill
body: A written or printed no-tlce dlsplayed to lnform those concerned of something to be done. People v. McLaughlin, 33 Misc. Rep. 691, 68 N. Y. Supp. 1106

title: Handborow
body: In Saxon law. A hand pledge; a name given to the nlne pledges in a decennary or frlborg; the tenth or chief, being called “headborow” (q. v.) So called as being an inferior pledge to the chief. Spelman

title: Handhabend
body: In Saxon law. one having a thing ln his hand; that is, a thief found having the stolen goods in his posses* sion. Jurisdictlon to try such thief

title: Handsale
body: Anciently, among all tbe northern nations, shaking of hands was held necessary to blnd a bargain,—a custom stlll retained in verbal contracts. A sale thus made was’ called “handsale," (venditio per mufuam manum complexioncm.) In pro* cess of tlme the same word was used to slg-nlfy the prlce or earnest which was given immediately after the shaking of hands, or lnstead thereof. 2 Bl. Comm. 448

title: Handsel
body: Handsale, or earnest money

title: Handwriting
body: The chirography of a person; the cast or form of writlng pecul-lar to a person, including the size, shape, and style of letters, trlcks of penmanship, nnd whatever gives lndlvlduality to hls writing, distinguishing it from that of other persons. In re Hyland’s will (Surr. Ct.) 27 N. Y. Supp. 963

title: Hang
body: In old practice. To remain undetermined. 'Tt has hung long enough; lt is time lt were made an end of." Holt, C. J.. 1 Show. 77

title: Hanging
body: In criminal law. Suspen-sion by the neck; the mode of capital pun-ishment nsed in England from time immemorial, and generally adopted ln the United States. 4 Bl. Comm. 403

title: Hangman
body: An executioner. One who executes condemned criminals by hanging

title: Hangwite
body: In Saxon law. A fine for Illegal hanging of a thief, or for allowing him to escape. Immunity from such fine. Du Conge

title: Hanse
body: An alliance or confederation among merchants or cities, for the good ordering and protection of the commerce of its members. An Imposition upon merchandise. Du Cange

title: Hansgrave
body: The chief of a company; the head man of a corporation

title: Hantelod
body: In old European lnw. An arrest or attachment. Spelman

title: Happiness
body: SS. The constitutional right of men to pursue their “happiness” means the right to pursue any lawful business or vocation, in any manner not inconsistent wlth the equal rights of others, which may Increase their prosperity, or develop thelr faculties, so as to give to them their highest enjoyment. Butchers’ Union Co. v. Crescent City Co., Ill U. S. 757, 4 Sup. CL 652, 28 L. Ed. 585; 1 Bl. Comm. 41. And see Eng-llsh v: English, 32 N. J. Eq. 750

title: Hague
body: In old statutes. A hand-gun, about three-quarters of a yard long

title: Haracium
body: In old English law. A race of horses and mares kept for breed; a stud. Spelman

title: Harbinger
body: In England, an officer of the royal household

title: Hard Labor
body: A punlshment, addi-tional to mere imprisonment, sometimes im-posed upon convicts sentenced to a penitentiary. But the labor is not, as a rule, any harder than ordinary mechanical labor. Brown v. State, 74 Ala. 483

title: Hard Money
body: Lawful coined money. Henry v. Bank of Salina, 5 HUI (N. Y.) 523,' 536

title: Hardheidis
body: In old Scotch law. Lions; coins formerly of the value of three half-pence. 1 Pitc. Crim. Tr. pt. 1, p. 64, note

title: Hardship
body: The severity with which a proposed construction of the law would bear upon a particular case, founding, sometimes, au argument against such construction, which ls otherwise termed the “argument ab inconvenienti

title: Harmless Error
body: See Ebbob

title: Harnasca
body: In old European law. The defensive armor of a man; harness. Spelman

title: Harness
body: All warlike instruments; also the tackle or furniture of a ship

title: Haro, Harron
body: Fr. In Norman and early English law. An outcry, or hue and cry after felons and malefactors. Cowell

title: Harriott
body: The old form of “herlot," (q. v.) williams, Seis. 203

title: Hart
body: A stag or male deer of the forest five years old complete

title: Hasp And Staple
body: In old Scotch law. Tlie form of entering an helr ln a sub-ject situated within a royal borough. It consisted of the heir's taking hold of the hasp and staple of the door, (which was the symbol of possession,) with other formalities. Bell; Burrill

title: Haspa
body: In old English law. The hasp of a door; by which livery of eelsin might anciently he made, where there was a house on the premises

title: Hat Money
body: In maritime law. Prl-mage; a small duty pald to the captain and mariners of a shlp

title: Hauber
body: O. Fr. A high lord; a great baron. Spelman

title: Howgh
body: or HOWGH. A green plot in a valley

title: Haul
body: The use of thls word, instead of the statutory word “carry,” in an indictment charging that the defendant “did felo-niously steal, take, and haul away” certain personalty, will not render* the indlctment bad, the words being in one sense equiva-lent. Spittorff v. Stnte, 108 Ind. 171, 8 N. E. 911

title: Haur
body: In old English law. Hatred. Leg. wm. I. c. 16; Blount

title: Haustus
body: Lat. In the clvll law. A species of servitude, consisting In the rlght to draw water from another’s well or spring, in which the iter, (right of way to the well or spring,) so fnr as it ls necessary, is tacitly included. Dlg. 8, 3, 1; Mackeld. Rom. Law, S 318

title: Haut Chemin
body: L. Fr. Highway. Yearb. M. 4 Hen. VI. 4

title: Haut Estret
body: L. Fr. High street; highway. Yearb. P. 11 Hen. VI. 2

title: Hauthoner
body: In old English law. A man armed wlth a coat of maii. Jacob

title: Have
body: To possess corporally. “No one, at common law, was sald to have or to be in possession of land, unless it were con-veyed to him by the livery of seisin, which gave him the corporal investiture and bodily occupation thereof." Bl. Law Tracts, 113

title: Haven
body: A place of a large recelpt and safe riding of shlps, so situate and secured by the land circumjacent that the vessels thereby rlde and anchor safely, and are protected hy the adjacent land from dangerous or violent winds; as Milford Haven, Plym-outh Haven, and the like. Hale de Jure Mar. par. 2, c. 2. And see Lowndes v. Board of Trustees, 153 U. S. 1, 14 Sup. Ct. 758, 38 L. Ed. 615; De Longuemere v. New York Ins. Co., 10 Johns. (N. Y.) 125(a); De Lovio v. Bolt, 7 Fed. Cas. 429

title: Hawberk
body: A coat or shirt of mail; hence, derivatively (in feudal law) one who held a fief on the duty or service of providing himself with such armor and standing ready, thus equipped, for military service when called on. wharton

title: Hawgh, Howgh
body: In old English law. A valley. Co. Litt. 5b

title: Hawker
body: A trader who goes from place to place, or along the streets of a town, selling the goods which he carries with him

title: Hay-Bote
body: Another name for “hedge-bote,” being one of the estovers allowed to a tenant for life or years, namely, material for repairing the necessary hedges or fences of his grounds. 2 Bl. Comm. 35; 1 washb. Real Prop. 129

title: Hayward
body: In old English law. An oflicer appointed in the lord's court to keep

title: Hazard.- I
body: In old Englisb law. An

title: Hazardous
body: Exposed to or involving danger; perilous; risky

title: Head
body: Chief; leading; principal; the upper part or priucipal source of a stream

title: Headborough
body: In Saxon law. Tbe head or chlef officer of a borough; chief of the frankpledge tithing or decennary. This office was afterwards, when the petty con-stableship was created, united with that of-flce

title: Head-Courtb
body: Certain tribunals in Scotland, abolished by 20 Geo. II. c. 50. Ersk. 1, 4, 5

title: Headland
body: In old English law. A narrow piece of unplowed land left at the end of a plowed field for the turning of the plow. Called, also, “butt”

title: Head-Note
body: A syllabus to a reported case; a summary of the points decided in the case, which is placed at the head or be-glnning of the report

title: Head-Pence
body: An exaction of 40d. ob more, collected by the sheriff of Northum-berland from the people of that county twice iu every seven years, without account to the king. Abolished in 1444. Cowell

title: Headright Certificate
body: In the

title: Heafodweard
body: In old English law. one of the services to be rendered by a thane, but in what it consisted seems un-certain

title: Healgemote
body: In Saxon law. A court-baron; an ecclesiastical court

title: Heals Fang
body: In Saxon law. A sort of pillory, by which the head of the culprlt was caught between two boards, as feet are caught ln a pair of stocks. Cowell

title: Healing Act
body: Another name for a curative act or statute. See Lockhart v. Troy, 48 Ala. 584

title: Health
body: Freedom from slckness or suffering. The right to the enjoyment of health Is a subdivision of the right of per-sonal security, one of the absolute rights of persons. 1 Bl. Comm. 129, 134. As to in-juries affecting health, see 3 Bl. Comm. 122

title: Healthy
body: Free from disease or bodily ailment, or any state of the system pecu-liarly susceptible or liable to disease or bod,^ ily ailment Bell v. Jeffreys, 35 N. C. 356. w

title: Hearing
body: In equity praotioe. The

title: Hearsay
body: A term applied to that spe-cies of testimony given by a witness who relates, not what he knows personally, but what others have told him, or what he has heard said by others. Hopt v. Utah, 110 U. S. 574, 4 Sup. Ct 202. 28 L. Ed. 262; Morell v. Morell, 157 Ind. 179, CO N. E. 1092; Stockton v. williams, 1 Doug. (Mich.) 570; People v. Kraft, 91 Hun, 474, 36 N. Y. Supp. 1034

title: Hearth Money
body: A tax levied In England by St. 14 Car. II. c. 10. consisting of two shillings on every hearth or stove in the kingdom. It was extremely unpopular, and wns abollshed by 1 W. & M. St. 1, c

title: Hearth Silver
