body: In English law. A species of modus or composition for tithes. Anstr. 323. 326

title: Heat Of Passion
body: In criminal law. A state of violent and uucoutrollable rage

title: Heave To
body: In maritime parlance and admiralty law. To stop a sailing vessel’s headway by bringing her head “into the wind,” that is, in the direction from which the wind blows. A steamer is said to be “hove to" when held In such a position that she takes the heaviest seas upon her quar-ter. The Hugo (D. C.) 57 Fed. 411

title: Hebberman
body: An unlawful fisher in the Thames below London bridge; so called because they generally fished at ebbing tide or water. 4 Hen. VII. c. 15; Jacob

title: Hebberthef
body: In Saxon law. The privilege of having the goods of a thief, and the trial of him, within a certain liberty. Cowell

title: Herring-Wears
body: A device for catch-ing fish in ebbing water. St. 23 Hen. VIII. c. 5

title: Hebdomadius
body: A week's man; the canon or prebendary in a cathedral church, who had the peculiar care of the choir and the offices of it for his own week. Cowell

title: Hecoagium
body: In fendal law. Rent

title: Heck
body: Ah engine to take fish in the river Ouse. 23 Hen. VIII. c. 18

title: Heda
body: A small haven, wharf, or land-ing place

title: Hedagium
body: Toil or customary dues at the hithe or wharf, for landing goods, etc., from which exemption was granted by the crown to some particular persons and societies, wharton

title: Hedge-Bote
body: An allowance of wood for repairing hedges or fences, w’hich a ten-ant or lessee has a right to take off the land let or demised to him. 2 Bl. Comm. 35

title: Hedge-Priest
body: A vagabond priest in olden time

title: Hegemony
body: The leadership of one among several Independent confederate states

title: Hegira
body: The epoch or account of time used by the Arabians and the Turks, who begin their computation from the day that Mahomet was compelled to escape from

title: Hegumenos
body: The leader of the monks in the Greek Church

title: Heifer
body: A young cow which has not had a calf. 2 East, P. C. 616. And see State v. McMinn, 34 Ark. 162; Mundell v. Hammond, 40 Vt. 645

title: Heir
body: At common law. A person who succeeds, by the rules of law, to an estate in lands, tenements, or hereditaments, upon the death of his ancestor, by descent and right of relationship. Hoover v. Smith, 96 Md. 393, 54 Atl. 102; Fletcher v. Holmes, 32 Ind. 510; Sewall v. Roberts, 115 Mass. 268; Dodge’s Appeal, 106 Pa. 216, 51 Am. Rep. 519; Howell v. Gifford, 64 N. J. Eq. 180, 53 Atl. 1074

title: Heir-Looms
body: Such goods and chat-tels as, contrary to the nature of chattels, shall go hy special custom to the heir along with the inheritance, and not to the ex-ecutor. The termination “loom" (Sax.) sig-niflee a limb or member; so that an heir-loom ls nothlng else but a limb or member of the inheritance. They are generally such thlngs as cannot be taken away wlthout damaging or dismembering the freehold; such as deer ln a park, doves ln a cote, deeds and charters, etc. 2 Bl. Comm. 427

title: Heirdom
body: Succession by inheritance

title: Heiress
body: SS. A female heir to a person havlng an estate of lnherltance. when there are more than one, they are called “co-heir-esses," or “co-heirs.”

title: Heirs
body: A word used in deeds of conveyance, (either solely, or in connection with others,) where lt ls intended to pass a fee

title: Heirshif
body: The quality or condition of being heir, or the relation between the heir and hls ancestor

title: Heirship Movables
body: In Scotch law. The movables which go to the heir, and not to the executor, that the land may not go to the heir completely dismantled, such as the best of furniture, horses, cows, etc., but not funglhles. Bell

title: Hell
body: The name formerly given to a place under the exchequer chamber, where the klng’s debtors were confined. Rich. Dict

title: Helm
body: Thatch or straw; a covering for the head in war; a coat of arms bearing a crest; the tiller or haudle of the rudder of a ship

title: Helowe-Wall
body: The end-wall covering and defendlng the rest of the building. Paroch. Antiq. 573

title: Helsxng
body: A Saxon brass coin, of the value of a half-penny

title: Hemiplegia
body: In medical Juriepru-dence. Unilateral paralysis; paralysis of one slde of the body, commonly due to a lesion ln the brain, but sometimes originating from the spinal cord, as ln “Brown-Sequard’s paral-ysls,” unilateral paralysis with crossed anaesthesia. In the cerebral form, the Aemi-plegia is sometimes “alternate” or crossed, that ls, occurring on the opposite side of the body from the initial lesion

title: Helmelborch
body: or HELMELBORCH

title: Henceforth
body: A word of futurity, whlch, as employed ln legal documents, stat-utes, and the llke, always imports a con-tinuity of action or condition from the pres-ent time forward, hut excludes all the past Thomson v. American Surety Co., 170 N. Y. 109, 62 N. E. 1073; opinion of Chief Justice, 7 Pick. (Mass.) 128, note

title: Henchman
body: A page; an attendant; a herald. See Barnes v. State, 88 Md. 347, 41 Atl. 781

title: Hen Edfenny
body: A customary payment of money Instead of hens at Christmas; a composition for eggs. CowelJ

title: Henfare
body: A fine for flight on account of murder. Domesday Book

title: Henghen
body: In Saxon law. A prison, a gaol, or house of correction

title: Hengwyte
body: Sax. In old Engllsh law. An acquittance from a flne for hanglng a thief. Fleta, llb. 1, c. 47, | 17

title: Henrious Vetus
body: Henry the old, or*Elder. Klng Henry I. ls so called in anclent English chronicles and charters, to dis-tinguish hlm from the subsequent kings of that name. Spelman

title: Heordpenny
body: Peter-pence, (q. «

title: Heordwerch
body: In Saxon law. The servlce of herdsmen, done at the will of their lord

title: Heptarchy
body: A government exercised by seven persons, or a natlon divided into seven governments. In the year 560, seven dlfferent monarchies had been formed ln England by the German tribes, namely, that of Kent by the Jutes; those of Sussex, wes-sex, and Essex by the Saxons; and those of East Anglia, Bernlcia, and Deira by the An-gles. To these were added, about the year 586, an eighth, called the “Kingdom of Mer-cla,” also founded hy the Angles, nnd com-prehendlng nearly the whole of the heart of the kingdom. These states formed what has been designated the “Anglo-Saxon octarchy,” • or more commonly, though not so correctly, the “Anglo-Saxon Heptarchy," from the cus-tom of speaking of Delra and Bernicia under the single appellation of the “Kingdom of Northumberland." wharton

title: Herald
body: In ancient law, a herald was a diplomatic messenger tvho carried messages between kings or states, and especially proc-lamatlons of war, peace, or truce. In English law, a herald is an ofiicer whose duty is to keep genealogical lists and tables, ad-Just armorial bearings, and regulate the cer-emonies at royal coronations and funerals

title: Heraldry
body: The art, office, or science of heralds. Also an old and obsolete abuse of buying and selling precedence in the pa-per of causes for hearing

title: Herbage
body: In English law. An ease-ment or liberty, which consists in the right to pasture cattle on another’s ground

title: Herbagium Anterius
body: The first crop of grass or hay, in opposition to after-math or second cutting. Paroch. Antiq. 459

title: Harbinger
body: or HARBINGER. An

title: Herbergagium
body: Lodgings to receive guests ln the way of hospitality. CoweU

title: Herbergatus
body: Harbored or enter-talned in an lnn. Cowell

title: Herbury
body: or HERBURY. An lnn

title: Hercia
body: A harrow. Fleta, lib. 2, c. 77

title: Herciare
body: To harrow. 4 Inst. 270

title: Herciatura
body: In old English law. Harrowing; work with a harrow. Fleta, llb. 2, c. 82, $ 2

title: Herciscunda
body: In the clvll law. To *be divided. Familia hcrcixcundo, an inherlt-ance to be divided. Actio famili# herds-fund#, an action for dividing an inheritance. Erciscunda is more commonly used in the civil law. Dig. 10, 2; InsL 3, 28, 4; Id. 4, 6, 20

title: Herdewich
body: A grange or place for cattle or husbandry. Mon. Angl. pt 3

title: Herdwerch, Heordwerch
body: Herdsmen’s work, or customary labor, done by shepherds and lnferior tenants, at the will of the lord. CowelL

title: Hereafter
body: A word of futurity, always used ln statutes aud legal documents ss indicative of future time, excluding both the present and the past Chapman v. Holmes, 10 N. J. Law, 26; Tremont & S. Mills v. Lowell, 165 Mass. 265, 42 N. E. 1134; Dobbins v. Cragin, 50 N. J. Eq. 640, 23 AU. 172; Thomas v. Mueller, 106 IU. 43

title: Herebannum
body: In old English law. A proclamation summoning the army into the field

title: Herebote
body: The royal edict summoning the people to the field. CowelL

title: Heredad
body: In Spanlsh law. A piece of land under cultivatlon; a cultivated farm, real estate; an inheritance or heirship. —Heredad yaoente. From Lat. “hareditas jacens,” (q. v.) In Spanish law. An inhere itance not yet entered upon or appropriated, white, New Recop. b. 2. tit. 19. c. 2, f

title: Heredero
body: In Spanish law. Heir; he who, by legal or testamentary disposition, succeeds to the property of a deceased person. “Deeres censeatur cum defuncto uno eademque persona” Las Partidas, 7, 9, 13; See Emeric v. Alvarado, 64 Cal. 529, 2 Pac. 433

title: Hereditagium
body: In Sicilian and Neapolitan law. That whlch ls held by heredi-tary right; the same with hercditamentum (hereditament) in English law. Spelman

title: Hereditaments
body: Things capable of being inherited, he it corporeal or incorpo-real. real, personal, or mixed, and inclnding not only lands and everything thereon, but also heir-looms, nnd certain furniture which, by custom, mny descend to the heir together with the land. Co. Litt. 5b; 2 Bl. Comm. 17; Neills v. Munson, 108 N. Y. 453. 35 N. E. 739; owens v. Lewis, 46 Ind. 508, 15 Am. Rep. 295; whltlock v. Greacen, 48 N. J. Eq. 359, 21 Atl. 944 ; Mitchell v. warner, 5 Conn. 497; New York v. Mabie, 13 N. Y. 159, 64 Ain. Dec. 538

title: Hereditary
body: That which Is the sub

title: Herefare
body: Sax. A going into or with an army; a going out to war, (profcctio militaris;) an expedition. Spelman

title: Heregeat
body: A heriot, (q. v

title: Heregeld
body: Sax. In old English law. A tribute or tax levied for the maintenance of an army. Spelman

title: Heremitorium
body: A place of retlre-ment for hermits. Mon. Angl. tom. 3, p. 18

title: Heremones
body: Followers of nn army

title: Herenach
body: An archdeacon. Cowell

title: Heres
body: Heir; an heir. A form of haeres. very common in the civil law. See HjEBES

title: Hereslita, Heressa, Heressiz
body: A hired soldier who departs withont license. 4 Inst 128.

title: Heresy
body: In English law. An offense against religion, consisting not in a total de-nlal of Christianity, but of some of its essen-tlal doctrines, publicly and obstinately avow-ed. 4 Bl. Comm. 44, 45. An opinion on dlvlne subjects devised by human reason, openly taught, and obstinately maintained

title: Heretooh
body: A general, leader, or commander; also a baron of the realm. Dn Fresne

title: Heretofore
body: This word simply de-notes time past, ln distinction from time present or time future, and has no definite and precise signification beyond this. Andrews v. Thayer, 40 Conn. 157

title: Heretum
body: In old records. A court or yard for drawing up guards or mllitary retinue. Cowell

title: Herezeld
body: In Scotch law. A glft or present made or left by a tenant to his lord as a token of reverence. Skene

title: Herge
body: In Saxon law. offenders who joined in a body of more than thirty-five to commit- depredations

title: Herigalds
body: In old Engllsh law. A sort of garment. Cowell

title: Heriot
body: In English'law. A customary tribute of goods and chattels, payable to the lord of the fee on the decease of the owner of the land

title: Herischild
body: In old Engllsh law. A species of mllitary servlce, or knlght'a fee. Cowell

title: Herischulda
body: In old Scotch law. A flue or penalty for not obeying the proclaina-tion made for warfare. Skene

title: Herisoindium
body: A division of household goods. Blonnt

title: Herislit
body: Laying down of arms. Blount Desertion from the army. Spelman

title: Heribtal
body: The station of an army; the place where a camp is pitched. Spelman

title: Heritable
body: Capable of being taken by descent A . term chiefly used In Scotch law, where lt enters lnto several phrases

title: Heritage
body: In tbe oivil law. Every species of immovable whlch can be the subject of property; such as lands, houses, orchards, woods, marshes, ponds, etc., ln whatever mode they may have been acquired, either by descent or purchase. 3 Toullier, no. 472

title: Heritor
body: In Scotch law. A proprietor of land. 1 Eames, Eq. Pref

title: Hermandad
body: In Spanish law. A fra* ternity formed among different towns and villages to prevent the commission of crimes, and to prevent the abuses and vexations to which they were subjected -by men in power. Bouvier

title: Hermaphrodite
body: In medical juris-prudence. A person of doubtful or double sex; one possessing, really or apparently, and ln more or less developed form, some or all of the genltal organs of both sexes

title: Hermeneutics
body: The science or art of construction and Interpretation. By the phrase “legal hermeneutics” ls understood the systematic body of rules which are recognlzed as applicable to the construction and lnterpretatlon of legal writings

title: Hermer
body: A great lord. Jacoh

title: Hermogenian Oode
body: See Conn

title: Hernescus
body: A heron. CowelL

title: Hernasium
body: or HERNASIUM

title: Heroud, Heraud
body: L. Fr. A herald

title: Herpex
body: A harrow. Spelman

title: Herpioatio
body: In old Engllsh taw. A day's work wlth a harrow. Spelman

title: Herring Silver
body: Thls was a composition in money for the custom of supplying herrings for the provision of a religious house, wharton

title: Herus
body: Lat. A master. Servus facit ut rterus det, the servant does [the work] ln order that the master may glve [hlm the wages agreed on.] Herus dat ut servus facit, the master gives [or agrees to give, the wages,] in consideration of, or with a view to, the servant’s doing [the work.] 2 Bl. Comm. 445

title: Hesia
body: An easement Du Cange

title: Hest Corn
body: In old records. Com or grain glven or devoted to rellglous persons or purposes. 2 Mon. Angl. 367b; CoweU

title: Hestha
body: or HESTHA. A little loaf of bread

title: Hetabrarcha
body: The head of a rellglous house; the head of a college; the ward* en of a corporation

title: Hetjeria
body: In Roman law. A company, society, or college

title: Heuvelborh
body: Sax. In old English law. A surety, (warrantus

title: Heylode
body: In old records. A customary burden upon lnferlor tenants, for mend-lng or repalrlng hays or hedges

title: Heymeotus
body: A hay-net; a net for catching conies. CoweU

title: Hibernagium
body: The season for sowing winter corn. CowelL

title: Hidage
body: An extraordinary tax formerly payable to the crown for every hlde of land. This taxation was levled, not ln money, but provlslon of armor, etc. Cowell

title: Hidalgo
body: In Spanlsh law. A noble; a person entltled to the rights of noblllty. By hidalgos are understood men chosen from

title: Hidalguia
body: In Spanish law. Nobility hy descent or lineage, white, New Recop. b. 1, tit 6, c. 8, | 4

title: Hide
body: In old Engllsh law. A measure of land, being as much as could be worked wlth one plow. It is variously estimated at from 60 to 100 acres, but was probably de-termlned by local usage. Another meaning was as much land as would support one family or the dwellers in a mansion-house. Also a house; a dwelling-house

title: Hidel
body: In old English law. A place of protection; a sanctuary. St 1 Hen. VII. cc. 5, 6; CowelL

title: Hidgild
body: A sum of money pald by a villein or servant to save himself from a whipping. Fleta, L 1, c. 47, | 20

title: High
body: This term, as used In various -compound legal phrases, is sometimes merely an addltlon of dignity, not Importing a com-parlson; hut more generally it means exalt-ed, either in rank or location, or occupying a position of superiority, and ln a few in-etances it Implies superiority in respect to Importance, size, or frequency or publicity of use, e. g., "high seas," "highway.”

title: Higher And Lower Scale
body: In

title: Highness
body: A title of honor given to princes. The kings of England, before the time of James I., were not usually salated with the title of “Majesty," but wlth that of “Highness.” The children of crowned heads generally recelve the style of "Highness." wharton

title: Highway
body: A free and pnblic road, way, or street; one which every person has the right to use. Abbott v. Duluth (C. C.) 104 Fed. 837; Shelby County Com’rs v. Cas-tetter, 7 Ind. App. 309, 83 N. B. 986; State v. Cowan, 29 N. C. 248; In re City of New York, 135 N. Y. 253, 31 N. B. 1043, 81 Am. St Rep. 825; Parsons v. San Francisco, 23 Cal. 464

title: Highwayman
body: A bandit; one who robs travelers upon the highway

title: Higler
body: In English law. A hawker or peddler. A person who carries from door to door, and sells hy retail, small articles of provisions, and the like

title: Higuela
body: In Spanish law. A receipt given by an heir of a decedent, setting forth what property he has received from the estate

title: Hilary Rules
body: A collection of orders and forms extensively modifying the plead-ing and practice in the English superior courts of common law, established in Hilary term, 1834. Stimson

title: Hilary Term
body: In English law. A term of court, beglning on the 11th and ending on tbe 31st of January in each year. Superseded (1875) by Hilary sittings, which begin January 11th, and end on the wednes-day before Easter

title: Hindeni Homines
body: A society of men. The Saxons ranked men Into three classes, and valued them, as to. satisfaction for ln-jurles, etc., according to their class. The highest class were valued at 1,200s., and were called “twelf hindmcn;" the middle class at 600s., and called “ttexhindmen the lowest at 200s., called “ttryhindmen” Thelr wlves were termed “hindus.” Brompt Leg. Alfred, c. 12

title: Hinder And Delay
body: To hinder and delay is to do something whlch is an attempt to defraud, rather than a successful fraud; to put some obstacle in the path, or interpose some time, unjustifiably, before the creditor can reallze what is owed out of his debtor’s property. See Walker v. Sayers, 5 Bush (Ky.) 5S2; Burdick v. Post, 12 Barb. (N. Y.) 186; Crow v. Beardsley, 68 Mo. 439; Burn-ham v. Brennan, 42 N. ¥. Super. Ct. 63

title: Hindu Law
body: The system of native law prevailing among the Gentoos, nnd admlnis-tered by the government of British Indla

title: Hind
body: or HIND. In old English law. A husbandry servant

title: Hinefare
body: In old English law. The loss or departure of a servant from his master. Domesday

title: Hipoteca
body: In Spanish law. A mortgage of real property

title: Hirciscunda
body: See Hcbciscunda

title: Hirer
body: One who hlres a thing, or the labor or services of another person. Turner v. Cross, 83 Tex. 218, 18 S. W. 578, 15 L. R. A. 262

title: Hiring
body: Hiring ls a contract by which one person grants to another either the en-joyment of a thing or the use of the labor and industry, either of himself or his servant, during a certain time, for a stipulated compensation, or where one contracts for the labor or services of another about a thing hailed to him for a specified purpose. Code Ga. 1882, | 2085

title: Hirst, Hurst
body: In old English law

title: His Excellency
body: In English law

title: His Honor
body: A title given by the con-stitution of Massachusetts to the lieutenant-governor of that commonwealth. Const Mass. pt. 2, c. 2, { 2, art. 1

title: His Testibus
body: Lat. These being witnesses. The attestation clause in old deeds and charters

title: Hitherto
body: In legal use, this term always restricts the matter in connection with which it Is employed to a period of time already passed. Mason v. Jones, 13 Barb. (N. Y.) 479

title: Hiwiso
body: In old English law. A hide of land

title: Hlaf Jeta
body: Sax. A servant fed at his master’s cost

title: Hlaford
body: Sax. A lord. 1 Spence, Ch. 86

title: Hlafordsocna
body: Sax. A lord’s protection. Du Cange

title: Hlafordswice
body: Sax. In Saxon law. The crime of betraying one's lord, (proditio domini;) treason. Crabb, Eng. Law, 59, 301

title: Hlasocna
body: Sax. The benefit of the law. Du Cange

title: Hlothbote
body: In Saxon law. A fine for being present at an unlawful assembly. Spelman

title: Hlothe
body: In Saxon law. An unlawful assembly from eight to thirty-five, inclusive. Cowell

title: Hoastmen
body: In Engllsh law. An ancient gild or fraternity at Newcastle-upon-Tyne, who dealt in sea coal. St. 21 Jac. L c. 3

title: Hobbit
body: A measure of welght in use ln wales, equal to 168 pounds, being made up of four welsh pecks of 42 pounds each. Hughes v. Humphreys, 26 Eng. L. & Eq. 132

title: Hobblers
body: In old Engllsh law. Light horsemen or bowmen; also certain tenants, bound by their tenure to maintain a little light horse for giving notice of any invasion, or such like peril, towards the seaside. Cam* den, Brit

title: Hoo Quidem Perquam Durum Est, Sed Ita Lex Scripta Est
body: Let. (This Indeed is exceedingly hard, bat so the law ls written; such is the written or positive law.) An observation quoted by Blackstone as used by Ulplan in the civil law; and applied to cases where courts of equlty have no power to abate the rigor of the law. Dig. 40, 9, 12, 1; 3 Bl. Comm. 430

title: Hoc Paratus Est Verifioare
body: Lat This he is ready to verify.

title: Hoccus Saltis
body: A hoke, hole, or less-er pit of salt. Cowell

title: Hock-Tuesday Money
body: This was a duty given to the landlord that his tenants and bondmen might solemnize the day on which the English conquered the Danes, being the second Tuesday after Easter week. Cowell

title: Hodge-Podge Act
body: A name applled to a statute which comprises a medley of incongruous subjects

title: Hoga
body: In old English law. A hill or mountain. In old English, a how. Qrene hoga, Grenehow. Domesday; Spelman

title: Hogaster
body: In old English law. A sheep of the second year. Fleta, lib. 2, c. 79, §§ 4, 12. A young hog. Cowell

title: Hogietus
body: or HOGIETU8. A hog or

title: Hoghenhyne
body: In Saxon law. A house-servant. Any stranger who lodged three nlghts or more at a man’s house ln a decennary was called “hoghenhyne,” and hls host became responsible for his acts as for those of his servant

title: Hogshead
body: A measure of a capacity containing the fourth part of a tun, or sixty-three gallons. Cowell. A large cask, of indefinlte contents, but usually containing from one hundred to one hundred and forty gallons, webster

title: Holder
body: The holder of a bill of exchange, promissory note, or check ls the person who bas legally acquired the possession of the same, from a person capable of trans-ferring it, by indorsement or delivery, and who is entitled to receive payment of the instrument from the party or parties liable to meet it. Bowling v. Harrison, 6 How. 258, 12 L. Ed. 425; Crocker-woolworth Nat. Bank v. Nevada Bank, 139 Cal. 564, 73 Pac. 456, 63 L. R. A. 245, 96 Am. St. Rep. 169; Rlce v. Hogan, 8 Dana (Ky.) 135; Rev. Laws Mass. 1902, p. 053. $ 207

title: Holdes
body: Sax. In Saxon law. A mll-ltary commander. Spelman

title: Holding
body: In English law. A piece of land held under a lease or slmllar tenancy for agricultural, pastoral, or slmllar pur-poses

title: Holiday
body: A religious festival; a day set apart for commemorating some important event ln history; a day of exemption from labor. Webster. A day upon which the usual operations of business are suspended and the courts closed, and, generally, no legal process ls served

title: Holm
body: An Island ln a river or the sea. Spelman

title: Holografo
body: In Spanish law. A holograph. An Instrument (particularly a will) wholly ln the handwriting of the person executing it; or which, to be valid, must be so wrltten by hls own hand

title: Holograph
body: A will or deed written entirely by the testator or grantor with hls own hand. Estate of Billings, 64 Cal. 427, 1 Pac. 701; Harrison v. weatherby, 180 111. 418, 64 N. E. 237

title: Holt
body: Sax. In old English law. A wood or grove. Spelman; Cowell; Co. Litt. 4b

title: Holy Orders
body: In eccleslastlcal law. The orders of bishops, (Including archbish-ops,) priests, and deacons in the Church of England. The Roman canonists had the or-ders of bishop, (in which the pope and arch-bishops were included,) prlest, deacon, sub-deacon, psalmist, acolyte, exorcist, reader, ostiarius. 3 Stepb. Comm. 55, and note a

title: Homage
body: In feudal law. A service (or the ceremony of rendering it) which a tenant was bound to perform to his lord on receiving investiture of a fee, or succeeding to it as heir, in acknowledgment of the ten-ure. It is described by Littleton as thc most honorable service of reverence that a free tenant might do to his lord. The ceremony was as follows: The tenant, heing ungirt and wlth hare head, knelt before the lord

title: Homager
body: one who does or is bound to do homage. Cowell

title: Homagio Respectuando
body: A wrlt to the escheator commanding him to de-liver seisin of lands to the heir of the king's tenant, notwithstanding his homage not done. Fitzh. Nat. Brev. 269

title: Homagium
body: L. Lat. Homage, (q. v

title: Hombre Bueno
body: In Spanlsh law. The judge of a district Also an arbitrator chosen by the parties to a suit Also a man in good standing; one who ls competent to testify in a suit

title: Home
body: when a person voluntarily takes up his abode in a given place, with intention to remain permanently, or for an indefinite period of time, or without any present inten-tion to remove therefrom, such place of abode becomes hls residence or home. This word has not the same technical meaning as “domicile." See Lsnghammer v. Munter, 80 Md. 518, 31 Atl. 300, 27 L. R. A. 330; King v. King, 155 Mo. 406, 56 S. W. 534; Dean v. Cannon, 37 W. Va. 123, 16 S. H 444; Jef-ferson v. washington, 19 Me. 293; welch v. whelpley, 62 Mich. 15, 28 N. W. 744, 4 Am. St. Rep. 810; warren v. Thomaston, 43 Me. 418, 69 Am. Dec. 69

title: Homme
body: or HOMME. L. Fr. Man; a man

title: Homesoken, Homsoken
body: See

title: Homestall
body: A mansion-house. Dlck-inson v. Mayer, 11 Heisk. (Tenn.) 521

title: Homestead
body: The home place; the place where the home is. It is the home, the

title: Homicidal
body: Pertaining to homicide; relating to homicide; impelling to homicide; as a homicidal mania. (See Insanity

title: Homicide
body: The killing of any human creature. 4 Bl. Comm. 177. The killing of one human being by the act, procurement, or omission of another. Pen. Code N. Y. 8 179. The act of a human being In taking away tbe

title: Homicidium
body: Lat Homicide, (q. v

title: Hominatio
body: The mustering of men; the doing of homage

title: Homine Capto In Withernam-Ium
body: A writ to take him that had taken any bond man or woman, and led him or her out of the country, so that he or she could not be replevied accordlng to law. Reg. orig. 79

title: Homine Eligendo
body: In old English law. A writ directed to a corporation, re-qulring the members to make choice of a man to keep one part of the seal appointed for statutes merchant, when a former ls dead, according to the statute of Acton Burnell. Reg. orig. 178; wharton

title: Homine Replegiando
body: In English law. A writ which lay to replevy a man out of prison, or out of the custody of any private person, in the same manner that chat-tels taken in distress may he replevied. Brown

title: Homines
body: Lat. In feudal law. Men; feudatory tenants who claimed a privilege of having their causes, etc., tried only in their lord’s court. Paroch. Antiq. 15

title: Homiplagium
body: In old English law. The maiming of a man. Blount

title: Homme
body: Fr. Man; a man. This term is defined by the Civil Code of Louisiana to include a woman. Article 3522, notes 1, 2

title: Hommes De Fief
body: Fr. In feudal law. Men of the fief; feudal tenants; the peers in the lords’ courts. Montesq., Esprlt des Lois, liv. 28, c. 27

title: Hommes Feodaux
body: Fr. In feudal law. Fendal tenants; the same with horn

title: Homo
body: Lat. A man; a human being, male or female; a vassal, or feudal tenant; a retainer, dependent, or servant

title: Homologacion
body: In Spanish law. The tacit consent and approval inferred by law from the omission of the parties, for the space of ten days, to complain of the sen-tences of arbitrators, appointment of syndics, or assignees of insolvents, settlements of successions, etc. Also the approval given by the judge of certain acts and agreements for the purpose of rendering them more bind-ing and executory. Escrlche

title: Homologare
body: In the civil law. To confirm or approve; to consent or assent; to confess. Calvin

title: Homologate
body: In modern civil law. To approve; to confirm; as a court homologates a proceeding. See Homologation. Literally, to use the same words with an-other; to say the like. Viales v. Gnrdenler, 9 Mart. O. S. (La.) 324. To assent to what another says or writes

title: Homologation
body: In the oivil law

title: Homonymie
body: A term applied in the civU law to cases where a law was repeated, or laid down in the same terms or to the Bame effect, more than once. Cases of Iter* ation and repetition. 2 Kent, Comm. 489, note

title: Hondhabend
body: Sax. Having in hand. See Handiiabend

title: Honeste Vtvere
body: Lat To live hon-orably, creditably, or vlrtuously. one of the three general precepts to whlch Justinian reduced the whole doctrine of the law, (InsL 1, 1, 3; Bract, fols. 3, 3b,) the others being alterum non Ice der e, (not to injure others,) and suum euique tribuere, (to render to every man his due

title: Honestus
body: Lat. of good character or standing. Coram duobus vel pluribus viris legalibus ct honestis, before two or more lawful and good men. Bract fol. 6L

title: Honorable
body: A title of courtesy glv-en ln England to the younger children of

title: Honorarium
body: In the civil law. An honorary or free gift; a gratuitous payment, as distinguished from hire or compensation for service; a lawyer’s or counsellor's fee. Dig. 50, 13, 1, 10-12

title: Honorarium Jus
body: Lat In Roman law. The law of the prstors and the edicts of the sediles

title: Honorary
body: As applied to public offices and other positions of responsibility or trust, this term means either that the office or tltle is bestowed upon the Incumbent as a mark of honor or compliment, without Intending to charge him with the active discharge of the duties of the place, or else that he ls to re-cel ve no salary or other compensation ln money, the honor conferred by the Incumbency of the office being his only reward. See B os-well v. New York, 81 N. Y. 258. In other connections, it means attached to or grew-lng out of some honor or dignity or honorable ofiice, or else it imports an obligation or duty growing out of honor or trust only, ss distinguished from legal accountability

title: Honoris Respectum
body: By reason of honor or privilege. See Challenge

title: Hontfongenethef
body: In Saxon law. a thief taken with hondhabend; i. e„ hav-Ing the thing stolen in his hand. CowelL

title: Hony
body: L. Fr. Shame; evil; disgrace. Hony soit qui mal y pense, evil be to him who evil thinks

title: Hookland
body: Land plowed and sown every year

title: Hopoon
body: In old English law. A valley. CowelL

title: Hoppo
body: A Chinese term for a collector; an overseer of commerce

title: Hora
body: Lat An hour; the hour

title: Horca
body: In Spanish law. A gallows; the punlshment of hanging, white, New Re-cop. b. 2, tit 19, c. 4, J L

title: Horda
body: In old records. A cow in calf

title: Hordera
body: In old Engllsh law. A treasurer. Du Cange

title: Horderium
body: In old English law. A hoard; a treasure, or repository. Cowell

title: Hordeum
body: In old records. Barley. Hordeum palmale, beer barley, as distin-guished from common barley, which was called “hordeum quadragesimalc." Blount

title: Horn
body: In old Scotch practice. A kind of trumpet used in denouncing contumacious persons rebels and outlaws, which was done with three blasts of the horn by the king’s sergeant. This was called "putting to the hornand the party so denounced was said to be “at the horn.4* Bell. See Hobninq

title: Horn-Book
body: A primer; a book ex-plaining the rudiments of any science or branch of knowledge. The phrase “horn-book law" ls a colloquial designation of the rudiments or most familiar principles of law

title: Horn Tenure
body: In old English lnw. Tenure by cornage; that ls, by the service of winding a horn when the Scots or other ene-mies entered the land, in order to warn the king’s subjects. This was a species of grnnd serjeanty. Litt. 5 156; 2 Bl. Comm. 74

title: Horngeld
body: Sax. In old English law. A tax withln a forest, paid for horned beasts. CoweU; Blount

title: Horning
body: In Scotch law. “Letters of horning" is the name given to a judicial pro-cess issuing on the decree of a court, by which the debtor is summoned to perform his obligation ln terms of the decree, the con-sequence of his failure to do so heing lia-bllity to arrest and imprisonment It was anciently the custom to proclaim a debtor who had failed to obey such process a rebel or outlaw, whlch was done by three blasts of the horn hy the king's sergeant in a public place. Thls was called “putting to the horn,” whence the name

title: Horreum
body: Lat A place for keeping graln; a granary. A place for keeping fruits, wines, and goods generally; a store-house. Calvin.; Bract fol. 48

title: Hobs
body: L. Fr. Out; out of; without

title: Hors Wealh
body: In old English law. The wealh, or Briton who had care of the klng's horses

title: Hobs Weard
body: In old English law. A servlce or corvde, consisting ln watchlng the horses of the lord. Anc. Inst Eng

title: Horse
body: An animal of the genus equus and species caballus. In a narrow and strict sense, the term Ib applied only to the male, and only to males of four years old or there-abouts, younger horses being called “colts.” But even ln this sense the term Includes both stallions and geldings. In a wider sense, and as generally used ln statutes, the word is taken as nomcn gcneralissimum, and in-cludes not only horses strictly so called, but also colts, mares and fillies, and mules and asses. See owens v. State, 38 Tex. 557; Ashworth v. Mounsey, L. R. 9 Exch. 187 ;.Pul-len v. State, 11 Tex. App. 91; Allison ▼. Brookshire, 38 Tex. 201; State v. Ingram, 16 Kan. 19; State v. Dunnavant, 3 Brev. (S. C.) 10, 5 Am. Dec. 530; State v. Gooch, 60 Ark. 218, 23 S. W. 640; Davis v. Collier, 13 Ga. 491. Compare Richardson v. Chicago & A. R. Co.; 149 Mo. 311, 50 8. W. 782

title: Horse Guards
body: The directing power of the military forces of the kingdom of Great Britain. 'Hie commander in chief, or general commanding the forces, is at the

title: Hortus
body: Lat. In the civil law. A gar-den. Dig. 32, 91, 6

title: Hospes
body: Lat A guest 8 Coke, 32

title: Hospes Generalis
body: A great chamberlain

title: Hospital
body: An institution for the re-ception and care of sick, wounded, infirm, or aged persons; generally incorporated, and then of the class of corporations called “elee-mosynary” or “charitable." See In re Curtiss (Sur.) 7 N. Y. Supp. 207

title: Hospitallers
body: The knights of a re-ligious order, so called because they built a hospital at Jerusalem, wherein pilgrims were received. All their lands and goods in Eng-land were given to the sovereign by 32 Hen. VIIL c. 24

title: Hospitator
body: A host or entertainer

title: Hospitia
body: Inns. Hospitia communia, common inns. Reg. orig. 105. Hospitia curia, inns of court Hospitia cancellarics, inns of chancery. Crabb, Eng. Law, 428, 429 ; 4 Reeve, Eng. Law, 120

title: Hospiticide
body: one that kills hls guest or host

title: Hospitium
body: An inn; a household. See Cromwell ▼. Stephens, 2 Daly (N. Y.) 17

title: Hospodar
body: A Turkish governor in Mol-davia or wallachia

title: Host
body: L. Fr. An army. Britt, c. 22. A military expedition; war. Kelham

title: Hostage
body: A person who is given into the possession of the enemy, ln a public war, his freedom (or life) to stand as security for the performance of some contract or promise made by the belligerent power giving the hostage with the other

title: Hostelagium
body: In old records. A right to receive lodging and entertainment, anciently reserved by lords in the houses of tlieir tenants. CowelL

title: Hosteler
body: See Hostler

title: Hostes
body: Lat Enemies. Hostes humanl generis, enemies of the human race; i. e., pirates

title: Hostia
body: In old records. The host-bread, or consecrated wafer, in the eucha-rist Cowell

title: Hosticide
body: One who kills an enemy

title: Hostilaria, Hospitalaria
body: A

title: Hostile
body: Having the character of an enemy; standing in the relation of an ene-my. See 1 Kent, Comm. c. 4

title: Hostility
body: In the law of nations. A state of open war. “At the breaking out of hostility.” 1 Kent, Comm. 60

title: Hostler
body: In Norman and old English law, this was the tltle of the officer in a monastery charged with the entertainment of guests. It was also applied (until about the time of Queen Elizabeth) to an innkeeper, and afterwards, when the keeping of horses at livery becamea distinct occupation, to the keeper of a livery stable, and then (under the modern form “ostler”) to the groom in charge of the stables of an inn. Cromwell v. Stephens, 2 Daly (N. Y.) 20. In the lan-guage of railroading, an “ostler” or “hostler” at a roundhouse ls one whose duty lt is to receive locomotives as they come in from the road, care for them ln tbe roundhouse, aud have them cleaned and ready for de-parture when wanted. Railroad Co. v. Mas-sig, 50 IU. App. 666; Railroad Co. r. Ash-ling, 34 111. App. 105; Grannis v. Railroad Co., 81 Iowa, 444, 46 N. W. 1067

title: Hot-Water Ordeal
body: In old Eng-lish law. This was a test, ln cases of accusation, by hot water; the party accused and suspected being appointed by the judge to put hls arms up to the elbows in seeth

title: Hotchpot
body: The blending and mixing property belonging to different persons, ln order to divide it equally. 2 Bl. Comm. 190

title: Hotel
body: An inn; a public house or tavern; a house for entertaining strangers or travelers. St ‘Louis v. Siegrist, 46 Mo. 594; People v. Jones, 54 Barb. (N. Y.) 316; Crom-weii v. Stephens, 2 Daly (N. Y.) 19

title: Hour
body: The twenty-fourth part of a natural day; sixty minutes of time

title: Hour Of Gause
body: In Scotch practice. The hour when a court ls met. 3 How. 8tate Tr. 603

title: House
body: 1. A dwelling; a building de-signed for the habitation and residence of men

title: Houseage
body: A fee paid for housing goods by a carrier, or at a wharf, etc

title: Housebreaking
body: In criminal law. Breaking and entering a dwelling-house with Intent to commit any felony therein. If done by night, it comes under the definition of “burglary.”

title: Household
body: A family llvtng together. May v. Smith, 48 Ala. 488; woodward v. Murray, 18 Johns. (N. Y.) 402; Arthur v. Morgan, 112 U. S. 495, 5 Sup. Ct 241, 28 L. Ed. 825. Those who dwell under the same roof and compose a famlly. webster. A man’s family living together constitutes hls household, though he may have gone to an-other state

title: Householder
body: The occupier of a house. Brande. More correctly, one who keeps house with his family; the head or master of a family, webster; 18 Johns. 302. one who has a household; the head of a household. See Greenwood v. Maddox, 27 Ark. <»55; Sullivan v. Canan, wils. (Ind.) 534; Shively v. Lankford, 174 Mo. 535, 74 S. W. 835

title: Housekeeper
body: one who Is in actual possession of and who occupies a house, as

title: Hovel
body: A place used by husbandmen to set thelr plows, carts, and other farming utensils out of the rain and sun. A shed; a cottage; a mean house

title: Howe
body: In old English law. A hllL Co. Lltt 5b

title: Hoyman
body: The master or captain of a hoy

title: Huckster
body: A petty dealer and retailer of small articles of provisions, particularly farm and garden produce. Mays ▼. Cincln-natl, 1 ohlo St 272; Lebanon County v. Kline, 2 Pa. Co. CL R. 622

title: Huousque
body: In old pleading. Hither-to. 2 Mod. 24

title: Hude-Geld
body: ln old English law. An acquittance for an assault upon a trespassing servant. Supposed to be a mistake or mis-print in Fleta for “hinegeld." Fleta, lib. 1, c. 47, | 20. Also the price of one's skin, or the money paid by a servant to save himself from a whipping. Du Cange

title: Hue And Cry
body: In old English law. A ioud outcry with which felons (such as rob-bers, burglars, and murderers) were anciently pursued, and which all who heard lt were hound to take up, and join ln the pursuit, nntll the malefactor was taken. Bract fols. 115b, 124; 4 BL Comm. 293

title: Huebras
body: In Spanish law. A* meas-ure of land equal to as much as a yoke of oxen can plow in one day. 2 whlte, Recop. (38,) 49; Strother v. Lucas, 12 Pet 443, 0 L. Ed. 1137

title: Huis
body: L. Fr. A door. “Al huis del es-gIise,” at the door of the church. Bendloe, 133

title: Huisserium
body: A ship used to transport horses. Also termed “u/fer.”

title: Huissiers
body: ln French law. Marshals; ushers; process-servers; sheriffs* officers. Ministerial officers attached to the courts, to effect legal servlce of process required by law ln actions, to issue executions, etc., and to maintain order during the sitting of the courts

title: Hulka
body: In old records. A hulk or small vessel. CowelL

title: Hullus
body: In old records. A hilL 2 Mon. Angl. 292; Cowell

title: Humagium
body: A moist place. Mon. Angl

title: Hundred
body: Under the Saxon orgauiza-tion of England, each county or shire corn-prised an indefinite number of hundreds, each hundred containing ten titMngs, or groups of ten families of freeholders or frank-pledges. The hundred was governed by a high constable, and had its own conrt; but its most remarkable feature was the corporate responsibility of the whole for the crimes or defaults of the Individual members. The introduction of this plan of or-ganization into England is commonly ascrib-ed to Alfred, but the idea, as well of the collective liability as of the division, was prob-ably known to the ancient German peoples, as we find the 6ame thing established in the Frankish kingdom under Clothaire, and in Denmark. See 1 BL Comm. 115; 4 BL Comm. 411

title: Hundredarius
body: In old English law. A hundredary or hundredor. A name given to the chief officer of a hundred, as weil as to the freeholders who composed it Spel. voc. “H undr edits

title: Hundred Ary
body: The chief or presiding officer of a hundred

title: Hun-Dredes Man
body: DOR, or HUN-DREDES MAN. The presiding officer ln the hundred court Anc. Inst Eng

title: Hundredors
body: In English law. The Inhabitants or freeholders of a hundred, an-ciently the suitors or judges of the hundred court Persons impaneled or fit to be lm-paneled upon juries, dwelling wlthln the hundred where the cause of action arose. Cromp. Jur. 217. It was formerly necessary to have some of these upon every panel of jurors. 3 BL Comm.' 859, 360 ; 4 Steph. Comm. 370

title: Hung Jury
body: A jury so irreconcilably divided in opinion that they cannot agree npon any verdict

title: Hurdereferst
body: A domestic; one of a family

title: Hurdle
body: In English criminal law. A kind of sledge, on which convicted felons were drawn to the place of execution.

title: Hurricane
body: A storm of great violence or intensity, of which the particular characteristic is the high velocity of the wind. There ls naturally no exact measure to distinguish between an ordinary storm and a hurricane, bnt the wind should reach a velocity of at least 50 or 60 miles an hour to be called by the latter name, or, os expressed in some of the cases, lt should be sufficient to “throw down buildings.” A hurricane is properly a circular storm in the nature of a cyclone. See Pelican Ins. Cb. v. Troy Co-op. Ass'n, 77 Tex. 225, 13 S. W. 980; Queen Ins. Co. v. Hudnut Co., 8 Ind. App. 22, 35 N. B. 397; Tyson v. Union Mut Fire A Storm Co., 2 Montg. Co. Law Rep’r (Pa.) 17

title: Hirst
body: HYRST, HERST, or HIRST

title: Hurt
body: In such phrases as “to the hurt or annoyance of another,” or “hurt, molest-ed, or restrained in his person or estate," this word is not restricted to physical in-juries, but Includes also mental pain, as well as discomfort or annoyance. See Row-land v. Miller (Super. N. Y.) 15 N. Y. Supp. 702; Pronk v. Brooklyn Heights R. Co., 68 App. Div. 390, 74 N. T. Supp. 375; Thurston v. whitney, 2 Cush. (Mass.) 110

title: Hortus
body: DUS, or HORTUS. A ram or

title: H U R T O
body: In Spanish law. Theft white. New Recop. b. 2, tit 20

title: Husband
body: A married man; one who has a lawful wlfe living. The correlative of “wife

title: Husbandman
body: A farmer; a cultivator or tiller of the ground. The word “farmer” is colloquially used as synonymous with “hus-bandmnn,” but originally meant a tenant who cultivates leased ground

title: Husbandria
body: In old English law. Husbandry. Dyer, (Fr. Ed.) 35b

title: Husbandry
body: Agriculture; cultivation of the Soil for1 food; farming, in the sense of operating land to raise provisions. Simons v. Lovell, 7 Heisk. (Tenn.) 516 ; McCue v. Tunstead, 65 Cal. 506, 4 Pac. 510

title: Husbreo
body: In Saxon law. The crime of housebreaking or burglary. Crabb, Eng. Law, 59, 308

title: Huscarle
body: In old English law. A house servant or domestic; a man of the household. Spelman

title: Husfastne
body: He who holds house and land. Bract L 3, L 2, c. 10

title: Husgablum
body: In oid records. House rent; or a tax or tribute laid upon a house. Cowell; Blount

title: Hush-Money
body: A colloquial expression to designate a bribe to hinder information; pay to secure silence

title: Hustings
body: Councll; court; tribunal. Apparently so called from belng held within a building, at a time -when other courts were held in the open air. It was a local court The county oourt in the city of London bore this name. There were hustings at York, winchester, Lincoln, and ln other pla-ces similar to the London hustings. Also the raised place from which candidates for seats ln parliament address the constituency, on the occasion of their nomination, whartpn

title: Hutesium Et Clamor
body: Hue and cry. See Hui ano Cbt

title: Hutilan
body: Taxes. Mon. Angl. 1. 586

title: Hwata, Hwatung
body: In old English law. Augury; divination

title: Hybernagium
body: In old English law. The season for sowing winter grain, between Michaelmas and Christmas. The lnnd on which such grain was sown. The grain It-self; winter grain or winter corn. Cowell

title: Hybrid
body: A mongrel; an animal foriu-ed of the nnlon of different species, or dif-ferent genera; also (metaphorically) a human being born of the union of persons of different races

title: Hydage
body: See Hidage

title: Hydrometer
body: An instrument for measuring the density of fluids. Being ira-mersed in fluids, as in water, brines beer, brandy, etc., lt determines the proportion of thelr density, or their specific gravity, and thence their quality. See Rev. St U. S. S 2918 (U. S. Comp. St. 1901, p. 1927

title: Hyems, Hiems
body: Lat In the civU law. winter. Dig. 43, 20, 4, 34. written, in some of the old books, “perns.” Fleta, lib. 2, c. 73, SS 16, 18

title: Hypnotism
body: In medical jurisprudence. A psychic or mental state rendering the pa-tient susceptible to suggestion at the will of another

title: Hypobolum
body: In tbe civil law. The name of the bequest or legacy given by the husband to hls wife, at his death, above her dowry

title: Hypochondria
body: See Insanity

title: Hypostasis
body: In medical jurisprudence. (1) The morbid deposition of a sediment of any kind in the body. (2) A congestion or flushing of the blood vessels, as in varicose veins. Post-mortem hypostasis, a peculiar lividity of the cadaver

title: Hypotheo
body: In Scotland, the term “hypothec" is used to signify the landlord's right which, independently of any stipula-tlon, he has over the crop and stocking of his tenant. 'It gives a security to the landlord over the crop of each year for the lent of

title: Hyfotheca
body: “Hypotheca” was a term of the Roman law, and denoted a pledge or mortgage. As distinguished from the term “pignus" ln the same law, it denoted a mortgage, whether of lands or of goods, in whlch the subject in pledge remained in the pos-sesslon of the mortgagor or debtor; whereas In the pignus the mortgagee or creditor was in tbe possession. Such an hypotheca might be either express or implied; express, where the parties upon the occasion of a loan en-tered into express agreement to that effect; or implied, as, e. g., in the case of the stock and utensils of a farmer, which were subject to the landlord’s right as a creditor for rent; wheuce the Scotch law of hypothec

title: Hypothecaria Actio
body: Lat In the

title: Hypothecarh Creditores
body: Lat

title: Hypothecary Action
body: The name of an action allowed under the civil law for the enforcement of the claims of a credit-or by the contract of hypotheca. Lovell v. Cragin, 136 U. S. 130, 10 Sup. CL 1024, 34 I* Ed. 372

title: Hypothecate
body: To pledge a thing without delivering the possession of it to the pledgee. “The master, when abroad, and in the absence of the owner, may hypothecate the ship, freight, and cargo, to raise money requisite for the completion of the voyage.” 3 Kent Comm. 171. See Spect v. Spect, 88 Cal. 437, 26 Pac. 203, 13 L. R. A. 137, 22 Am. St. Rep. 314; ogden v. Lathrop, 31 N. ¥. Super. Ct. 651

title: Hypothecation
body: A term borrowed from the civil law. In so far as It Is nat-urailzed in English and American law, it means a contract of mortgage or pledge in

title: Hypothecation Bond
body: A bond giv-en ln the contract of bottomfy or respondentia

title: Hypotheque
body: In French lnw. Hy-pothecatlon; a mortgage on real property; the right vested ln a creditor by the assign-inent to hlm of real estate as security for the payment of hls debt, whether or not lt be accompanied by possession. See Clv. Code La. art 3360

title: Hypothesis
body: A supposition, assumption, or theory; a theory set up by the pros-ecution, on a criminal trial, or by the de-fense, as on explanation of the facts ln evi-dence, aud a ground for inferring guilt or ln-nocence, as the case may be, or as indicating a probable or posslble motive for tbe crlme

title: Hypothetical Question
body: A com-binatlon of assumed or proved facts and cir-cumstances, stated ln such form as to constitute a coherent and specific situation or state of facts, upon whicli the oplnion of an expert is asked, by way of evldence on a trial. Howard v. People, 185 111. 552, 57 N. E. 441; People v. Durrant, 116 Cal. 216, 48 Pac. 85; Cowley v. People, 83 N. Y. 464. 38 Am. Rep. 464; Stearns v. Field, 90 N. Y. 641

title: Hyrnes
body: In old English law. A par* Ish

title: Hysteria
body: A paroxysmal disease or disorder of the nervous system, more common ln females than males, not originating in any anatomical lesion, due- to psychic rather than physical causes, and attended, in the acute er convulsive form, by extraordinary manifesta-tions of secondary effects of extreme nervous-ness

title: Hysteropotmoi
body: Those who, hav-ing been thought dead, had, after a long absence ln foreign countries, returned safely home; or those wbo, having been thought dead in battle, had afterwards unexpectedly escaped from thelr enemies and returned home. These, among the Romans, were not permitted to enter their own houses at the door, bnt were received at a passage opened in the roof. Enc. Lond

title: Hysterotomy
body: The Caesarean opera-tion. See Cjksabeaw Sbction

title: Hythe
body: In English law. A port, wharf, or small haven to embark or land merchandise at Cowell; Blount

title: I O U
body: A memorandum of debt, consisting of these letters, (“I owe you,”) a sum of money, and the debtor's signature, is termed an “I O U.” Kinney v. Flynn, 2 R. I. 329

title: Ibernagium
body: In old English law. The season for sowing winter corn. Also spelled “hibernagium” and “hybernagium

title: Ibidem
body: Lat In the same place; in the same book; on the same page, etc. Abbreviated to “ibid.” or “ib

title: Icona
body: An Image, figure, or representa-tlon of a thing. Du Cange

title: Ictus
body: In old English law. A stroke or blow from a club or stone; a bruise, contusion, or swelling produced by a blow from' a club or stone, as distinguished from “ploga,” (a wound.) Fleta, lib. 1, c. 41, | 3

title: Id Est
body: Lat That is. Commonly ab-breviated “i. e.”

title: Idem
body: Lat The same. According to Lord Coke, “idem" has two significations, se., idem syllable seu verbis, (the same ln syllables or words,) and idem re et sensu, (the same in substance and in sense.) 10 Coke, 124a

title: Idem Per Idem
body: The same for tiie same. An illustration of a kind that really adds no additlonal element to the considera-Uon of the question

title: Idem Sonans
body: Sounding the same or alike; having the same sound. A term ap-plied to names which are substantially the same, though slightly varied In the spelling, as “Lawrence” and “Lawrance,” and the llke. 1 Cromp. & M. 806 ; 3 Chit. Gen. Pr. 171

title: Identification
body: Proof of identity; the prdvlng that a person, subject, or ar-tide before the court is the very same that he or It is alleged, charged, or reputed to be; as where a witness recognizes the prisoner at the bar as the same person whom lie saw committing the crime; or where handwrlt-ing, stolen goods, counterfeit coin, etc., are recognized as the same which once passed under the observation of the person identi-fylng them

title: Identitate Nominis
body: In English law. An ancient writ (now obsolete) which lay for one taken and arrested in any per-sonal action, and committed to prison, by mistake for another man of the same name, Fitzh. Nat Brev. 267

title: Identity
body: In tbo law of ovidenoo

title: Ideo
body: Lat. Therefore. Calvin

title: Ideo Consideratum Est
body: Lat. Therefore lt is considered. These were the words used at the beginning ef the eutry of judgment in an action, when the forms were ln Iatln. They are also used as a name for that portion of the record

title: Ides
body: A division of time among the Romans. In March, May, July, and october, the Ides were on the 15th of the month; in the remaining months, on the 13th. This method of reckoning is still retained ln the chancery of Rome, and in the calendar of the breviary, wharton

title: Idiochira
body: Grseco-Lat. In the civil law. Ah instrument privately executed, as distinguished from such as were executed before a public officer. Cod. 8, 18, 11; Calvin

title: Idiocy
body: See Insanity

title: Idiot
body: A person who hns been withont understanding from hls nativity, nud w’hom the law, therefore, presumes never likely to attain any. Shelf. Lun. 2. See Insanity

title: Idiota
body: In' tbo civil law. An unlearned, illiterate, or simple person. Calvin. A private man; one not in office

title: Idiota Inquirendo, Writ De
body: This is the name of an old writ which directs the sheriff to inquire whether a man be an idiot or not. The Inquisition is to be made by a Jury of twelve men. Fitzh. Nat Brev. 2321 ..And, if the man were found an idiot, the profits of hls lands and the cos-tody of his person might be granted by Che

title: Idoneus
body: Lat. In the civil and com-mon law. Sufficient; competent; fit or proper; responsible; unimpeachable. Ido-neus homo, a responsible or solvent person; a good and lawful man. Sufficient; ade-quate; satisfactory. Idonea cautio, suffl-cient security

title: Idonietas
body: In old Engllsh law. AbU-ity or fitness, (of a parson.) Artie. Cleri, c. 13

title: Ii'Un Gia
body: In old Engllsh law. The fin-est whlte bread, formerly called “cocked bread." Blount

title: Iglise
body: L. Fr. A church. Kelham. Another form of “eglise.”

title: Ignis Judicium
body: Lat The old ju-dicial trial by fire. Blount

title: Ignitegium
body: In old English law. The curfew, or evenlng bell. Cowell. See Curfbw

title: Ignominy
body: Public dlsgrace; Infamy; reproach; dishonor. Ignominy ls the op-posite of esteem, wolff, f 145. See Brown v. Kingsley, 38 Iowa, 220

title: Ignoramus
body: Lat. “we are igno-rant;” “We Ignore it.” Formerly the grand jury used to write thls word on bills of ln-dictment wben, after having heard the evi-dence, they thought the accusation against the prisoner was groundless, intimating that, though the facts might possibly be true, the truth did not appear to them; but now they usually wrlte in English the words “Not a true bill,” or “Not found,” if that ls their verdict; but they are still said to ignore the bill. Brown

title: Ignorance
body: The want or absence of knowledge

title: Ignorantia
body: Lat. Ignorance; want of knowledge. Distinguished, from mistake, (error,) or wrong conception. Mackeld. Rom. Law, § 178; Dig. 22, 6. Divided by Lord Coke into ignorantia facti (ignorance of fact) and ignorantia juris, (ignorance of law.) And the former, he adds, is twofold.—lec-tionis et lingua, (Ignorance of reading and ignorance of language.) 2 Coke, 3b

title: Ignoratio Elenchi
body: Lat. A term of logic, sometimes applied to pleadings and to arguments on appeal, which signifies a mistake of the question, that is, the mistake of one who, failing to discern the real ques-tion which he Is to meet and answer, ad-dresses his allegations or arguments to a collateral matter or somethlng beside the point. See Case upon tbe Statute for Dis-tribution, wythe (Va.) 309

title: Ignore
body: 1. To be ignorant of, or un-acquainted with

title: Ill Fame
body: Evil repute; notorious bad character. Houses of prostitution, gaming

title: Illata Et Invecta
body: Lat Thlngs brought Into the honse for use by the ten-ant were so called, and were liable to the jus hypothec# of Roman law, just as they are to tbe landlord’s rlght of distress at common law

title: Illegal
body: Not authorized by law; U-licit; unlawful; contrary to law

title: Illegitimacy
body: The condition before the law, or the social status, of a bastard; the state or condition of one whose parents were not intermarried at the tlme of hls birth. Miller v. Miller, 18 Hun (N. Y.) 509; Brown v. Belmarde, 3 Kan. 62

title: Illegitimate
body: That whlch Is con-trary to law; It is usually applied to bas-tards, or children born out of lawful wed-lock

title: Illeviable
body: Not leviable; that can-not or ought not to be levled. Cowell

title: Illicenciatus
body: In old Engllsh law. Without license. Fleta, llb. 3, c. 5, i 12

title: Illicit
body: Not permitted or allowed; pro-hlbited; unlawful; as an illicit trade; <1

title: Illicite
body: Lat. Unlawfully. This word has a technical meanlng, and ls requisite ln an indictment where the act charged is un-lawful; as ln the case of a riot 2 Hawk

title: Illicitum Collegium
body: Lat An il

title: Illiterate
body: Unlettered; ignorant; unlearned. Generally used of oue who can-not read and write. See In re Succession of Carroll, 28 La. Ann. 388

title: Illocable
body: Incapable of being placed eut or hired

title: Illud
body: Lat That

title: Illusion
body: In medical jurisprudence. An image or Impression in the mind, excited by some external object addressing itself to one or more of the senses, bnt which, in-stead of corresponding with the reality, is perverted, distorted, or wholly mistaken, the error being attributable to the imagination of the observer, not to any defect in the or-gans of sense. See Hallucination, and see "Delusion," under Insanity

title: Illustrious
body: The prefix to the title of a prince of the biood in England

title: Imagine
body: In English law. In cases ot treason the law makes lt a crime to lmag-ine the death of the king. But, in order to complete the crime, this act of the mind must be demonstrated by some overt act. The terms “imagining” and “compassing’* are in this connection synonymous. 4 BL Comm. 78

title: Imaum
body: IMAM, or IMAUM. A Moham-medan prince having supreme spiritual as well as temporal power; a regular priest of the mosqu

title: Imbargo
body: An old form of “embargo,** (q. v.) SL 18 Car. II. c. 8

title: Imbasing Of Money
body: The act of

title: Imbecility
body: See Insanity

title: Imbezzle
body: An occasional or obsolete form of “embezzle,” (q. t

title: Imbladare
body: In old English law. To plant or sow graln. Bract fol. 176b

title: Imbracery
body: See Embracery

title: Imbrocus
body: A brook, gutter, or water-passage. CowelL

title: Imitation
body: The maklng of one thlng In the similitude or likeness of another; as, counterfeit coin ls said to be made “ln lmita-tlon" of the genuine. An imitation of a trade-mark is that which so far resembles the genuine trade-mark as to be likely to induce the belief that it is genuine, whether by the use of words or letters similar ln appearance or in sound, or by any sign, device, or other menns. Pen. Code N. Y. 1903, t 308; wagner v. Daly, 67 Hun, 477, 22 N. Y. Supp. 493; State v. Harris, 27 N. C. 294

title: Immaterial
body: Not material, essential, or necessary; not lmportant or pertinent; not decisive

title: Immediate
body: 1. Present; at once; without delay; not deferred by any Interval of time. In this sense, the word, without any very precise signification, denotes that action is or must be taken either Instantly or without any considerable loss of time

title: Immediately
body: “It is Impossible to lay down any hard and fast rule as to what is the meaning of the word ‘immediately’ in all cases. The words ‘forthwith’ and ‘im-mediately* have the same meaning. They are stronger than the expression *within a reasonable time,’ and Imply prompt, vigor-ous action, without auy delay, and whether there has been such action is a question of fact having regard to the circumstances of the particular case." Cockburn, C. J., in Reg. v. Justices of Berkshire, 4 Q. B. Div. 471

title: Immemorial
body: Beyond human mem-ory; time out of mind

title: Immeubles
body: Fr. These are, ln French law, the immovables of English law. Thlngs are immeubles from any one of three causes: (3) From their own nature, e. g., lands and houses; (2) from their destina-tion, e. g., animals and instruments of agri-culture when supplied by the landlord; or (3) hy the object to which they are annexed, e. g., easements. Brown

title: Immigration
body: The coming Into a country of foreigners for purposes of per-manent residence. The correlative term “emigration” denotes the act of such persons in leaving thelr former country

title: Imminent Danger
body: In relation to homlclde in self-defense, this term means immediate danger, such as must be instantly met, such as cannot be guarded against by calling for the assistance of others or the protection of the law. U. S. v. outer-bridge, 27 Fed. Cas. 390; State v. west, 45 La. Ann. 14, 12 South. 7; State v. Smith, 43 or. 109, 71 Pac. 973. or, as otherwise defined, such an appearance of threatened and Impending Injury as would put a rea-sonable and prudent man to his instant de-fense. State v. Fontenot, 50 La. Ann. 537, 23 South. 634, 69 Am. St Rep. 455; Shorter ▼. People, 2 N. Y. 201, 51 Am. Dec. 286

title: Immiscere
body: Lat In the civil law. To mix or mingle with; to meddle with; to Join wlth. Calvin

title: Immittere
body: Lat. In tbe civU law. To put or let into, as a beam into a wall, fcalvin; Dlg. 50, 17, 242, 1

title: Immobilis
body: Let Immovable. Immobilia or res immobiles, immovable things, such as lands and buddings. Mackeld. Rom. Law, 1160

title: Immoral
body: Contrary to good morals; Inconsistent wlth the rules and principles of morality which regard men as living ln a community, and which are necessary for the public welfare, order, and decency

title: Immorality
body: TY. That whlch to contra bonos mores. See Immoral

title: Immovables
body: In the clvll law. Property which, from its nature, destination, or the object to which it is applied, cannot move itself, or be removed

title: Immunity
body: An exemption from serv-ing in an office, or performing duties which the law generally requires other citizens to perform. Long v. Converse, 91 U. S. 113, 23 L. Ed. 233; Ex parte Levy, 43 Ark. 54, 51 Am. Rep. 550; Lonas v. State, 3 Heisk. (Tenn.) 306; Douglass v. Stephens, 1 Del. Ch. 476

title: Impaib
body: To weaken, diminish, or relax, or otherwlse affect In an lnjurlous manner. Davey v. 2Etna L. Ins. Co. (C. C.) 20 Fed. 482; State v. Carew, 13 Rich. Law (S. C.) 541, 91 Am. Dec. 245; Swinburne v. Mills, 17 wash. 611, 50 Pac. 489, 61 Am. St. Rep. 932

title: Impairing The Obligation Op Contracts
body: T8. For the meaning of this phrase in the constitution of the United States, see 2 Story, Const. §§ 1374-1399; 1 Kent, Comm. 413-422; Pom. Const Law; Black, Const Law (3d Ed.) p. 720 et seq

title: Impanel
body: In English praotioe. To

title: Imparcare
body: In old English law. To impound. Reg. orig. 92b

title: Impargamentum
body: The right of im-pounding cattle

title: Imparl
body: To have license to settle a litigation amicably; to obtain delay for ad-Justment

title: Imparlance
body: In early practice, imparlance meant time given to either of the parties to an action to answer the pleading of the other. It thus amounted to a continuance of the action to a further day. Literally the term signified leave given to the parties to talk together; i. e., with a view to settling their differences amicably. But in modern practice lt denotes a time given to the defendant to plead

title: Imparsonee
body: L. Fr. In ecdeslas-tical law. one who is Inducted and in possession of a benefice. Parson lmparsonee, (persona impersonata.) Cowell; Dyer, 40

title: Impatronization
body: In ecclesiastical law. The act of putting Into full possession of a benefice

title: Impeach
body: To accuse; to charge a liability upon; to sue

title: Impeachment
body: A criminal proceed-lng against a public officer, before a quasi political court, instituted by a written accu-sation called “articles of impeachment;” for example, a written accusation by the house of representatives of the United States to

title: Impechiare
body: To Impeach, to accuse, or prosecute for felony or treason

title: Impediens
body: In old practice, one who hinders; an lmpedlent. The defendant or deforciant in a flne was sometimes so called. Cowell; Blount

title: Impedimento
body: In Spanish law. A prohibition to contract marriage, established by law between certain persons

title: Impediments
body: Disabilities, or hin-drances to the making of contracts, snch as coverture, infancy, want of reason, etc

title: Impeditor
body: In old English law. A disturber in the action of quare impedit. St Marlb. c. 12

title: Impens.X
body: Lat. In the civil law. Ex-penses; outlays. Mackeld. Rom. Law, S 168; Calvin. Divided into necessary, (necessaries,) useful, (utiles,) and tasteful or orna-mental, (voluptuaries.) Dig. 50, 16, 79. See Id. 25, 1

title: Imperative
body: See Dibectobt

title: Imperfect
body: As used in various legal compound terms, this word means defective or incomplete; wanting in some legal or formal requisite; wanting in legal sanction or effectiveness; as in speaking of imperfect “obligations," “ownership," “rights," “title," “usufruct,” or “war.” See those nouns

title: Imperitia
body: Lat. Unskillfulness; want of skill

title: Imperium
body: The right to command, which includes the right to employ the force of the state to enforce the laws. Thls ls one of the principal attributes of the power ot the executive. 1 Toullier, no. 58

title: Impertinence
body: Irrelevancy; the fault of not properly pertaining to the issue or proceeding. The introduction of any mat-ters into a bill, answer, or other pleading or proceeding in a suit, which are not properly before the court for decision, at any particular stage of the suit Story, Eq. PL

title: Impertinent
body: In equity pleading

title: Impescare
body: In old records. To im* peach or accuse. Impescatus, Impeached. Blount

title: Impetrare
body: In old English practice. To obtain by request, as a writ or privilege. Bract fols. 57, 172b. This appllcatlon of the word seems to be derlved from the clvll law. Calvin

title: Impetration
body: In old English law. The obtaining anything by petition or en-treaty. Particularly, the obtaining of a benefice from Rome by solicitation, which benefice belonged to the disposal of the king er other lay patron, webster; CowelL

title: Imfier
body: Umpire, (q. v

title: Impierment
body: Impairing or prejudle-Ing. Jacob

title: Impignorata
body: Pledged; given in pledge, (pignori data;) mortgaged. A term applied ln Bracton to land. Bract, fol. 20

title: Impignoration
body: The act of pawn-lng or putting to pledge

title: Implacitare
body: Let To Implead; to sue

title: Implead
body: In practice. To sue or prosecute by due course of law. People ▼. Clarke, 0 N. Y. 368

title: Impleaded
body: Sued or prosecuted; used particularly in the titles of causes where there are several defendants; as “A. B., im-pleaded with C. D.”

title: Implements
body: Snch things as are used or employed for a trade, or furniture of a house. Coolidge ▼. Choate, 11 Metc. (Mass.) 82

title: Implicata
body: A term used in mercan-tile law, derived from.the Italian. In order to avoid the risk of making fruitless voyages, merchants have been in the habit of receiv-ing small adventures, on freight, at so much per cent, to which they are entitled at all events, even if the adventure be lost; and this is called “implicata.” wharton

title: Implication
body: Intendment or infer-ence, as dlstlngulshed from the actual expression of a thlng In words. In a wlll, an estate may pass by mere implication, without any express words to direct Its course. 2 BL Comm. 381

title: Implied
body: This word is nsed in law as contrasted with “express;” i. where the Intention in regard to the subject-matter is not manifested by explicit and direct words, but is gathered by implication or necessary deduction from the circumstances, the gen-eral language, or the conduct of the parties

title: Importation
body: The act of bringing goods and merchandise Into a country from a foreign country

title: Imports
body: Importations; goods or other property imported or brought into the country from a foreign country

title: Imfortunity
body: Pressing solicitation; urgent request; application for a claim or favor which is urged with troublesome frequency or pertinacity, webster

title: Imposition
body: An Impost; tax; contribution. Paterson v. Society, 24 N. J. Law, 400; Singer Mfg. Co. v. Heppenheimer, 58

title: Impossible Contracts
body: An impossible contract is one which the law will not hold binding upon the parties, because of the natural or legal impossibility of the performance by one party of that which is the consideration for the promise of the other. 7 wait, Act ft Def. 124

title: Imfosts
body: Taxes, duties, or impositions. A duty on imported goods or merchandise. Story, Const § 949. And see Norris v. Bos-ton, 4 Metc. (Mass.) 296; Pacific Ins. Co. v. Soule, 7 wait 435, 19 L. Ed. 93; woodruff v. Parham, 8 wall. 131, 19 L Ed. 382; Dooley v. U. S., 183 U. S. 151, 22 Sup. Ct 62, 43 L. Ed. 128; Passenger Cases, 7 How. 407, 12 L. Ed. 702

title: Imfotence
body: In medical jurisprudence. The incapacity for copulation or propagating the species. Properly used of the male; but it has also been used synonymously with “sterility.” Griffeth v. Griff-eth, 162 111. 368, 44 N. E. 820; Payne v. Payne, 46 Mlnn. 467, 49 N. W. 230, 24 Am. St Rep. 240; Kempf v. Kempf, 34 Mo. 213

title: Imp O Tent I Am, Property Propter
body: A qualified property, which may subsist In animals ferae natura on account of thelr inability, as where hawks, herons, or other birds build In a person's trees, or conies, etc., make thelr nests or burrows In a person’s land, and have yonng there, such person has a qualified property ln them till they can fly or run away, and then snch property expires. 2 Steph. Comm. (7th Ed.)

title: Impound
body: To shut up stray animals or distrained goods ln a pound. Thomas v. Harries, 1 Man. & G. 703; Goodsell v. Dunning, 34 Conn. 257; Howard v. Bartlett, 70 VL 314. 40 Atl. 825

title: Imprescriptibility
body: The state or quality of being incapable of prescription; not of such a character that a right to it can be gained by prescription

title: Imprescriptible Rights
body: Such rights as a person may use or not. at pleasure, since they cannot be lost to him by

title: Impression
body: A “case of the first im-pression” is one without a precedent; one presenting a wholly new state of facts; one Involving a question never before determined

title: Impressment
body: A power possessed by the English crown of taking persons or property to aid ln the defense of the country, with or without the consent of the persons concerned. It ls usually exercised to obtain hands for the royal ships in time of war, by taking seamen engaged in merchant vessels, (1 Bl. Comm. 420; Maud & P. Shipp. 123:) but in former times impressment of merchant ships was also practiced. The admiralty issues protections against impress-ment in certain cases, either under statutes passed in favor of certain callings (e. g., persons employed in the Greenland fisheries) or voluntarily. Sweet

title: Imprest Money
body: Money pald on enlisting or lmpresslng soldiers or sailors

title: Impretiabilis
body: Lat. Beyond price; invaluable

title: Imprimatur
body: Lat. Let lt be prlnted. A license or allowance, granted by the constituted authorities, giving permisslon to print and publish a book. This allowance wns formerly necessary, ln England, before any book could lawfully be printed, and in some other countries is still required

title: Imprimere
body: To press upon; to impress or press; to imprint or print

title: Imprimery
body: In some of the ancient English statutes this word is used to signify a printing-office, the art of printing, a print or impression

title: Imprimis
body: Lat In the first place; first of all

title: Imprison
body: To put ln a prison; to put in a place of confinement

title: Imprisonment
body: The act of putting or confining a man in prison; the restraint of a man’s personal liberty; coercion exer-cised upon a person to prevent the free exer-clse of his powers of locomotion. State v. Shaw, 73 Vt 149, 50 Atl. 863; In re Langs-low, 167 N. Y. 314, 60 N. E. 590; In re Langan (C. C.) 123 Fed. 134; Steere v. Field, 22 Fed. Cas. 1221

title: Impristi
body: Adherents; followers. Those who slde wlth or take the part of another, either in his defense or otherwise

title: Improbation
body: In Scotch law. An action brought for the purpose -of having some instrument declared false and forged. 1 Forb. Inst pt 4, p. 161. The verb “lm-prove” (q. v.) was used in the same sense

title: Improper
body: Not suitable; unfit; not suited to the character, time, and place. Palmer v. Concord, 48 N. H. 211, 97 Am. Dec. 605. wrongful. 53 Law J. P. D. 65

title: Impropriate Rector
body: In ecclesiastical law. Commonly signifies a lay rector as opposed to a spiritual rector; just as irn-propriate tithes are tithes in the hands of a lay owner, as opposed to approprlate tithes, which are tithes in the hands of a spiritual owner. Brown

title: Impropriation
body: In ecclesiastical law. The annexing an ecclesiastical bene-flee to the use of a lay person, whether indl-vidual or corporate, In the same way as appropriation i§ the annexing of any such bene-flce to the proper and perpetual use-of some splritual corporation, whether sole or aggre-gate, to enjoy forever. Brown

title: Improve
body: In Scotch law. To dls-prove; to invalidate or Impeach; to prove false or forged. 1 Forb. InsL pt 4, p. 162

title: Improved
body: Improved land is such as has been reclaimed, is used for the purpose of husbandry, and ls cultivated as such, whether the appropriation is for tillage, meadow, or pasture. “Improve" is synonymous with “cultivate.” Clark v. Phelps, 4 Cow. (N. Y.) 190

title: Improvement
body: A valuable addition made to property (usually real estate) or an amelioration in its condition, amounting to more than mere repairs or replacement of waste, costing labor or capltal, and Intended to enhance lts value and utility or to adapt it for new or further purposes. Spencer v. Tobey, 22 Barb. (N. Y.) 269; Allen v. McKay, 120 Cal. 332, 62 Pac. 828; Simpson v. Robinson, 37 Ark. 132

title: Improvements
body: A term used ln leas-es, of doubtful meaning. It would seem to apply principally to buildings, though generally it extends to the amelioration of every description of property, whether real or personal; but, when contained in any document, its meaning is generally explained by other words. 1 Chlt Gen. Pr. 174

title: Impruiare
body: In old records. To im-prove land. Impruiamcntum, tbe improve-ment so made of lt Cowell

title: Impulse
body: As to “irresistible” or "un-con trollable” impulse, see Insanitt

title: Impunity
body: Exemption or protection from penalty or punishment Dillon v. Rogers, 36 Tex. 153

title: Imputatio
body: LaL In the civil law. Legal llabillty

title: Imputation Of Payment
body: In the

title: Imputed
body: As used in legal phrases, thls word means attributed vicariously; that is, an act, fact, or quality ls said to be “imput-ed” to a person when it is ascribed or charged to him, not because he is personally cognizant of it or responsible for it, but because another person ls, over whom he has control or for whose acts or knowledge he ls re-sponsible

title: In Agtion
body: Attainable or recoverable by actlon; not ln possesslon. A term ap-plied to property of which a party has not the possession, but only a rlght to recover it by action. Things in action are rights of personal things, whicb nevertheless are not in possession. See Chose in Action

title: In Adversum
body: Against an adverse, unwilling, or resisting party. “A decree not by consent, but in adversum." 3 Story, 818

title: In Ajqua Manu
body: In equal hand. Fle-te, lib. 3, c. 14, f 2

title: In Jequali Manu
body: In equal hand; held equally or indifferently between two parties, where an instrument was deposit-ed by the parties to it ln tbe hands of a third

title: In Aueno Solo
body: In another's land

title: In Alio Loco
body: In another place

title: In Aperta Luce
body: In open daylight; ln tbe day-time. 9 Coke, 65b

title: In Apicibus Juris
body: Among the sub-tleties or extreme doctrines of the law. 1 Eames, Eq. 190. See Apex Juris

title: In Arbitrium Judicis
body: At the

title: In Arcta Et Salva Custodia
body: In

title: In Artigulo
body: In a moment; imme-diately. Cod. 1, 64, 2

title: In Articulo Mortis
body: In the article of death; at the point of death. Jack-son ▼. Vredenbergh, 1 Johns. (N. Y.) 159

title: In Autre Droit
body: L. Fr. In anoth-er’s right As representing another. An ex

title: In Banco
body: In hank; ln the bench. A term applied to proceedings in the court ln bank, as distinguished from proceedings at nisi prius. Also, in the English court of common beuch

title: In Being
