title: Loculus
body: In old records. A cotfin; a purse

title: Locum Tenens
body: Lat Holding the place. A deputy, substitute, lieutenant, or representative

title: Locuples
body: Lat In the civil law. Able to respond in an action; good for the amount which the plaintiff might recover. Dig. 50, 16, 234, L

title: Locus
body: Lat A place; the place where a thing is done

title: Lode
body: This term, as used in the legis-lation of congress, is applicable to any zone or belt of miueralized rotit lying within boundaries clearly separating it from the neigh boriug rock. It includes all deposits of miueral matter found through a miueral-ized zone or belt coming from the same source, impressed with the same forms, and appearing to have been created by the same processes. Eureka Consol. Min. Co. v. Richmond Min. Co., 4 Sawy. 312, 8 Fed. Cas. 823. And see Duggan v. Davey, 4 Dak. 110, 26 N. W. 887; Stevens v. williams, 23 Fed. Cas. 42; Montana Cent Ry. Co. v. Migeon (C. C.) 68 Fed. 813; Meydenbauer v. Stevens (D. C.) 78 Fed. 790; Iron Silver Min. Co. v. Cheeseman, 116 U. S. 529, 6 Sup. Ct. 481, 29 L. Ed. 712; U. S. v. Iron Silver Miu. Co., 128 U. S. 673, 9 Sup. Ct. 195, 32 L. Ed. 571

title: Loadsman
body: or LOADSMAN. The pilot conducts the ship up the river-or Into port; but the loadsman is he that undertakes to bring a ship through the haven, after being brought thither by the pilot, to the quay or place of discharge. Jacob.

title: Lodemanage
body: The hire of a pilot for conducting a vessel from oue place to another. CowelL

title: Lodger
body: one who occupies hired apnrt-ments iu another’s house; a tenant of part of another’s house

title: Lodgings
body: Habitation in another’s house; apartments ln another’s house, fur-nished or unfurnished, occupied for habita-tion; the occupier heing termed a “lodger

title: Lods Et Ventes
body: In old French and Canadian law. A flne payable by a roturier on every change of ownership of his land; a mutation or alienation fine, Steph. Lect. 351

title: Log-Book
body: A ship’s Journal. It con-tains a minute account of the ship's course^ with a short history of every occurrence dur-' lng the voyage. 1 Marsh. Ins. 312

title: Log-Rolling
body: A mischievous legisla-tive practice, of embracing in one bill several distinct matters, none of which, perhaps, could singly obtain the assent of the legis-lature, and then procuring its passage hy a combination of the minorities in favor of each of the measures Into a majority that will adopt them all. walker v. Griffith, 60 Ala. 369; Com. v. Barnet, 199 Pa. 161, 48 Atl. 976, 55 L. R. A. 882; o’Leary v. Cook County, 28 111. 534; St. Louis v. Tiefel, 42 Mo. 590

title: Logating
body: An unlawful game mention-ed in SL 33 Hen. VIII. c. 9

title: Logia
body: A small house, lodge, or cot-tage. Mon. Angl. tom. 1, p. 400

title: Logic
body: The science of reasoning, or of the operations of the understanding wbich are subservient to the estimation of evidence. The term includes both tlie process Itself of proceeding from known truths to unknown, and all other lntellectual operations, In so far as auxiliary to this

title: Logium
body: In old records. A lodge, hov-el, or outhouse

title: Logographus
body: In Roman law. A*' public clerk, register, or book-keeper; one

title: Logs
body: Stems or trunks of trees cut into convenient lengths for the purpose of being afterwards manufactured into lumber of va-rious kinds; not including manufactured lumber of any sort, nor timber which is squared or otherwise shaped for use without further change ln form. Kolloch v. Parcher, 52 wis. 393, 9 N. W’. 67. And see Haynes v. Hayward, 40 Me. 148; State v. Addington, 121 N. C. 538, 27 S. E. 988; Code W. Va. 1899. p. 10n, 8 27 (Code 1906, S 2524

title: Lollards
body: A body of primitive Wes-leyans, who assumed importance about the time of John wycliffe, (1360,) and were very successful iu disseminating evangelical truth; but, being implicated (apparently against thelr wlll) in tbe insurrection of,the villeins in 1381, the statute De Haretico Comburen-do (2 Hen. IV. c. 15) was passed against them, for their suppression. However, they were not suppressed, and their representa-tives survive to the present day under vari-008 names and disguises. Brown

title: Lombards
body: A name given to the mer-chants of Italy, numbers of whom, during the twelfth and thirteenth centuries, were established as merchants and bankers in the principal cities of Europe

title: Londres
body: L. Fr. London. Yearb. P. 1 Edw. II. p. 4

title: Long
body: In various compound legal terms (see infra) this word carries a meaning not essentially different from its signification in the vernacular

title: Lookout
body: A proper lookout on a vessel is some one In a favorable position to see, stationed near enough to the helmsman to communicate with him, and to receive communications from bim, and exclusively employed in w’atchiug the movements of ves-sels which they are meetlug or about to pass. The Genesee Chief v. Fitzhugh, 12 How. 462, 13 L. Ed. 1058

title: Lopwood
body: A right in the inhabitants of a parish within a manor, in England, to lop for fuel, at certain periods of the year, the branches of trees growing upon the waste lands of the manor. Sweet

title: Loquela
body: Lat. A colloquy; talk. In old Engllsh law, this term denoted the oral altercations of the parties to a suit, which led to the issue, now called the “pleadings.” It also designated an “imparlance,” (q. r.,) both names evidently referring to the talk-ing together of tlie parties. Loqucla sine die, a postponement to an indefinite time

title: Lord
body: In Englisb law. A title o» honor or nobility belonging properly to the degree of baron, but applied also to the

title: Lordship
body: Iu English law. Domin* lou, manor, seigniory, domain; also a title of honor used to a nobleman not being a duke. It is also the customary titulary appellatlon of the judges and some other persons in authority and office

title: Loss
body: In inanranoe. The injury or damage sustained by the insured in consequence of the happening of one or more of the accidents or misfortunes against which tbe insurer, in consideration of the premium, has undertaken to indemnify the insured. 1 Bouv. Inst no. 1215

title: Lost
body: An article is “lost" when the owner has lost the possession or custody of it, iu-voluntarily and by any means, but more par-ticularly by accident or his own negligence or forgetfulness, and when he ls ignorant of its whereabouts or cannot recover lt by an ordinarily diligent search. See State Sav. Bank v. Buhl, 129 Mlch. 193, 88 N. W. 471, 56 L. R. A. 944; Belote v. State, 30 Mlss. 120, 72 Am. Dec. 163; Hoagland v. Amusement Co., 170 Mo. 335, 70 S. W. 878, 94 Am. SL Rep. 740

title: Lot And Scot
body: In English law. Cer-taln duties which must be paid by thosu who clalm to exercise the elective franchlse within certain cltles and boroughs, before they are entltled to vote. It Is said that the practlce became unlform to refer to the poor-rate as a register of “scot and lot” voters; so that the term, when employed to define a right of election, meant only the payment by a parishioner of the sum to which he was assessed on the poor-rate. Brown

title: Lot Of Land
body: A small tract or par-cel of land ln a village, town, or city, suitable for .building, or for a garden, or other simllar uses. See Pllz v. Klllingsworth, 20 or. 432. 26 Pac. 305; wilson v. Proctor, 28 Mlnn. 13, 8 N. W. 830; webster v. Little Rock, 44 Ark. 551; Diamond Mach. Co. v. Ontonagon, 72 Mlch. 261, 40 N. W. 448; Fitzgerald v. Thomas, 61 Mo. 500; Phlllipsbnrgh v. Bruch, 37 N. J. Eq. 486

title: Leyerwit
body: TE, or LEYERWIT. In

title: Lottery
body: A lottery ls any scheme for the disposal or distribution of property by chance among persons who have paid, or

title: Louage
body: Fr. This is the contract of hiring and letting in Freuch law, and may be either of things or of labor. The varieties of each are the following

title: Lourcurdus
body: A ram or bell-wether

title: Love-Day
body: In old English law. The day on whlch any dispute was amicably settled between neighbors; or a day on which one neighbor helps another without hire, wharton

title: Low Justice
body: In old European law, jurisdlction of petty offenses, as distinguished from “high Justice,’’ (q. v

title: Low Water
body: The furthest receding point of ebb-tide. Howard v. Ingersoll, 13 How. 417, 14 L. Ed. 189

title: Lowbote
body: A recompense for the death

title: Lowers
body: Fr. In French maritime law. wages, ord. Mar. llv. 1, tit. 14, art. 16

title: Loyal
body: Legal; authorized by or conforming to law. Also faithful in one’s polit-lcal relations; giving faithful support to one's prince or sovereign or to the existing government

title: Loyalty
body: Adherence to law. Faithfulness to one’s prince or sovereign or to the existing government

title: Lucid Intervals
body: In medical ju-risprudence. Intervals occurring in the men-tal life of an insane person during which he is completely restored to the use of his reason, or so far restored that be has suffl-dent intelligence, judgment, and will to enter Into contractual relations, or perform other legal acts, without disqualification by reason of his disease. See Insanity

title: Lucra Nuptlalia
body: Lat In Roman law. A term Including everything which a husband or wife, as such, acquires from the estate of the other, either before the marriage, or on agreeing to it, or during its continuance, or after its dissolution, and whether the acquisition is by pure gift, or by virtue of the marriage contract, or against the will of the other party by law or statute. See Mackeld. Rom. Law, § 580

title: Lucrativa Causa
body: Lat. In Roman law. A consideration which is voluntary; that is to say, a gratuitous gift, or such like. It was opposed to onerosa causa, which denoted a valuable consideration. It was a principle of the Roman law that two lucra-tive causes could not concur in the same person as regarded the same thing; that ls to say, that, when the same thing was bequeath-ed to a person by two different testators, he could not have the thing (or its value) twice over. Brown

title: Lucrativa Usucapio
body: Lat This

title: Lucrattve
body: Yielding gain or profit; profitable; bearing or yielding a revenue or salary. •

title: Lucratus
body: ln Scotch law. A gainer

title: Lucre
body: Gain in money or goods; profit; usually in an ill sense, or with the sense of something base or unworthy, webster

title: Lucri Causa
body: Lat In criminal law. A term descriptive of the intent with which property is taken in cases of larceny, the phrase meaning “for the sake of lucre" or gain. State v. Ryan, 12 Nev. 403, 28 Am. Rep. 802; State v. Slingerland, 19 Nev. 135, 7 Pac. 280

title: Lucrum Cessans
body: Lat. In Scotch law. A ceasing gain, as distinguished from damnum datum, an actual loss

title: Luctuosa Habreditas
body: AS. A mournful inheritance. See H^keditas Luctuosa

title: Luctus
body: In Roman law. Mourning. See Annus Luctus

title: Luggage
body: Luggage may consist of any articles intended for the use of a passenger while traveling, or for his personal equip-ment. Civ. Code Cal. $ 2181

title: Lumen
body: Lat. In the civil law. Light; the light of the sun or sky; the privilege of receiving light into a house

title: Lumina
body: Lat In the civil law. Lights; windows; openings to obtain light for one’s building

title: Luminare
body: A lamp or candle set burning on the altar of any church or chapel, for the maintenance whereof lands and rent-charges were frequently given to parish churches, etc. Kennett, Gloss

title: Lumping Sale
body: As applied to judicial sales, this term means a sale in mass, as

title: Lunacy
body: Lunacy is that condition or habit in which the mind is directed by the will, but is wholly or partially misguided or erroneously governed by it; or it is the im-pairment of any one or more of the faculties of the mind, accompanied with or inducing a defect in the comparing faculty, owlngs’ Case, 1 Bland (Md.) 388, 17 Am. Dec. 311: See Insanity

title: Lunar
body: Belonging to or measured by the revolutions of the moon

title: Lunatic
body: A person of deranged or un-sound mind; a person whose mental faculties are in the condition called "lunacy,” (q. v

title: Lundress
body: In old English law. A silver penny, so called because it was to be coln-ed only at London, (a Londres,) and not at the country mints. Lown. Essay Coins, 17; Cowell

title: Lupanatrix
body: A bawd or strumpet. 3 lnst. 206

title: Lupinum Caput Gerere
body: Lat. To be outlawed, and have one’s head exposed, like a wolfs, with a reward to him who should take it. Cowell

title: Lurgulary
body: Casting any corrupt or poisonous thing into the water, wharton

title: Lushborow
body: In old English law. A base sort of money, coined beyond sea in the likeness of English coin, and introduced Into England in the reign of Edward III. Prohibited by St 25 Edw. III. c. 4. Spelman; Cowell

title: Luxury
body: Excess and extravagance which was formerly an offense against the public economy, but is not now punishable, wharton

title: Lych-Gate
body: The gate Into a church-yard, with a roof or awning hung on posts over It to cover the body brought for burial, when lt rests underneath, wharton

title: Lyef-Geld
body: Sax. In old records. Lief silver or money; a small flne paid by the customary tenant to the lord for leave to plow or sow, etc Somn. Gavelkind, 27

title: Lying By
body: A person who, hy hls pres-ence and silence at a transaction which affects hls interests, may be fairly supposed to acquiesce ln it, if he afterwards propose to disturb the arrangement, is said to be pre-vented from doing so by reason that he has been lying by

title: Lying In Franchise
body: A term descriptive of waifs, wrecks, estrays, and the like, which may be seized without snit or action

title: Lying In Grant
body: A phrase applied to Incorporeal rights, Incapable of manual tra-ditlon, and whlch must pass by mere dellv-ery of a deed

title: Lying In Wait
body: Lying ln ambush; lying hid or concealed for the purpose of making a sudden and unexpected attack upon a person when he shall arrive at the scene. In some jurisdictions, where there are sev-eral degrees of murder, lying ln wait is made evidence of that deliberation and premedltat

title: Lynch Law
body: A term descriptive of the action of unofficial persons, organized bands, or mobs, who seize persons charged with or suspected of crimes, or take them out of the custody of the law, and Inflict sum-mary punishment upon them, without legal trial, and without the warrant or authority of law. See State v. Aler, 39 W. Va. 549, 20 S. E. 585; Bates’ Ann. St ohio, 1904, | 4426

title: Lyon King Of Arms
body: In Scotch law. The ancient duty of this officer was to carry public messages to foreign states, and lt ls still the practice of the heralds to make all royal proclamations at the Cross of Edinburgh. The officers serving under him are heralds, pursuivants, and messengers. Bell

title: Lytje
body: In old Roman law. A name given to students of the dvil law in the fourth year of their course, from their being supposed capable of solving any difficulty in law. Tayl. Civil Law, 39

title: Mace
body: A large staff, made of the precious metals, and highly ornamented. It is nsed as an emblem of authority, and carried before certain public functionaries hy a mace-bearer. In many legislative bodies, the mace ls employed as a visible symbol of the dlg-nity and collective authority of the house! In the house of lords and house of commons of the British parliament, it ls laid upon the table when the house is in session. In the United States house of representatives, it ls borne upright hy the sergeant-at-arms on extraordinary occasions, as when it is necessary to quell a disturbance or bring refractory members to order

title: Mace-Greff
body: In old English law. one who buys stolen goods, particularly food, knowing it to have been stolen

title: Macedonian Decree
body: In Roman law. This was the Benatus-consuUwn Mace-donianum, a decree of tbe Roman senate, first given under Claudius, and renewed un-der Vespasian, by whlch it was declared that no action should be maintained to recover a loan of money made to a child who was un-der the patria potestas. It was lntended to strike at the practice of usurers ln making

title: Machecollare
body: To make a warlike device over a gate or other passage like to a grate, through which scalding water or pon-derous or offensive things may be cast npon the assailants. Co. IAtt 5a

title: Machination
body: Contriving a plot or conspiracy. The act of planning or contriv-ing a scheme for executing some purpose, particularly an evil purpose; an artful design formed with deliberation

title: Machine
body: In patent law. Any contrivance used to regulate or augment force or motlon; more properly, a complex structure, consisting of a combination, or peculiar modification, of the mechanical powers

title: Machinery
body: A more comprehensive term than “machine;" Including the appurtenances necessary to the working of a ma-. chine. Seavey v. Central Mut F. Ins. Co., Ill Mass. 540

title: Macholum
body: In old Engllsh law. A barn or granary open at the top; a rlck or stack of corn. Spelman

title: Mactator
body: L. Lat In old European law. A murderer

title: Maoulare
body: In old European law. To. wound. Spelman.

title: Mad Point
body: A term used to designate the idea or subject to which is confined the derangement of the mental faculties of one suffering from monomania, owing’s Case, 1 Bland (Md.) 388, 17 Am. Dec. 311. See In-sanity

title: Made Known
body: where a writ of seire facias has been actually served upon a de-fendant, the proper return is that its con-tents have been “made known” to him

title: Madman
body: An insane persou, partlcu-larly one suffering from mania in any of its forms. Said to be inapplicable to idiots (Com. v. Haskell, 2 Brewst. [Pa.] 497); but it is not a technical term either of medlciue or the law, and ls incapable of being applied with scientific precision. See Insanity

title: Madness
body: See Insanity

title: Madras Regulations
body: Certain regulations prescribed for the government of the Madras presidency. Mozley & whltley

title: Mabc-Burgh
body: In Saxon law. Kin-dred; family

title: Msgbote
body: In Saxon law. A recompense or satisfaction for the slaying or mur-der of a kinsman. Spelman

title: Msre
body: Famous; great; noted; as z2?l-mere, all famous. Gibs. Camd

title: Mjeremium
body: Timber; wood suitable tor building purposes

title: Magic
body: In English statutes, witch-craft and sorcery

title: Magis
body: Lat. More; more fully; more ln number; rather

title: Magister
body: Lat. In Englisb law. A master or ruler; a person who has attained to some eminent degree in science. Cowell

title: Magisterial
body: Relating or pertaining to the character, office, powers, or duties of a magistrate or of the magistracy

title: Magistracy
body: This term may have a more or less extensive signification according to the use and connection in which it occurs. In its widest sense it includes the whole body of public functionaries, whether thelr offices be legislative, judicial, executive, or admin-istrative. In a more restricted (and more usual) meaning, It denotes the class of offi-Oers who are charged with the application and execution of the laws. In a still more confined use, It deslgnates the body of judi-cial officers of the lowest rank, and more es-pecially those who have Jurisdiction for the trial and punishment of petty misdemeanors or the preliminary steps of a criminal prosecution, such as police judges and justices of the peace. Tlie term also denotes the office of a magistrate

title: Magistralia Brevia
body: In old English practice. Magisterial writs; writs adapt-ed to special cases, and so called from being

title: Magistrate
body: A public officer belonging to the civil organization of the state, and invested with powers and functions which may be either judicial, legislative, or execu-tive

title: Magistratus
body: Lat In the clvll law. A magistrate. Calvln. A judlclal officer who had the power of hearlng and determin-lng causes, but whose office properly was to lnqulre Into matters of law, as distinguished from fact. Hallifax, Clvll Law, b. 3, c. 8

title: Magna Assisa
body: In old Englisb law. The grand assize. Glanv. lib. 2, cc. 11, 12

title: Magna Assisa Eligenda
body: An an

title: Magna Averia
body: In old pleading. Great beasts, as horses, oxen, etc Cro. Jac

title: Magna Centum
body: The great hundred, or six score, wharton

title: Magna Charta
body: The great charter

title: Magna Oomponere Parvis
body: To

title: Magna Culpa
body: Great fault; gross negligence

title: Magna Negligently
body: In the civil law. Great or gross negligence

title: Magna Prec Aria
body: In old English law. A great or general reap-day. Cowell; Blount

title: Magna Serjeantia
body: In old English

title: Magnum Cape
body: In old practice. Great or grand cape. 1 Reeve, Eng. Law

title: Magnum Concilium
body: In old English law. The great council; the general council of the realm; afterwards called “parliament” 1 Bl. Comm. 148; 1 Reeve, Eng. Law, 62; Spelman

title: Magnus Rotulus Statutorum
body: The great statute roll. The first of the Eng-lish statute roils, beginnlug with Magna Charta, and ending wlth Edward III. Hale, Com. Law, 16, 17.

title: Maha-Gen
body: In Hlndu law. A banker or any great shop-keeper

title: Mahal
body: Iu Hlndu law. Any land or pnblic fund producing a revenae to the gov-ernment of Hlndostan. “Mahalaat” ls the plural

title: Mahlbrief
body: In maritime law. The German name for the contract for the building of a vessel. This contract contains a specification of the kind of vessel Intended, her dimensions, the time within which she is to be completed, the price and times of payment, etc. Jac. Sea Laws, 2-8

title: Maiden
body: In Scotch law. An instru-ment formerly used ln beheading criminals. It resembled the French guillotine, of which it is said to have been the prototype, whar-ton

title: Maiden Assize
body: In Engllsh law. originally an assize at which no person was condemned to-die. Now it Is a session of a criminal court at which there are no prison-ers to be tried

title: Maiden Rents
body: A flne paid by the tenants of some manors to the lord for a II-cense to marry a daughter. Cowell, or, perhaps, for the lord’s omitting the custom of marcheta, (q. v

title: Maignagium
body: A brasier’s shop, or, perhaps, a house. Cowell

title: Ma Them
body: See Mayhem; Maim

title: Maihematus
body: Maimed or wounded

title: Maihemium
body: In old English law. Mayhem, (q. v

title: Mail
body: As applied to the post-office, this term means the carriage of letters, whether applled to the hag lnto whlch they are put, the coach or vehicle by means of which they are transported, or any other means em-ployed for their carriage and delivery by publlc authority, wynen v. Schappert, 6 Daly (N. Y.) 560. It may also denote the letters or other matter so carried

title: Mailable
body: Sultable or admisslble for transmission by the mail; belonglng to the classes of articles which, by the laws and postal regulations, may be sent by post

title: Mails
body: In old English law. A klnd of anclent money, or silver half-pence; a small rent

title: Mailed
body: This word, as applled to a letter, means that the letter was properly prepared for transmisslon by the servants of the postal department, and that lt was put in the custody of the officer charged with the duty of forwarding the mail. Pier v. Helnrlchshoffen, 67 Mo. 163, 29 Am. Rep. 501

title: Mauls And Duties
body: In Scotch law. The rents of an estate. Bell

title: Maim
body: To deprive a person of a member or part of the body, the loss of which renders him less capable of fighting; to commit mayhem, (q. v.). State v. Johnson, 58 ohio St. 417, 51 N. E. 40, 65 Am. SL Rep. 769

title: Main
body: L. Fr. A hand. More common-ly written “megn.”

title: Main
body: Prlncipal, chlef, most Important in size, extent, or utility

title: Mainad
body: In old Engllsh law. A false oath; perjury. Cowell. Probably from Sax. “manath" or “mainath” a false or de-celtful oath

title: Maine-Port
body: A small tribute, commonly of loaves of bread, which ln some places the parishloners paid to the rector ln lieu of small tithes. Cowell

title: Mainour
body: In crlmlnal law. An article stolen, when found ln the bands of the thlef. A thlef caught with the stolen goods ln hls possession is said to be taken “wlth the mainour.” that is, with the property in manu, in his hands. 4 Bl. Comm. 307

title: Mainceuvre
body: or MAINCEUVRE. A

title: Mainpernable
body: Capable of belng bailed; bailable; admissible to bail on giv-lng surety by mainpernors

title: Mainpernor
body: In old practlce. A surety for the appearance of a person under arrest, who ls delivered out of custody Into the hands of his ball. “Mainpernors” dif-fer from “ball” in that a mnn’s bail may imprison or surrender him up before the stipulated day of appearance; mainpernors can do neither, but are barely sureties for hls appearance at the day. Bail are only sureties that the party be answerable for the speclal matter for which they stipulate; mainpernors are bound to produce him to answer all charges whatsoever. 3 Bl. Comm. 128. other distinctions are made ln tbe old books. See Cowell

title: Mainprise
body: SE. The dellvery of a person into tbe custody of mainpernors, (q. «.) Also the name of a writ (now obsolete) command-ing the sheriff to take the security of main-pernors and set the party at liberty

title: Mainsworn
body: Forsworn, by making false oath with hand (main) on hook. Used in the north of England. BrownL 4; Hob. 125

title: Maintain
body: To maintain an action or suit is to commence or institute it; the term imports the existence of a cause of action. Boutiller v. The Milwaukee, 8 Mlnn. 105, (Git 80, 81

title: Maintained
body: In pleading. A tech-nlcal word indispensable in an indictment for maintenance. 1 wils. 325

title: Maintainor
body: In criminal law. one that maintains or seconds a canse dependbig. ln suit between others, either by disbursing money or making friends for either party to-wards hls help. Blount one who is guilty of maintenance (q. v

title: Maintenance
body: Sustenance; support; assistance. The furnishing by one person to. Another, for his support, of the means of living, or food, clothing, shelter, etc., particularly where the legal relation of the par-ties is such that one is bound to support the other, as between father' and child, or hnsband and wife, wall v. williams, 93 N. C. 330, 53 Am. Rep. 458; winthrop Co. v. Clin-ton, 196 Pa. 472, 46 AU. 435, 79 Am. St Rep. 729; Regina v. Gravesend, 6 El. A Bl. 466; State v. Beatty, 61 Iowa, 307. 16 N. W. 149; In re warren Insane Hospital, 3 Pa. Dist R. 223

title: Maire
body: In old Sootob law. An ofiicer to whom process was directed, otherwise called “mair of fie,” (fee,) and classed with the “serjand.” Skene

title: Maieie
body: In French law. The govern-ment building of each commune. It con-tains the record office of ail civil acts nnd the list of voters; and it is there that political and municipal elections take place. Arg. Fr. Merc. Law, 566

title: Maison De Dieu
body: Fr. A hospital; an almshouse; a monastery. SL 39 Eliz. c

title: Maister
body: An old form, of “master.”

title: Maisura
body: A house, mansion, or farm. Cowell

title: Maitre
body: Fr. In‘French maritime law. Master; ’ the master or captain of a vessel, ord. Mar. liv. 2, tlt. 1, art L

title: Majestas
body: Lat. In Roman law. The majesty, sovereign, authority, or supreme prerogative of the state, or prince. Also a. shorter form of the expression “crimen majestatis” or “crimen l#*(r majestatis,” an offense against sovereignty, or against the safety or organic life of the Roman people

title: Majesty
body: Royal dignity. A term used ot kings and emperors as a title of honor

title: Major
body: A person of full age;. one wbo is no longer a minor; one who has attained the management of hls own concerns and the enjoyment of his civic rights

title: Major Annus
body: The greater year; the bissextile year, consisting of 366 days. Bract fo’. 359b

title: Major General
body: In mllitary law. An officer next in rank above a brigadier

title: Majora Regalia
body: The king's dig-nity, power, and royal prerogative, as op-posed to his revenue, which is comprised in the minora regalia. 2 Steph. Comm. 475; 1 Bl. Comm. 240

title: Majores
body: In Roman law and genealogical tables. The male ascendants be-yond the sixth degree

title: Majority
body: Full age; the age at which, by law, a person is entitled to the manage-ment of his own affairs and to the enjoyment of civic rights. The opposite of minority. Also tlie status of a person who is a major in age

title: Majus Jus
body: In old practice. Greater right or more right. A plea ln the old real actions. 1 Reeve, Eng. Law, 470. Majus jus mcrum, more mere right Bract, fol. 3L

title: Making Law
body: In old practice. The formality of denying a plaintiff’s charge under oath, in open court, with compurga-tors. one of the ancient methods of trial, frequently, though inaccurately, termed “waging law,” or “wager of law.” 3 Bl. Comm. 341

title: Mal Gree
body: L. Fr. Against the will; without the consent. Hence the slngle word "malgre,” and more modern “ mail g re,” (q.v

title: Mal-Tolte
body: Fr. In old French law. A term said to have arisen from the usurious gains of the Jews and Lombards in their management of the public revenue. Stepb. Lect 37X

title: Mala
body: Lat. Bad; evil; wrongful

title: Maladministration
body: This term is used, in the law-books, interchangeably with mis-adminlstratlon, and both words mean “wrong administration." Minkler v. State, 14 Neb. 183, 15 N. W. 331

title: Malandrinus
body: In old English law. A thief or pirate, wals. 338

title: Malary
body: In Hindu law. Judicial; belonging to a judge or magistrate

title: Malberge
body: A hill where the people assembled at a court, like the English assiz-es; which by the Scotch and Irish were called "parley hills.” Du Cange

title: Malconna
body: In Hindu law. A treasury or store-house

title: Male Creditus
body: In old English law. Unfavorably thought of; in bad repute or credit. Bract fols. 116, 154

title: Malediction
body: A curse, which was anciently annexed to donations of lands made to churches or religious houses, agaiust those w’ho should violate their rights. Cowell

title: Malefaction
body: A crime; an ofTense

title: Malefactor
body: He who is guilty, or has been convicted, of some crime or offense

title: Maleficium
body: In the civil law. waste; damage; tort; injury. Dig. 5, 18, L

title: Malison
body: or MALISON. A curse

title: Malsworn
body: N, or MALSWORN. For-sworn. Cowell

title: Malfeasance
body: The wrongful or unjust doing of some act which the doer has no right to perform, or which he has stipulated by contract not to do. It differs from “misfeasance" and “non-feasance," (which titles see.) See 1 Chit Pr. 9; 1 Chit Pl. 134; Dudley v. Flemlngsburg, 115 Ky. 5, 72 S. W. 327, 60 L. R. A. 575, 103 Am. St. Rep. 253; Colte v. Lynes, 33 Conn. 115; Bell v. Josse-iyn, 3 Gray (Mass.) 311, 63 Am. Dec. 741

title: Malfetria
body: In Spanish law. Offense. white, New Recop. b. 2, tlt. 19, C. 1, I 1

title: Malice
body: In oriminal law. In its

title: Malicious
body: Evincing malice; done with malice and an evil design; willful

title: Malignare
body: To malign or slander; also to maim

title: Malinger
body: To feign sickness or any physical disablement or mental lapse or de-rangement, especially for the purpose of escaping the performance of a task, duty, or work

title: Malitia
body: Lat Actual evil design; ex-press malice

title: Malo Animo
body: Lat with an evil mind; with a bad purpose or wrongful in-tention; with malice.

title: Malo Grato
body: Lat In spite.; ,unwillingly

title: Malo Sensu
body: Lat In jah^eyd^^se or meaning; with an evil signification

title: Malpractice
body: As applied to physi-cians and surgeons, this term means, general-ly, professional misconduct towards a pa-tlent which is considered reprehensible either because immoral in itself or because con-trary to law or expressly forbidden by law. In a more specific sense, it means had, wrong, or injudicious treatment of a patient, pro-fess ion ally and In respect to tbe particular disease or injury, resulting ln iujury, unnecessary suffering, or death to the patient

title: Malt
body: A substance produced from bar-ley or other grain by a process of steeping ln water until germination begins and then drying in a kiln, thus converting the starch into saccharine matter. See Hollender v. Magone (C. C.) 38 Fed. 915; U. S. v. Cohn, 2 Ind. T. 474, 52 S. W. 38

title: Maltreatment
body: In reference to the treatment of hls patient by a surgeon, this term signifies improper or unskillful treat-ment; it mny result either from Ignorance, neglect or willfulness; but the word does not necessarily imply that the conduct of the surgeon, in hls treatment of the patient, ls either willfully or grossly careless. Com. v. Hackett, 2 Allen (Mass.) 142

title: Malveilles
body: In old English law. Ill wlll; crlmes and misdemeanors; malicious practices. Cowell

title: Malveis Procurors
body: L. Fr. Such as used to pack juries, by the nomination of either party ln a cause, or other practice. Cowell

title: Malveisa
body: A warlike engine to batter and beat down walls

title: Malversation
body: In French law. This word ls applied to all grave and pun-ishable faults committed in the exercise of a charge or commission, (office,) such as corruption, exaction, concussion, larceny. Merl. Repert

title: Manacles
body: Chains for the hands; shackles

title: Manage
body: To conduct; to carry on; to direct the concerns of a business or establtsb-ment. Generally applied to affairs that are somewhat complicated and that Involve skill nnd judgment. Com. v. Johnson, 144 Pa. 377, 22 Atl. 703; Roberts v. State, 26 Fla. 360, 7 South. 861; Ure v. Ure, 185 111. 216, 56 N. E. 1087; Youngwortb v. Jewell, 15 Nev. 48; watson v. Cleveland, 21 Conn. 541; The Silvia, 171 U. S. 462, 19 Sop. Ct. 7, 43 L. Ed. 241

title: Managium
body: A mansion-house or dwell-ing-place. CowelL

title: Manas Medis
body: Men of a mean con-dltlon, or of the lowest degree

title: Manbote
body: In Saxon law. A compensation or recompense for homicide, particularly due to the lord for killing his man or vassal, the amount of which was regulated by that of the were

title: Mancusa
body: MANCUS, or MANCUSA. A

title: Manceps
body: Lat. ln Roman law. A pur-chaser ; oue w’ho took the artlcle sold In hls haud; a formality observed in certain sales. Calvin. A farmer of the public taxes

title: Manche-Present
body: A bribe; a present from the donor’s own haDd

title: Mancipare
body: Lat. In Roman law. To sell, alienate, or make over to another; to sell with certain formalities; to sell a person; one of the forms observed ln the pro-cess of emancipation

title: Mancipate
body: To enslave; to bind; to tie

title: Mancipatio
body: Lat. In Roman law. A certain ceremony or formal process anciently required to be performed, to perfect tbe sale or conveyance of res mancipi, (land, houses, slaves, horses, or cattle.) The parties were present, (vendor and vendee,) with five wit-nesses and a person called “libripens," who held a balance or scales. A set form of words was repeated on either side, indicative of transfer of ownership, aud certain pre-serlbed gestures performed, and the vendee then struck the scales with a piece of copper, thereby symbolizing the payment, or welgh-lng out, of the stipulated price

title: Mancipi Res
body: LaL In Roman law. Certain classes of thlngs which could not be aliened or transferred except by means of a certain formal ceremony of conveyance called “mancipatio:* (q. v.) These lncluded land, houses, slaves, horses, and cattle. All other things were called “res nec mancipi:’ The dlstlnction was abolished by Justinian. The distinction corresponded as nearly as may be to the early dlstlnction of English law lnto real and personal property; res mancipi belng objects of a mllitary or agricultural character, and res nec mancipi being all other subjects of property. Like personal estate, res nec mancipi were not originally either valuable in se or valued. Brown

title: Mancipium
body: Lat In Roman law. The momentary condition in which a fllius, etc., might be when ln course of emancipatlon from the potestas, and before that emanclpa-tlon was absolutely complete. The condltlou was not like the dominica potestas over slaves, but slaves are frequently called “man-cipia” ln the non-legal Roman authors. Brown

title: Manciple
body: A clerk of the kitchen, or caterer, especially ln colleges. Cowell

title: Mancomunal
body: In Spanish law. An obligation is said to he mancomunal when one person assumes the contract or debt of another, and makes hlmself liable to pay or fulfill it Schm. CivU Law, 120

title: Mandameento
body: In Spanish law. Commission; authority or power of attorney. A contract of good faith, hy which oue per-son commits to the gratuitous charge of an-other his affairs, a>d the latter accepts the charge, w’hite, New Recop. b. 2, tit. 12, c. 1

title: Mandans
body: Lat In the civil law. The employing party in a contract of mandate, one who gives a thing in charge to another; one who requires, requests, or employs an-other to do some act for him. Inst. 3, 27, 1, et seq

title: Mandant
body: In French and Scotch law. The employing party in the contract of man-datum, or mandate. Story, Bailm. $ 138

title: Mandataire
body: Fr. In French law. A person employed hy another to do some act for him; a mandatary

title: Mandatary
body: He to whom a mandate, charge, or commandment is given; also, he that obtains a benefice by mandamus. Briggs v. Spaulding, 141 U. S. 132, 11 Sup. CL 924, 36 L. Ed. 662

title: Mandate
body: In praotioe. A judlclal command or precept proceeding from a conrt or judicial officer, directing the proper officer to enforce a judgment, sentence, or decree. Seaman v. Clarke, 60 App. Div. 416, 69 N

title: Mandato
body: In Spanish law. The con-tract of mandate. 'Escriche

title: Mandato, Panes De
body: Loaves of bread given to the poor upon Maundy Thurs day

title: Mandator
body: The person employing an-other to perform a mandate

title: Mandatory
body: Containing a command; preceptive; imperative; peremptory. A pro-vision in a statute ls mandatory when dis-obedience to it will make the act done under

title: Mandatum
body: Lat In the civil law. The contract of mandate, (q. v

title: Mandavi Ballivo
body: (I have com-manded or made my mandate to the bailiff.) ln English practice. The return made by a sheriff, where the bailiff of a liberty has the execution of a writ, that he has commanded the bailiff to execute it 1 Tidd, Pr. 309 ; 2 Tidd, Pr. 1025

title: Manentes
body: Tenants. obsolete. Cowell

title: Manera
body: In Spanish law. Manner or mode. Las Partidas, pt 4, tit 4, 1. 2

title: Manerium
body: In old English law. A

title: Mangonare
body: In old English law. To buy in a market

title: Mangonellus
body: A warlike Instrument for casting stones against the walls of a castle. Cowell

title: Manhood
body: In feudal law. A term denoting the ceremony of doing homage by the vassal to hls lord. The formula used was, “Devento vester homo,” I become your man. 2 Bl. Comm. 54

title: Mania
body: See Insanitt

title: Manifest
body: In maritime law. A sea-letter; a written document required to be carried by merchant vessels, containing an account of the cargo, with other particulars, for the facility of the customs officers. See New York & Cuba S. S. Co. v. U. S. (D. C.) 125 Fed. 320

title: Manifesto
body: A formal written decla

title: Manipulus
body: In canon law. A hand-kerchief, whlch the priest always had in hle left hand. Blount

title: Mankind
body: The race or species of hn-man beings. In law, females, as well as males, may be included nnder thls term. Fortesc. 91

title: Manner
body: This Is a word of large sig-niflcatlon, but cannot exceed the subject to which lt belongs. The incident cannot be extended beyond Its principal, wells v.- Bain, 75 Pa. 39, 54,15 Am. Rep. 563

title: Manner And Form; Modo Et Forma
body: Formal words Introduced at the concluslon of a traverse. Their object ls to put the party whose pleading is traversed not only to the proof that the matter of fact de-nied is, in its geueral effect, true as alleged, but also that the manner and form ln whlch the fact or facts are set forth are also ca-pable of proof. Brown

title: Manning
body: A day’s work of a man. Cowell. A summoning to court. Spelman

title: Mannire
body: To cite any person to ap-pear in court and stand in judgment there. It is different from bannire; for, though both of them are citations* this is by the adverse party, and that Is by the judge. Du Cange

title: Mannopus
body: In old English law. Goods taken ln the hands of an apprehended thief. The same as “mainour," (q. vj

title: Mannus
body: A horse. CowelL

title: Manor
body: A house, dwelling, seat, or residence

title: Manqueller
body: In Saxon law. A murderer

title: Manse
body: Iu old Engllsh law. A habitation or dwelling, generally with land at1 tached. Spelman.

title: Manser
body: A bastard. Cowell

title: Mansion
body: A dwelling-house or place of residence, Including its appurtenant out-buildings. Thompson v. People, 3 Parker, Cr. R. (N, Y.) 214; Comm. v. Pennock, 3 Serg. & R. (Pa.> 199; Armour v. State, 3 Humph. (Tenn.) 385; Devoe v. Comm., 3 Metc. (Mass.) 325

title: Manslaughter
body: In criiulual law. The unlawful kllling of another without

title: Mansum
body: or MANSUM. In old English law\ A mansion or house. Spelman

title: Manstealing
body: . A word sometimes used synonymously with “kiduapplng,* (<?. v

title: Mansuetus
body: Lat. Tame; as though accustomed to come to the hand. 2 BL Comm. 391

title: Mantea
body: In old records. A long robe or mantle

title: Mantheoff
body: In Saxon law. A hora^ stealer

title: Manticulate
body: To pick pockets

title: Man-Traps
body: Engines to catch tree-passers, now unlawful unless set in a dwell-iug-house for defense between sunset and sunrise. 24 & 25 Vict. c. 100, 8 31

title: Manu Brevi
body: Lat. with a short hand. A term used iu the clvil luw, sigulfy

title: Manu Forti
body: Lat with strong haud. A term used in old writs of trespass. Manu forti et cum multitudine gentium, with strong hand and multitude of people. Reg. orig. 183

title: Manu Longa
body: Lat. with a long hand. A term used in the civil law, signifying iu-dlrectly or circuitously. Calvin

title: Manu Opera
body: Lat. Cattle or irnple-menta of husbandry; also stolen goods tak-en from a thief caught in the fact. Cowell

title: Manual
body: Performed by the baud; used or employed by the hand; held in the hand. Thus, a distress cannot be made of tools in the “manual occupation” of the debtor

title: Manualia Beneficia
body: The daily distributions of meat and drink to the can-ons and other members of cathedral church-es for their present subsistence. Cowell

title: Manualis Obedientia
body: Sworn obedience or submission upon oath. Cowell

title: Manucaptio
body: In old English prac-tice. A writ which lay for a man taken on suspicion of felony, and the like, who could not be admitted to bail by the sheriff, or others having power to let to mainprise. Fltzh. Nat. Brev. 249

title: Manucaptors
body: The same as main-pernors, (q. v

title: Manufactory
body: A building, the main or principal design or use of which is to be a place for produclng articles as products of labor; not merely a place where some-thtng may be made hy hand or machinery, but what in common understanding is known as a “factory.” IIalpin v. lnsurance Co., 129 N. Y. 73, 23 N. E. 989. 8 L. R. A. 79; Schott v. Harvey, 105 Pa. 227, 51 Am. Rep. 201; Franklin F. Ins. Co. v. Brock, 57 Pa. 82

title: Manufacturing Corporation
body: A corporation engaged In the production of some article, thing, or object, by skill or labor, out of raw material, or from matter which has already been subjected to artl-flclal forces, or to. which something has been added to change lts natural condition. Peo-ple v. Knlckerbocker Ice Co., 99 N. Y. 181, 1 N. E. 669. The term does not lnclude a mining corporation. Byers v. Franklin Coal Co., 106 Mass. 135.

title: Manjtmission
body: The act of liberating a slave from bondage and givlng him free-dom. ln a wider sense, releasing or deliv-ering one person from the power or control of another. See Fenwick v. Chapman, 9 Pet. 472, 9 L. Ed. 193; State v. Prnll, 1 N. J. Law, 4

title: Monung
body: or MONUNG. In old English law. The district wlthin the jurisdic-tlon of a reeve, apparently so called from hls power to exerclse therein one of hls chief functions, viz., to exact (amaniah) all fines

title: Manupes
body: In old English law. A foot of full and legal measure

title: Manupretium
body: Lat In Roman law. The hire or wages of labor; compensation for labor or servlces performed. See Mack-eld. Rom. Law, S 413. t

title: Manurable
body: In old English law. Capable of being had or held ln hand; capa-ble of manual occupation; capable of being cultivated; capable of being touched; tan-gible; corporeal. Hale, Anal. | 24

title: Manure
body: In old Engllsh law. To oc-cupy; to use or cultivate; to have ln man-ual occupation; to bestow manual labor upon. Cowell

title: Manus
body: Lat, A hand

title: Manuscript
body: A wrltlng; a paper written with the hand; a writing that has not been printed. Parton v. Prang, 18 Fed. Cas. 1275: Leon Loan & Abstract Co. v. Equalization Board, 86 Iowa, 127, 53 N. W. 94, 17 L. R. A. 199, 41 Am. St. Rep. 486

title: Manutenentia
body: The old wrlt of maintenance. Reg. orlg. 182

title: Manworth
body: In old English law. Tbe prlce or value of a man's life or head. Co-well

title: Many
body: This term denotes a multitude, not merely a number greater than that denoted by the word “few." . Louisville de N

title: Manzie
body: In old Scotch law. Mayhem; mutilation of the body of a person. Skene

title: Mara
body: In old records. A mere or moor; a lake, pool, or pond; a bog or

title: Marauder
body: “A marauder is defined ln the law to be ‘one wbo, while employed in the army as a soldier, commits larceny or robbery in the neighborhood of tbe camp, or while wandering away from the army? But ln the modern and metaphorical sense of the word, as now sometimes used in common speech, it seems to be applied to a class of persons who are not a part of any regular army, and are not answerable to any military discipline, but wbo are mere lawless banditti, engaged in plundering, robbery, murder, and all conceivable crimes.” Curry v. Collins, 37 Mo. 328

title: Marc-Banco
body: The name of a piece of money formerly coined at Hamburg. Its value was thirty-five cents

title: Marca
body: A mark; a coin of the value of 13s. 4d. Spelman

title: Marcatus
body: The rent of a mark by the year anciently reserved ln leases, etc

title: March
body: In Scotch law. A boundary line or border. Bell. The word is aiso used, ln composition; as march-dike, march-stone

title: Marchandises Avariees
body: In

title: Marchers
body: In old Engllsh law. No-blemen who lived on the marshes of wales or Scotland, and who, according to Camden, had thelr private laws, as if they had been petty kings; which were abollshed by the statute 27 Hen. VIIL c. 26. Called also “lords marchers.” Cowell

title: Marches
body: An old English term for boundaries or frontiers, particularly the boundaries and limits between England and wales, or between England and Scotland, or tbe borders of the dominions of the crown, or the boundaries of properties ln Scotland. Mozley & whltley

title: Marcheta
body: In old Sootob law. A

title: Marchioness
body: A dignity In a woman answerable to that of marquis in a man, conferred either by creation or by marriage with a marquiBi wharton

title: Mare
body: Lat The sea

title: Marescallus
body: Iu old English law. A marshal; a master of the stables; an officer of the exchequer; a military officer of high rank, having powers and duties similar to those of a constable. Du Cange. See Marshal

title: Maresghal
body: L. Fr. Marshal; a high officer of the royal household. Britt fol. lb

title: Marettum
body: Marshy ground overflow-ed by the sea or great rivers. Co. Litt 5

title: Margin
body: 1. The edge or border; the edge of a body of water where lt meets the land. As applied to a boundary line of land, the “margin” of a river, creek, or other water-course means the center of the stream. Ez parte Jennings, 6 Cow. (N. Y.) 527, 16 Am. Dec. 447; Varick v. Smith, 9 Paige (N. ¥.) 551. But ln the case of a lake, bay, or natural pond, tbe “margin” means the line where land and water meet. Fowler v. Vree-land, 44 N. J. Eq. 268, 14 Atl. 116; Lem-beck v. Andrews, 47 ohio St. 336, 24 N. E. 686, 8 L. R. A. 578

title: Marginal Note
body: In Scotch law. A note Inserted on the margin of a deed, embodying either some clause which was omlt-ted in transcribing or some change in the agreement of the parties. Bell

title: Marinarius
body: An ancient word which signified a mariner or seaman. In England

title: Marine
body: Naval; relating or pertaining to the sea; transacted at sea; doing duty or service ou the sea

title: Mariner
body: A seaman or sailor; one engaged in navigating vessels upon the sea

title: Marines
body: A body of Infantry soldiers, trained to serve on board of vessels of war when ln commission and to fight in naval engagements

title: Marischal
body: An officer In Scotland, who, with the lord high constable, possessed a supreme itinerant jurisdiction in all crimes

title: Mariscus
body: A marshy or fenny ground. Co. Litt. 5a

title: Maritagio Amisso Per Defaltam
body: An obsolete writ for the tenant in frank-marriage to recover lands, etc., of whlch he was deforced

title: Maritagium
body: The portion which is given with a daughter in marriage. Also the power which the lord or guardian ln chivalry had of disposing of ids infant ward in matrimony

title: Marital
body: Relating to, or connected with, the status of marriage; pertaining to a husband; incident to a husband

title: Maritima Anglls
body: In old English law. The emolument or revenue coming to the klng from the sea, which the sher-lffs anciently collected, but which was after-wards granted to the admiral. Spelman

title: Maritima Incrementa
body: In old

title: Maritime
body: Pertaiuing to the sea or ocean or the navigation thereof; or to com-merce conducted by navigation of the sea or (ln America) of the great lakes and rivers

title: Maritus
body: Lat. A husband; a married man. Calvin

title: Mark
body: 1. A character, usually in the form of a cross, made as a substitute for his signature by a person who cannot write, in executing a conveyance or other legal docu-ment. It is commonly made as follows: A third person writes the name of the marksman, leaving a blank space between the Christian name and surname; ln this space the latter traces the mark, or crossed lines, and above the mark is written “his,” (or “her,”) and below it, “mark.”

title: Markepenny
body: A penny anclently paid at the town of Maldon by those wbo had gutters laid or made out of thelr houses lnto the streets, wharton

title: Market
body: A publlc time and appolnted place of buying and selling; also, purchase and sale. Caldwell v. Alton, 33 111. 419, 75 Am. Dec. 282; Taggart v. Detroit, 71 Mich

title: Marksman
body: In practice and convey-ancing. one who makes his mark; a person who cannot write, and only makes his mark in executing instruments. Arch. N. Pr. 13; 2 Chit. 92

title: Marlbridge, Statute Of
body: An

title: Marque And Reprisal, Letters Of
body: These words, “marque” and “reprisal," are frequently used as synony-mous, but, taken in thelr strict etymological sense, the latter signifies a “taking in re-turn;” the former, the passing the frontiers (marches) in order to such taking. Letters of marque and reprisal are grantable, by the law of nations, whenever the subjects of one state are oppressed and injured by those of another, and justice is denied by that state to which the oppressor belongs; and the par-ty to whom these letters are granted may then seize the bodies or the goods of the sub-jects of the state to which the offender be-iongs, until satisfaction be made, wherever they happen to be found. Reprisals are to be grauted only In case of a clear and open denial of Justice. At the present day, ln consequence partly of treaties and partly of the practice of nations, the making of reprisals is confined to the seizure of commer* dal property on the high seas by public cruisers, or by private cruisers specially au-thorized thereto. Brown

title: Marquess
body: or MARQUESS. In English law. one of the second order of nobility; next in order to a duke

title: Marquisate
body: The seigniory of a mar-quis

title: Marriage
body: Marriage, as distingnished from the agreement to marry and from the act of becoming married, ls the civil status ct one man and one woman united In law for life, for the discharge to each other and the community of the duties legally lncum-bent on those whose association is founded on the distinction of sex. 1 Bish. Mar.

title: Married Woman
body: A woman who has a husband living and not divorced; a feme covert

title: Marshal
body: In old English law. The

title: Marshaling
body: Arranging, ranklng, or disposing in order; particularly, ln the case of a group or series of conflicting clalms or Interests, arranging them in such an order of sequence, or so directing the manner of thelr satisfaction, as shall secure justice to all persons concerned and the largest possible measure of satisfaction to each. See sub-titles infra

title: Marshalsea
body: In Engllsh law. A prison belonging to the king’s bench. It has now been consolldated with others, un-der the name of the “King’s Prison." —Marshalsea, conrt of. The court of the Marshalsea had jurisdiction in actions of debt or torts, the cause of wbich arose within the verge of the royal court. It was abolished by St. 12 & 13 Vict. c. 101. 4 Steph. Comm. 317, note d

title: Mart
body: A place of pnblic traffic or sale

title: Marte Suo Deourrere
body: Lat To

title: Martial Law
body: A system of law, obtaining only in time of actual war and grow

title: Martinmas
body: The feast of St. Martin of Tours, on the 11th of November; some-times corrupted Into “Martilmas” or “Mar-tlemas." It is the third of the four cross quarter-days of the year, wharton

title: Marus
body: In old Scotch law. A maire; an officer or executor of summons, otherwise called “praeco regis.” Skene

title: Masagium
body: L. Lat. A messuage

title: Massa
body: In the civil law. A mass; an unwrought substance, such as gold or silver, before lt is wrought into cups or other articles. Dig. 47, 2, 52, 14; Fleta, llb. 2, c. CO, M 17. 22

title: Mast
body: To fatten with mast, (acorns, etc.) 1 Leon. 186

title: Mast-Selling
body: In old English law. The practice of selling the goods of dead seamen at the mast. Held void. 7 Mod. 14L

title: Masura
body: In old records. A decayed house; a wall; the ruins of a bulldlng; a certaln quantlty of land, about four oxgangs

title: Mate
body: The officer second in command on a merchant vessel. Ely v. Peck, 7 Conn. 242; MiUaudon v. Martin, 6 Rob. (La.) 539

title: Matelotage
body: In French Iaw. The hire of a ship or boat

title: Mater-Famhjas
body: Lat. In tbe civil law. The mother or mistress of a family. A chaste woman, married or single. Calvin

title: Materia
body: Lat In the civU law

title: Material
body: Important; more or less necessary; having influence or effect; going to the merits; having to do with matter, as distinguished from form. An allegation ls sald to be material when it forms a substan-tive part of the case presented by the plead-ing. Evidence offered ln a cause, or a question propounded, is material when it is rele-vant and goes to the substantial matters in dispute, or has a legitimate and effective

title: Materiality
body: The property or char-acter of being material. See Material

title: Materials
body: The substance or matter of which anything ls made; matter furnished for the erection of a house, ship, or other structure; matter used or intended to he used in the construction of any mechanical product See Moyer v. Pennsylvania Slate Co., 71 Pa. 293

title: Materna Maternis
body: Lat A max-im of the French law, signifying that prop-erty of a decedent acquired by him through hls mother descends to the relations on the mother’s side

title: Maternal
body: That which belongs to, or comes from, the mother; as maternal au-thorlty, maternal relation, maternal estate, maternal llne

title: Maternity
body: The character, relation, state, or condition of a mother

title: Matertera
body: Lat In the civil law! A maternal aunt; a mother’s sister. Inst. 3, 6, Bract fol. 68b

title: Mathematical Evidence
body: See

title: Matricide
body: The murder of a mother ; or one who has slain his mother

title: Matricula
body: In the clvll and old English law. A register of the admission of of-flcers and persons eAtered lnto any body or

title: Matriculate
body: To enter as a stu-dent ln a. university

title: Matrimonial
body: of or pertaining to matrimony or the estate of marriage

title: Matrimonium
body: Lat. In Roman law. A legal marriage, contracted in strict ac--cordance with the forms of the older Roman law, i. e., either with the farreum, the coemptio, or by usus. This was allowed only to Roman citizens and to those neighboring peoples to whom the right of connubium had been conceded. The effect of such a marriage was to bring the wife Into the manus, ■or marital power, of the husband, and to ■create the patria potestas over the children

title: Matrimony
body: Marriage, (q. v.,) in the sense of tbe relatlon or status, not of the ceremony

title: Matrix
body: In the civil law. The proto-col or first draft of a legal instrument, from which all copies must be taken. See Downing v. Diaz, 80 Tex. 436, 16 S. W. 53

title: Matrix Ecclesia
body: Lat A mother church. This term was anciently applied to a cathedral, in relation to the other churches in the same see, or to a parochial church, in relation to the chapels or minor churches attached to it or depending on it. Blount

title: Matron
body: A married woman; an elderly woman. The female superintendent of an establishment or institution, such as a

title: Matrons, Jury Of
body: Such a jury ie impaneled to try if a woman condemned to death be with child

title: Matter
body: Facts; substance as distinguished from form; the merits of a case

title: Maturity
body: In mercantile law. The time when a blll of exchange or promissory note becomes due. Story, Bllls, | 329. Gil-bert v. Sprague, 88 111. App. 508; wheeless v. williams, 62 Miss. 371, 52 Am. Rep. 190

title: Maugre
body: L Fr. In spite of; against the will of. Litt f 672

title: Maundy Thursday
body: The day pre-ceding Good Friday, on which princes gave alms

title: Maxim
body: An established principle or proposition. A principle of law universally admitted, as being a correct statement of the iaw, or as agreeable to natural reason

title: Mayhem
body: In criminal law. The act of unlawfully and violently depriving another of the nse of such of his members as may render him less able, in fighting, either to defend himself or annoy his adversary

title: Mayhemavit
body: Maimed. This ls a term of art w’hich cannot be supplied In pleading by any other word, as mutilavit, truneavit, etc. 3 Thom. Co. Litt. 548; Com. v. Newell, 7 Mass. 247

title: Mayn
body: L. Fr. A hand; handwriting. Britt c. 28

title: Maynover
body: L. Fr. A work of the hand; a thing produced by manual labor. Yearb. M. 4 Edw. III. 38

title: Mayor
body: The executive head of a municipal corporation; the governor or chief

title: Mayorazgo
body: In Spanish law. The right to the enjoyment of certain aggregate property, left with the condition thereon imposed that they are to pass in thelr in-tegrity, perpetually, successively to the eldest son. Schm. Civil Law, 62

title: Mead
body: Ground somewhat watery, not plowed, but covered with grass and flowers. Enc. Lond

title: Meadow
body: A tract of low or level land produclng grass which is mown for hay. webster

title: Meal-Rent
body: A rent formerly pald ln meal

title: Mesne
body: N, or MESNE. A middle between two extremes, whether applled to persons, thlngs, or time

title: Meander
body: To meander means to follow a wlndlng or fiexuous course; and when lt is said, ln a description of land, “thence with the meander of the river,” it must mean a meandered line,—a line which follows the sinuosities of the river,—or, in other words, that the river is the boundary be-tween the points Indicated. Turner v. Park-er, 14 or. 341, 12 Pac. 495; Schurmeler v. St. Paul & P. R. Co., 10 Minn. 100 (Gil. 75), 88 Ara. Dec. 59

title: Means
body: 1. The instrumeut or agency through which an end or purpose is accora-plished

title: Mese
body: E, or MESE. Norman-French for a house. IAtt. t§ 74, 251

title: Meason-Due
body: (Corruption of maison de Dieu.) A house of God; a monastery; religious house or hospital. See 39 Eliz. c. 5

title: Measure
body: That by which extent or dimension is ascertained, either length, breadth, thickness, capacity, or amount, webster. The rule by which anything is adjusted or proportioned

title: Meter
body: RER, or METER. An officer ln the city of London, who measured woolen clothes, coals, etc

title: Measuring Money
body: In old English law. A duty whlch some persons exacted, by letters patent, for every piece of cloth made, besides alnage. Now abolished

title: Mechanic
body: A workman employed in shaping and uniting materials, such as wood, metal, etc., into some kind of structure, machine, or other object, requiring the use of tools. Story v. walker. 11 Lea (Tenn.) 517, 47 Am. Rep. 303; In re osborn (D. C.) 104 Fed. 781; Savannah & C. R. Co. v. Callahan, 49 Ga. 511; Berks County v. Bertolet, 13 Pa. 524

title: Mechanic'S Lien
body: A secies of lien created by statute in most of tbe states, which exists in favor of persons who have performed work or furnished material in and for the erection of a building. Their lien attaches to tbe land as well as the

title: Mechanical
body: Having relation to, or produced or accomplished by, the use of mechanism or machinery. Used chiefly in patent law. See compound terms infra

title: Mederia
body: In old records. A house or place where me£heglin, or mead, was made

title: Medfee
body: In old English law. A bribe or reward; a compensation given in ex-chauge, where the things exchanged were not of equal value. Cowell

title: Media Annata
body: In Spanish law. Half-yearly profits of land. McMullen v. Hodge, 5 Tex. 34, 79

title: Media Nox
body: In old English law. Mid-night. Ad medium noctem, at midnight. Fleta, lib. 5, c. 5, 8 31

title: Mediae Et Infirms Manus Hom-Ines
body: Men of a middle and base condition. Blount

title: Medianus Homo
body: A man of middle fortune

title: Mediate Descent
body: See Descent

title: Mediate Powers
body: Those incident to primary powers given by a principal to hls agent For example, the general authority given to collect, receive, and pay debts due by or to the principal is a primary power. In order to accomplish this, it is frequently required to settle accounts, adjust disputed claims, resist those which are unjust, and answer and defend suits. These subordi-nate powers are sometimes called “mediate powers.” Story, Ag. § 58

title: Mediate Testimony
body: Secondary evidence, (q. t

title: Mediation
body: Intervention; lnterposi-tlon; the act of a third person who inter-feres between two contending parties with a view to reconcile them or persuade them to adjust or settle their dispute. In inter-national law and diplomacy, the word de-notes the friendly interference of a state in the controversies of others, for the purpose, by its influence and by adjusting their diffi-cultles, of keeping the peace in the family of nations

title: Mediator
body: OR. one who interposes be-tween parties at variance for the purpose of reconciling them

title: Medical
body: Pertaining, relating, or be-longlng to the study nnd practice of medicine, or the science and art of the investigation, prevention, cure, and alleviation of disease

title: Medicine
body: "The practice of medicine is a pursuit very generally known and under-stood, and so also ls that of surgery. The former includes the application and use of medicines and drugs for the pnrpose of curing, mitigating, or alleviating bodily diseases, while the furfctlons of the latter are limited to manual operations usually performed by surgical instruments or appllances.” Smith v. Lane, 24 Hun (N. Y.) 633

title: Medicine-Chest
body: A box containing aa assortment of medicines, required by stat

title: Medico-Legal
body: Relating to the law concerning medical questions

title: Medio Acquietando
body: A judicial writ to distrain a lord for the acquitting of a mesne lord from a rent, which he had ac-knowledged ln court not to belong to him. Reg. Jur. 129

title: Medium Tempus
body: In old English law. Meantime; mesne profits. Cowell

title: Medletum
body: In old English law. A mixing together; a medley or mdle'e; an af-fray or sudden encounter. An offense sud-denly committed in an affray. The English word "medley” is preserved in the term “chance-medley.” An intermeddling, without violence, in any matter of business. Spelman

title: Medley
body: An affray; a sudden or cas-ual fighting; a hand to hand battle; a mdtee. See Chance-Medley; Ch aud-Medley

title: Medsceat
body: In old English law. A bribe; hush money

title: Medsypp
body: A harvest sapper or entertainment given to laborers at harvest-home. Cowell

title: Meeting
body: A coming together of per-sons; an assembly. Particularly, in law, an assembling of a number of persons for the purpose of discussing and acting upon some matter or matters in which they have a eoin-mon interest

title: Megbote
body: In Saxon law. A recompense for the murder of a relation

title: Maisnader
body: r MAISNADER. In old Eng-lish law. A family

title: Meindre Age
body: L. Fr. Minority; lesser age. Kelham

title: Meinie
body: MEINE, or MEINIE. In old

title: Mejorado
body: In Spanish law. Prefer-red; advanced, white, New Recop. L 3, tit 10, c. 1, | 4

title: Melancholia
body: In medical jurispru-dence. A kind of mental unsoundness char-acterized by extreme depression of spirits, ill-grounded fears, delusions, aud brooding over one particular subject or train of ideas webster. See Insanitt

title: Meldfeoh
body: In Saxon law. The recompense due and given to him who made dis-covery of any breach of penal laws committed by another person, called the “promot-er’s It. e., informer's] fee.” wharton

title: Melior
body: Lat Better; the better. Melior res, the better (best) thing or chattel. Bract fol. 60

title: Meliorations
body: In Scotch law. Improvements of an estate, other than mere re-pairs; betterments. 1 Bell, Comm. 73. occasionally used in English and American law ln the sense of valuable and lasting improve-ments or betterments. See Green v. Biddle, 8 wheat. 84, 5 L. Ed. 547

title: Melius Inquirendum
body: To be better inquired Into

title: Members
body: In English law. Places where a custom-house has been kept of old time, with officers or deputies in attendance; and they are lawful places of exportation or importation. 1 ChiL Com. Law, 726

title: Membrana
body: Lat In tbo oivil lav

title: Membrum
body: A slip or small piece of land

title: Memoire
body: In French law. A document ln the form of a petition, hy which ap-peals to the court of cassation are initiated

title: Memorandum
body: Lat. To he remembered ; he it remembered. A formal word with which the body of a record ln the court of king’s beuch ancientiy commenced. Townsh. Pl. 486 ; 2 Tldd, Pr. 719. The whole clause ls now, in practice, termed, from this iuitial word, the "memorandum,” and lts use is sup-posed to have originated from the circum-stance that proceedings “by bill" (in which alone lt has been employed) were formerly considered as the by-business of the court. Gilb. Com. Pl. 47, 48

title: Memorial
body: A document presented to a legislative body, or to the executive, by one or more individuals, containing a petition or a representation of facts

title: Memoriter
body: Lat. From memory; by or from recollection. Thus, memoriter proof of a written Instrument is such as is fur-nished by the recollection of a witness who had seen and known it

title: Memorization
body: Committing anything to memory. Used to describe the act of one who listens to a public representation of. a play or drama, and then, from his recollection of Its scenes, Incidents, or language, reproduces It, substantially or in part, in der-ogation of the rights of the author. See 5 Term R. 245; 14 Amer. Law Reg. (N. S.) 207

title: Memory
body: Mental capaclty; the mental power to review and recognize tbe successive states of consciousness ln thelr consecutive order. Thls word, as used ln Jurisprudence to denote one of the psychological elements necessary in the making of a valid will or contract or the commission of a crime, irn-plies the mental power to conduct a consecutive train of thought, or an orderly planning of affairs, by recalling correctly the past states of the mlnd and past events, and ar-rangiug them ln thelr due order of sequence and in their logical relations with the events and mental states of the present

title: Men Of Straw
body: Men who used in former days to ply about courts of law, so called from their manner of makiug known their occupation, (i. e., hy a straw iu one of their shoes,) recognized by the name of “straw-shoes.” An advocate or lawyer who wanted a convenient witness knew by these signs where to meet with one, and the col-loquy between the parties was brief. “Don’t you remember?” said the advocate; to which the ready answer was, “To be sure I do.” “Then come into court and swear it.” And straw-shoes went into court aud swore. Ath-ens abounded in straw-shoes. Quart. Rev. vol. 33, p. 344

title: Menace
body: A threat; the declaration or show of a disposition or determination to inflict an evil or injury upon another. Cum-ming v. State, 99 Ga. 662, 27 S. E. 177; Mor-rill v. Nightingale, 93 Cal. 452, 28 Pac. 1068, 27 Am. St Rep. 207

title: Menetum
body: In old Scotch law. A stock-horn; a horn made of wood, “with circles and glrds of the same.” Skene

title: Menial
body: A servant of the lowest or-der; more strictly, a domestic servant living under his master’s roof. Boniface v. Scott, 3 Serg. & R. (Pa.) 354

title: Mens
body: Lat. Mind; intention; meaning; understanding; wilt

title: Mensa
body: Lat. Patrimony or goods and necessary things for livelihood. Jacob. A table; the table of a money-changer. Dig. 2, 14, 47

title: Mensalia
body: Parsonages or spiritual liv-lngs united to the tables of religious houses, and called “mensal benefices” amongst the canonists. Cowell

title: Mensis
body: Lat. In the civil and old Eng-llsh law. A mouth. Mcnsis ret it us, the pro-hibited month; fence-month, (q. v

title: Mensor
body: In the civil law. A measurer of land; a surveyor. Dig. 11, 6; Id. 50, 6, 6; Cod. 12, 28

title: Mensularius
body: In the clvll law. A money-changer or dealer in money. Dig. 2, 14, 47, 1

title: Men Sura
body: In old English law. A measure

title: Mental
body: Relating to or existing in the mind; intellectual, emotional, or psychic, aa distinguished from bodily or physical

title: Mentiri
body: Lat. To lie; to assert a falsehood. Calvin.; 3 Bulst 260

title: Mentition
body: The act of lying; a false-hood

title: Menu, Laws Of
body: A collection or institute of the earliest laws of anclent India. The work Is of very remote antiquity

title: Mere
body: or MERE. A fenny place. CowelL

title: Mera Noctis
body: Midnight Cowell

title: Merannum
body: In old records. Timbers; wood for building

title: Mercable
body: Merchantable; to he sold or bought

title: Mercantant
body: A foreign trader

title: Mercantile
body: Pertaining to merchants or their buslness; havlng to do with trade

title: Mercat
body: A market. An old form of the latter word common in Scotch law, formed from the Latin “mercatum

title: Mercative
body: Belonging to trade

title: Mercatum
body: Lat. A market. A con-tract of sale. Supplies for an army, (com

title: Mercature
body: The practice of buying and selling

title: Merged Ary
body: A hirer; one that hires

title: Meroen-Lage
body: The law of the Mer-clans. one of the three prlncipal systems of laws which prevailed In England about the beginning of the eleventh century. It was observed ln many of the mldland counties, and those bordering on the principality of wales. 1 Bl. Comm. 65

title: Mercenarius
body: • A hireling or servant. Jacob

title: Merces
body: Lat. In the civll law. Re-ward of labor ln money or other thlngs. As dlstlngulshed from “pensto,” it means the rent of farms, (pradia rustiei.) Calvin

title: Merchandise
body: All commodities which merchants usually buy and sell, whether at wholesale or retail; wares and commodities such as are ordinarily the objects of trade and commerce. But • the term ls never understood as including real estate, and is

title: Merchant
body: A man who traffics or car-rles on trade with foreign countries, or who exports and Imports goods and sells them by wholesale, webster. Merchants of thls de-scriptlon are commonly known by the name of “shipping merchants.”

title: Merchantable
body: Fit for sale; vendible In market; of a quality such as will brlng the ordinary market price. Riggs v. Armstrong, 23 W. Va. 773; Pacific Coast Elevator Co. v. Bravinder, 14 wash. 315, 44 Pac. 544

title: Merchantman
body: A ship or vessel employed in foreign or domestic commerce or in the merchant service

title: Merchet
body: In fendal law. A fine or composition paid by inferior tenants to the lord for liberty to dispose of their daughters in marriage. Cowell. The same as marcheta (q. v

title: Merciament
body: An amerciament, pen-alty, or flne, (q. v

title: Mercimonia
body: In old writs, wares. Mercimonia et inerchandisas, wares and merchandises. Reg. Brev. Append. 10

title: Mercimoniatus Anglub
body: In old

title: Mercy
body: In praotioe. The arbitrament of the king or judge ln punishing offenses uot directly censured by law. Jacob. So, “to be in mercy” signifies to be amerced or fined for bringing or defending an unjust snit, or to be liable to punishment ln the discretion of the court

title: Mere
body: Sax. A marsh. Spelman

title: Mere
body: L. Fr. Mother. JBle, mere, flllc, grandmother, mother, daughter. Brltt c. 89. En ventre sa mere, in its mother's womb

title: Mere Motion
body: The free and volun-tary act of a party himself, done without the suggestion or influence of another person, is said to be done of his mere motion, ex mere motu, (q. v.) Brown

title: Mere Right
body: The mere right of prop-erty in land; the jus proprietatis, without either possession or even the right of pos-sesslon. 2 Bl. Comm. 197. The abstract right of property

title: Mere-Stone
body: In old English law. A stone for bounding or dlvlding lands. Yearb. P. 18 Hen. VI. 5

title: Merennium
body: In old records. Timber. Cowell

title: Meretricious
body: of tbe nature of un-Iawful sexual connection. The term is descriptive of the relation sustained oy persons wbo contract a marriage that ls vold by reason of legal incapacity. 1 Bl. Comm. 436

title: Merger
body: The fusion or absorption of one thing or rigbt Into another; generally spoken of a case where one of the subjects ls of less dignity or importance than the

title: M. V
body: orporations. A merger of corporations consist ln the uniting of two or more corporations by the transfer of property of all to one of them, which continues in existence, the others being swallowed up or merged therein. In regard to the survivor-ship of one of the constituent corporations, it differs from a “consolidation,” wherein all the consolidating companies surrender their separate existence and become parts of a new corporation. Adams v. Yadoo & M. V. R. Co., 77 Miss. 194, 24 South. 200, 60 L. R. A. 33; Vicksburg ft Y. C. Tel. Co. v. Citizens’ Tel. Co., 79 Miss. 341, 30 South. 725, 89 Am. St. Rep. 056

title: Meridies
body: In old Engllsh law. Noon. Fleta, lib. 5, c. 5, $ 31

title: Meritorious
body: Possessing or characterized by “merit” In the legal sense of the word. See Merits

title: Merits
body: In practice. Matter of sub-stance in law, as distinguished from matter of mere form; a substantial ground of de-fense in law. A defendant ls said "to swear to merits" or “to make affidavit of merits” when he makes affidavit that he has a good and sufficient or substantial defense to the action on the merits. 3 Chit Gen. Pr. 543, 544. “Merits,” in this application of it, has the technical sense of merits in law, and ls not confined to a strictly moral and conscien-tious defense. Id. 545; 1 Burrill, Pr. 214; Rahn v. Gunnison, 12 wis. 529; Bolton v. Don-avan, 9 N. D. 575, 84 N. W. 357; ordway v. Boston A M. R. Co., 69 N. H. 429, 45 AU. 243; Blakely v. Frazier, 11 S. C. 134; Rogers v. Rogers, 37 W. Va. 407, 16 S. E. 633; oatman v. Bond, 15 wis. 26

title: Mero Motu
body: See Ex Mebo Motu; Mere Motion

title: Merscum
body: A lake; also a marsh or fen-land

title: Mertlage
body: A church calendar or ru-brlc. Cowell

title: Merton, Statute Of
body: An old Eng-lish statute, relatlng to dower, legltimaey, wardships,' procedure, lnclosure of common, and usury. It was passed in 1235, (20 Hen

title: Merum
body: In old English law. Mere; naked or abstract. Mcrum jus, mere right. Bract fol. 31

title: Merx
body: Lat. Merchandise; movable ar tides that are bought and sold; articles of trade

title: Mesgreauntes
body: L. Fr. Apostates; unbelievers

title: Mese
body: A house and its appurtenance. Cowell

title: Mesne
body: Intermediate; intervening; the middle between two extremes, especially of rank or time

title: Mesnality
body: or MESNALITY. A man-or held under a superior lord. The estate of a mesne

title: Mess Brief
body: In Danish sea law. one of a ship’s papers; a certificate of admeas-urement granted at the home port of a vessel by the government or by some other com-petent authority. Jac. Sea Laws, 51

title: Message From The Crowu
body: In

title: Messarius
body: In old Euglish law. A chief servant in husbandry; a bailiff

title: Messuage
body: This term is. now synon-ymous with “dwelling-house,” but had once a more extended signification. It is fre-quently used ln deeds, in describing tbe premises. Marmet Co. v. Archibald. 37 W. Va. 778, 17 S. E. 300; Grimes v. wilson, 4 Blackf. (Ind.) 333; Derby v. Jones, 27 Me. 36Q; Davis v. Lowden, 56 N. J. Eq. 126, 38 AU. 648

title: Mestizo
body: A mongrel or person of mix-ed blood; sometimes used as equivalent to "octoroon,” that Is, the child of a white per-son and a quadroon, sometimes as denoting a person one of whose parents was a Spaniard and the other an American Indian

title: Meta
body: LaL A goal, bonnd, or turn-ing-point In old Engllsh law, the term was used to denote a bound or boundary line of

title: Metachronism
body: An error in computation of time

title: Metallum
body: Lat. In Roman law. Met* al; a mine. Labor in mines, as a punish-ment for crime. Dig. 40, 0, 24, 5; Calvin

title: Metatus
