body: wherefore he obstructed. In old English practice. A writ which lay for one who, having a liberty to pass through his neighbor’s ground, could

title: Quarentena Terra
body: A furlong. Co. Lltt 5b

title: Quarrel
body: This word is said to extend not only to real and personal actions, hut also to the causes of actions and suits; so that by the release of all “quarrels," not only actions pending, but also causes of action and suit, are released; and “quarrels,” “con-troversies,” and "debates” are in law con-sidered as having the same meaning. Co. Litt 8, 153; Termes de la Ley

title: Quarry
body: In mining law. An open excavation where the works* are visible at the surface; a place or pit where stone, slate, marble, etc., ls dug out or separated from a mass of rock. Baiub. Mines, 2. See Marvel v. Merritt, 116 U. S. 11, 6 Sup. Ct. 207, 29 L. Ed. 550; Murray v. Allred, 100 Tenn. 100, 43 S. W. 355, 39 L. R. A. 249, 66 Am. St Rep. 740; Ruttledge v. Eress, 17 Pa. Super. Ct. 495

title: Quart
body: A llquid measure, containing* one-fourth part of a gallon

title: Quarta Falcidia
body: In Roman law. That portion of a testator’s estate whlch, by the Falcidian law, was required to be left to the heir, amounting to at least one-fourth. See Mackeld. Rom. Law, S 771

title: Quarter
body: The fourth part of any-thlng. especlally of a year. Also a length of four inches. In England, a measure of corn, generally reckoned at eight bushels, though subject to local variations. See Hospltal St. Cross v. Lord Howard De walden, 6 Term, 343. In Amerlcan land law, a quarter sec-tion of land. See infra. And see McCart-ney v. Dennison, 101 Cal. 252, 35 Pac 766

title: Quarter Sessions
body: In Enclisb law. A criminal court held before two or more justlces of the peace, (one of whom must be of the quorum,) ln every county, once in every quarter of a year. 4 BL Comm. 271; 4 Steph. Comm. 335

title: Quartering
body: In English criminal law. The dlviding a criminal's body into quarters, after execution. A part of the punishment of high treason. 4 Bl. Comm. 93

title: Quartering Soldiers
body: Tbe act of

title: Quarterization
body: Quartering of crim-lnals

title: Quarterly Courts
body: A system of courts in Kentucky possessing a limited orig-lnal jurisdictlon ln clvll cases and appellate jurisdlction from justices of the peace

title: Quarterone
body: In the Spanish and French west Indies, a quadroon, that is, a person one of whose parents was white and the other a mulatto. See Daniel v. Guy, 19 Ark. 131.

title: Quarto Die Fost
body: Lat on the

title: Quash
body: To overthrow; to abate; to an-nul; to make void. Spelman; 3 Bl. Comm. 303; Crawford v. Stewart, 38 Pa. 34; Hoi-land v. webster, 43 Fla,. 85^29 South. 625; Bosley v. Bruner, 2 Cushm. (Miss.) 462

title: Quasi
body: Let As lf; as lt were; anal-ogous to. This term is used in legal phrase

title: Quater Cousin
body: See Cousin

title: Quatuor Pedibus Currit
body: Lat

title: Quatuorviri
body: In Roman law. Mag-tetrates who had the care and inspection of roads. Dig. 1, 2, 3, 30

title: Quay
body: A wharf for the loading or un-loading of goods carried ln ships. This word ls sometimes spelled “key

title: Que Est Le Mesme
body: L. Fr. whlch is the same. A term used in actions of trespass, etc. See Quje est Eadbx

title: Que Estate
body: L. Fr. whose estate. A term used in pleading, particularly ln claiming prescrlptlon, by whlch it is alleged that the plalntlff and those former owners whose estate he has have lmmemorlally exer--clsed the right claimed. Thls was called “prescribing in a que estate.’’

title: Quean
body: A worthless woman; a strum-pet. obsolete

title: Queen
body: A woman who possesses the soverelgnty and royal power in a country under a monarchical form of government The wife of a klng

title: Queen Anne'S Bounty
body: A fund created by a charter of Queen Anne, (con-firmed by St 2 Ann. c. 11,) for the augmenta-tion of poor livings, consisting of all the revenue of first fruits and tenths, which was vested ln trustees forever. 1 Bl. Comm. 286

title: Queen'S Prison
body: A Jail which used to be appropriated to the debtors and crimi-nals confined under process or by authority of the superior courts at westminster, the high court of admiralty, and also to per-sons imprisoned under the bankrupt law

title: Quem Reditum Reddit
body: L. Lat. An old writ which lay where a rent-charge or other rent which was not rent service was granted by fine holding of the grantor. If the tenant would not attorn, then the grantee might have had this writ old Nat. Brev. 126

title: Querela
body: Lat. An action preferred in any court of justice. The plaintiff was called “querens," or complainant and hls brief, complaint, or declaration was called “querela." Jacob

title: Querela Coram Rege A Con-Cilio Discutienda Et Termi-Nanda
body: A writ by which one is called to justify a complaint of a trespass made to the king himself, before the king and his council. Reg. orlg. 124

title: Querela Inofficiosi Testamenti
body: Lat. In the civil law. A species of action allowed to a child who had been unjustly disinherited, to set aside the will, founded on the presumption of law, in such

title: Querens
body: Lat. A plaintiff; complain-ant; Inquirer

title: Questa
body: In old records. A quest; an inquest, inquisition, or inquiry, upon the oaths of an Impaneled jury. Oowell

title: Question
body: A method of criminal ex-amination heretofore in use ln some of the countries of continental Europe, consisting of the application of torture to the supposed criminal, by means of the rack or other engines, in order to- extort from him, as the condition of his release from the torture, a confession of his own guilt or the names of his accomplices

title: Questmonger
body: r QUESTMONGER. In

title: Questores Parricidii
body: Lat. In Roman law. Certain officers, two in number, who were deputed by the eomitia, as a kind of commission, to search out and try all cases of parricide and murder. They were proba-bly appointed annually. Maine, Anc. Law, 370

title: Questus Est Nobis
body: Lat A writ of nuisance, whicb, by 15 Fdw. I., lay against him to whom a house or other thing that caused a nuisance descended or was alienated ; whereas, before that statute the action lay only against him who first levied or caus-ed the nuisance to the damage of his neigh-bor. Cowell

title: Quia
body: Lat. Because; whereas; inasmuch as

title: Quia Datum Est Nobis Intelll
body: GI. Because lt is given to us to understand. Formal words in old writs,

title: Quia Emftores
body: “Because the pur-chasere.” The title of the statute of westm. S. (18 Edw. L c. 1.) This statute took from the tenants of common lords the feudal lib-erty they claimed of disposing of part of their lands to hold of themselves, and, in-stead of it, gave them a general liberty to sell all or any part, to hold of the next superlor lord, which they could not have done before without consent The effect of this statute was twofold: (1) To facilitate the alienation of fee-simple estates; and (2) to put an end to the creation of any new manors, i. e., tenancies in fee-simple of a sub-ject Brown

title: Quia Erronice Emanavit
body: Because it issued erroneously, or through mis-take. A term in old English practice. Tel. 83

title: Quia Timet
body: Lat Because he fears or apprehends. In equity practice. The technical name of a blll filed by a party who seeks the ald of a court of equity, because he fears some future probable injury to his rights or interests. 2 Story, Eq. Jur. | 826

title: Quibble
body: A cavilling or verbal ohjec-tion. A sllght difllculty raised without ne-cesslty or propriety

title: Quick
body: Living; alive. “Quick chattels must be put in pound-overt that the owner may give them sustenance; dead need not" Finch, Law, b. 2, c. 6

title: Quick With Child
body: See QUICKEN-IN G

title: Quickening
body: ln medical jurispru-dence. The first motion of the foetus in the womb felt by the mother, occurring usually about the middle of the term of pregnancy. See Com. v. Parker, 9 Metc. (Mass.) 266, 43 Am. Dec. 396; State v. Cooper, 22 N. J. Law, 57, 51 Am. Dec. 248; Evans v. People, 49 N. Y. 89.

title: Quid Juris Clamat
body: In old Eng-llsh practice. A writ which lay for the grantee of a reversion or remainder, where the particular tenant would not attorn, for the purpose of compelling him. Termes de la Ley; Cowell

title: Quid Fro Quo
body: what for what; something for something. Used in law for the giving one valuable thing for another. It is nothing more than the mutual consideration which passes between the parties to a con-tract, and which renders it valid and binding. Cowell

title: Quidam
body: Lat. Somebody. This term ls used in the French law to designate a person whose name is not known

title: Quietare
body: L. Lat. To quit, acquit, discharge, or save harmless. A formal word in old deeds of donation and other convey-ances. CowelL

title: Quiete Clamantia
body: L. Lat. In old English law. Quitclaim. Bract, fol. 33b

title: Quiete Clamare
body: L. Lat To quit-claim or renounce ali pretensions of right and title. Bract fols. 1, 5

title: Quietus
body: In old English law. Quit; acquitted; discharged. A word used by the clerk of the pipe, and auditors ln the exchequer, in their acquittances or discharges given to accountants; usuaily concluding with an abinde recessit quietus, (hath gone quit thereof,) which was called a “quietus est" CowelL

title: Quelle
body: In French marine law. Keel; the keel of a vessel. Ord. Mar. liv. 3, tlt 6, art 8

title: Quinque Portus
body: In old English law. The Cinque Ports. Spelman

title: Quinquepartite
body: Consisting of five parts; divided lnto five parts

title: Quinzime
body: E, or QUINZIME. Fif-teenths; also the fifteenth day after a festi-val. 13 Edw. I. See Cowell

title: Quinterone
body: A term used in the West Indles to designate a person one of whose parents was a-whlte person and the other, a quadroon. Also spelled “quintroon.” See Daniel v. Guy, 19 Ark. 131

title: Quinto Exactus
body: In old practice. Called or exacted the fifth tlme. A return made by the sheriff, after a defendant had been proclaimed, required, or exacted in five county courts successively, and falled to appear, upon which he was outlawed by the coroners of the county. 3 BL Comm. 283

title: Quire Op Dover
body: In English law. A record ln the exchequer, showing the ten-ures for guarding and repairing Dover Cas-tle, and determining the services of the Ctnque Ports. 3 How. State Tr. 868

title: Quiritarian Ownership
body: In Ro

title: Quitrent
body: Certain establlshed rents of the freeholders and ancient copyholders of manors are denominated “qultrents,” because thereby the tenant goes quit and free of all other services. 3 Cruise, Dig. 314

title: Quittance
body: An abbreviation of “ac

title: Quo Animo
body: Lat. with what Intention or motive. Used sometimes as a substantive, in lieu of the single word “animus,” design or motive. “The quo animo ls the real subject of Inquiry.” 1 Kent, Comm. 77

title: Quo Jure
body: Lat. In old Engllsh prac* tice. A writ which lay for one that had land in which another claimed common, to compel the latter to show bg what title he claimed it CoweU; Fitzh. Nat. Brev. 128, F

title: Quo Minus
body: Lat. A writ upon which all proceedings in the court of exchequer were formerly grounded. In it the plaintiff suggests that he is the king’s debtor, and that the defendant has done him the Injury or damage complained of, quo minus sufflcienS existit, by which he is less able to pay the king’s debt This was originally requisite in order to give Jurisdiction to the court of ex-chequer; but now this suggestion is a mere form. 3 Bl. Comm. 46

title: Quoad Hoc
body: Lat. As to this; with respect to this; so far as this in particular ls concerned

title: Quoad Sacra
body: Lat As to sacred things; for religious purposes

title: Quod Billa Cassetur
body: That the bill be quashed. The common-law form of a judgment sustaining a plea in abatement, where the proceeding ls by bill, i. e., by a capias instead of by original writ

title: Quod Clerici Beneficiati De Cangellaria
body: A writ to exempt a clerk of the chahcery from the contribution to-wards the proctors of the clergy in parlia-ment, etc. Reg. orlg. 261

title: Quod Computet
body: That he account Judgment quod computet is a preliminary or interlocutory judgment given in the action of account-render (also in the case of cred-itors’ bllls against au executor or administrator,) directing that accouhts be taken be-fore a master or auditor

title: Quod Cum
body: In pleading. For that whereas. A form of introducing matter of inducement ln certain actions, as assumpsit and case

title: Quod Fuit Concessum
body: which was granted. A phrase in the reports, signify-ing that an argument or poiut made was conceded or acquiesced in by the court

title: Quod Jussu
body: LaL In the civil law. The name of an action given to one who had contracted with a son or slave, by order ot the father or master, to compel such father or master to stand to the agreement Halll-fax, Civil Law, b. 3, c. 2, no. 3; InsL 4, 7, 1

title: Quod Non Fuit Negatum
body: which was not denied. A phrase found ln the old reports, signifying that an argument or prop-osition was not denied or controverted by the court. Latch, 213

title: Quod Nota
body: which note; which mark. A reporter’s note in the old books, directing attention to a point or rule. Dyer, 23

title: Quod Partes Replacitent
body: That the parties do replead. The form of the judgment on award of a repleader. 2 Salk. 579

title: Quod Partitio Fiat
body: That parti-tion be made. The uame of the judgment in a suit for partition, directing that a partition be effected

title: Quod Permittat
body: That he permit In old English law. A writ which lay for the heir of him that was disseised of his common of pasture, against the heir of the disseisor. Cowell

title: Quod Permittat Prosternere
body: That he permit to abate. In old practice. A writ, in the, nature of a w’rlt of right, which lay to abate a nuisance. 3 Bl. Comm. 221. And see Conhocton Stone Road v. Buffalo, etc., R. Co., 51 N. Y. 579, 10 Am. Rep. 646; Powell v. Furniture.Co., 34 W. Va. 804, 12 S. E. 1085, 12 L. R. A. 53; Miller v. True-hart, 4 Leigh (Va.) 577.

title: Quod Prostravit
body: That he do abate. The name of a judgment upon an in-dictment for a nuisance, that the defendant abate such nuisance

title: Quod Recuperet
body: That he recover The ordinary form of judgments for the plaintiff in actions at law. 1 Archb. Pr. K. B. 225; 1 Burrlll, Pr. 246

title: Quod Si Contingat
body: That lf it happen. words by which a condition might formerly be created in a deed. Litt. | 330

title: Quod Vide
body: whlch see. A direction to the reader to look to another part of tbe hook, or to another book, there named, for further information

title: Quoniam Attachiamenta
body: (Since the attachments.) one of the oldest books ln the Scotch law. So called from the two first words of the volume. Jacob; whishaw

title: Quorum
body: when a’committee, board of directors, meeting of shareholders, legis) a-tlve or other body of persons cannot nct un-less a certaln number nt least of them are present, that number is called a “quorum.” Sweet. In the absence of any law or rule fixing the quorum, lt consists of a majority of those entitled to act. See Ex parte willcocks, 7 Cow. (N. Y.) 409, 17 Am. Dee. 525; State v. wilkesville Tp., 20 ohio St. 293; Heiskell v. Baltimore, 65 Md. 125, 4 Atl. 116, 57 Am. Rep. 308; Snider v. Rlne hart, 18 Colo. 18, 31 Pac. 716

title: Quot
body: In old Scotch law. A twentieth part of the movable estate of a person dying, which was due to the bishop of the dio-cese within which the person resided. Bell

title: Quota
body: A proportional part or share, the proportional part of a demand or liabll-ity, falling upon each of those who are col lectlvely responsible for the whole

title: Quotation
body: 1. The production to a conrt or judge of the exact language of a statute, precedent, or other authority, in support of an argument or proposition ad-vanced

title: Quotient Verdict
body: A money ver dict the amount of which is fixed hy the following process: Each Juror writes down the sum he wishes to award by the verdict; these amounts are all added together, and the total is divided by twelve, (the number of the jurors,) and the quotient stands as the verdict of the jury by their agreement. See Hamilton v. Owego waterworks. 22 App Dlv. 573, 48 N. Y. Supp. 10G; Moses v. Railroad Co., 3 Misc. Rep. 322, 23 N. Y. Supp. 23

title: Quotuplex
body: Of how many kinds; how many fold. A term of frequent occurrence ln Sheppard’s Touchstone

title: Quousque
body: Lat. How long; how far; until. In old conveyances it is used as a word of limitation. 10 Coke, 41

title: Quovts Modo
body: Lat In whatever manner

title: Race
body: A tribe, people, or nation, be-longing or supposed to belong to the same stock or llneage. “Race, color, or.previous conditlon of servitude.” Const U. S., Am. XV

title: Race-Way
body: An artificial canal dug in the earth; a channel cut In the ground, wilder v. De Cou, 26 Mlnn. 17, 1 N. W. 48. The channel for the current that drives a water-wheel, webster

title: Rachat
body: In French law. The right of repurchase which, in English and American law, the vendor may reserve-to hlmself. It is also called “rdmfird” Brown

title: Raghater
body: L. Fr. To redeem; to repurchase, (or bny back.) Kelham

title: Rachetum
body: In Scotch law. Ransom; correspondlng to Saxon “weregild,” a pecun-lary composition for an offense. Skene; Jacoh

title: Rachimburgii
body: In the legal polity of the Sallans and Rlpuarlans and other Germanic peoples, this name was given to the judges or assessors who sat with the count in his mallum, (court,) and were generally associated with him in other matters. Spelman

title: Rack
body: An engine of tortnre anciently nsed in tbe inquisitorial method of examin-ing persons charged with crime, the office of whlch was to break the limbs or dislocate the joints

title: Rack-Rent
body: A rent of the full value of the tenement, or near It. 2 Bl. Comm. 43

title: Rack-Vintage
body: wines drawn from the lees. Cowell

title: Radicals
body: A political party. The term arose tn England, in 1S18, when the popular leaders, Hunt Cartwright, and oth-ers, sought to obtain a radical reform in the

title: Radoub
body: In French law. A term in-cluding the repairs made to a ship, and a fresh supply of furnlture and victuals, muni-tions, and other provlslons required for the voyage. 3 Pard. Drolt Commer. I 602

title: Raffle
body: A kind of lottery ln which several persons pay, ln shares, the value of something put up as a stake, and then deter-mine by chance (as by casting dice) which one of them shall become the sole possessor of lt. webster; Prendergast v. State, 41 Tex. Cr. R. 358, 57 S. W. 850; State v. Ken-non, 21 Mo. 264; People v. American Art Union, 7 N. Y. 241

title: Rageman
body: A statute, so called, of justices assigned by Edward I. and his coun-cll, to go a circuit through all England, and to hear and determine all complaints of in-juries done within five years next before Michaelmas, in the fourth year of hls reign. Spelman

title: Railroad
body: A road or way on which iron or steel rails are laid for wheels to run on, for the conveyance of heavy loads in cars or carriages propelled by steam or other motive power. The word “railway” is of exactly equivalent import

title: Railway
body: In law, this term is of ex actly equivalent import to “railroad.” See

title: Raise
body: To create. A use may be rais-ed; i. e., a use may be created. Also to in-fer; to create or bring to light by construction or lnterpretatlon

title: Rangho
body: Sp. A small collection of men or thelr dwellings; a hamlet. As used, however, in Mexico and in the Spanish law formerly prevailing in California, the term signifies a rauch or large tract of land suit-able for grazing purposes where horses or cattle are raised, and is distinguished from hacienda, a cultivated farm or plantation

title: Range
body: In the government survey of the United States, this term is used to de

title: Ranger
body: In forest law. A sworn of fleer of the forest, whose office chiefly con-sists in three points: To walk daily through his charge to see, hear, and Inquire as weil of trespasses as trespassers iu his bailiwick: to drive the beasts of the forest, both of venery and chace, out of the deafforested ln-to the forested lands; and to present all trespassers of the forest at the next courts holden for the forest. Cowell

title: Ransom
body: In international Uw. The

title: Rape
body: In oriminal law. The unlawful carnal knowledge of a woman by a man forcibly and against her will. Code Ga. I 4349; Gore v. State, 119 Ga. 418, 46 S. E. 671, 100 Am. St. Rep. 182; Maxey v. State, 66 Ark. 523, 52 S. W. 2; Croghan v. State, 22 W1&. 444; State v. Montgomery, 63 Mo. 298; People v. Crego, 70 Mich. 319, 38 N

title: Rapine
body: In criminal law. Plunder; pillage; robbery. In the civll law, raplna is defined as the forcible and violent taklng of another man's movable property wlth the criminal intent to appropriate it to the robber's own use. A prsetorian action lay for this offense, ln which quadruple damages were recoverable. Gaius, lih. 3, 8 209; Inst. 4, 2; Mackeld. Rom. Law, $ 481; Heinecc. Elem. $ 1071

title: Rapport A Succession
body: In French law and ln Loulslana. A proceeding similar to hotchpot; the restoration to the succession of such property as the heir may have received by way of advancement from the decedent, ln order that an even division may be made among all the co-helrs. Clv. Code La. art. 1305

title: Raptor
body: In old English law. A rav-isher. Fleta, llb. 2, c. 52, § 12

title: Raptu Hjeredis
body: In old Euglish law. A writ for taking away an heir holding in socage, of which there were two sorts: one when the heir was married; tbe other when he was not. Reg. orlg. 163

title: Rapuit
body: Lat In old English law. Ravished. A technical word in old indictments. 2 East, 30

title: Rasure
body: The act of scraping, scratch-lng, or shaving the surface of a written in-strument, for the purpose of removlng cer-tain letters or words from it It ls to be dlstlngulshed from “obliteration,” as thelat-ter word properly denotes the crossing out of a word or letter by drawlng a llne through it with ink. But the two expressions are often used interchangeably. See Penny v. Corwithe, 18 Johns. (N. Y.) 499

title: Rasus
body: In old English law. A rase; a measure of onions, containing twenty flones, and each flonls twenty-five heads. Fleta, llb. 2, C. 12, | 12

title: Ratam Rem Habere
body: Lat. In the civll law. To hold a thlng ratified; to ratify or confirm it Dig. 46, 8, 12, 1

title: Rate
body: Proportional or relative value, measure, or degree; the proportion or stand-ard by which quantity or value ls adjusted. Thus, the rate ot interest ls the proportion or ratio between the principal and interest. So the buildings in a town are rated tor Insurance purposes; i. e., classified and individually estimated with reference to their insurable quallties. In thls sense also we speak of articles as being ln “first-rate” or “second-rate” condltion

title: Ratification
body: The confirmation of a previous act done either by the party hlm-self or hy another; conflrmatlon of a void-able act See Story, Ag. H 250» 251; 2 Kent

title: Ratihabitio
body: Lnt. Confirmation, agreement, consent, approbation of a contract. Saltmarsh v. Cnndia, 51 N. H. 76

title: Ratio
body: Rate; proportion; degree. Reason, or understanding. Also a cause, or giving judgment therein

title: Rationabile Estoverium
body: A

title: Rationabili Parte Bonorum
body: A wrlt that lay for tlie wife against the executors of her husband, to have the third part of his goods after hls just debts and funeral expenses had been paid. Fitzh. Nat. Brev. 122.

title: Rationalibus Divisis
body: An abol-ished writ which lay where two lords, ln divers towns, had selgnlorles adjoining, for him who found hls waste by llttle and little to have been encroached upon, agalnst the other, who had encroached, thereby to rectl-fy their bounds. Cowell

title: Ratione Impotentue
body: Lat. on acconnt of inability. A ground of qualified property in some animals ferae natura; as in the young ones, while they are unable to fly or run. 2 Bl. Comm. 3, 4

title: Ratione Materub
body: Lat By reason

title: Ratione Personje
body: Lat By rea

title: Ratione Privilegii
body: Lat Thls

title: Ratione Soli
body: Lat. on account of the soll; wlth reference to the soll. Said to be the ground of ownershlp ln bees. 2 Bl. Comm. 393

title: Ratione Tenures
body: L. Lat. By rea-son of tenure; as a consequence of tenure. 3 Bl. Comm. 230

title: Rationes
body: In old law. The pleadlngs in a suit. Rationes exereere, or ad rationes stare, to plead

title: Ravished
body: In criminal practlce. A material word in indictments for rape, whart. Crim. Law, $ 401

title: Ravishment
body: In criminal law. An unlawful taking of a woman, or of an heir ln ward. Rape

title: Raze
body: To erase. 3 How. State Tr. 156

title: Razon
body: In Spanish law. Cause, (causa.) Las Partidas, pt. 4, tit. 4, 1. 2

title: Re. Fa. Lo
body: The abbreviation of “re-cordari facias loquelam” (q. v

title: Readers
body: In the middle temple, those persons were so called who were appointed to deliver lectures or “readings” at certain periods during term. The clerks ln holy or-ders who read prayers and assist ln the performance of divine service in the chapels of the several inns of court are also so termed. Brown

title: Reading-In
body: In English ecclesiastical law. The title of a person admitted to a rectory or other benefice will be divested unless within two months after actual posses-slon he publicly read in the church of the benefice, upon some Lord's day, and at the appointed times, the morning and evening service, according to the book of common prayer; and afterwards, publicly before the congregation, declare his assent to such book; and also publicly read the thirty-nine artlcles in the same church, ln the time of common prayer, with declaration of his as-sent thereto; and moreover, within three months after his ndmlssion, read upon some Lord's day in the same church, in the presence of the congregation, in the time of divine service, a declaration by him subscrlb-ed before the ordinary, of conformity to the Liturgy, together with the certificate of the ordinary of its having been so subscribed. 2 Steph. Comm. (7th Ed.) 687; wharton

title: Real
body: In common law. Relating to land, as distinguished from personal property. This term is applied to lands, tenements, and hereditaments

title: Real Law
body: At oommon law. The

title: Reality
body: In foreign law. That qual-lty of laws whlch concerns property or things, (quae ad rem spectant.) Story, Confl. Laws, § 16

title: Realize
body: To convert any kind of prop-erty into money; but especially to receive the returns from an investment. See Bitti-ner v. Gomprecht, 28 Misc. Rep. 218, 58 N

title: Realm
body: A kingdom; a country. 1 Taunt. 270; 4 Camp. 289

title: Realty
body: A brief term for real proper-ty; also for anything which partakes of the nature of real property

title: Reappraiser
body: A person who, in cer-tain cases, is appointed to make a revalua tlon or second appraisement of imported goods at the custom-house

title: Reason
body: A faculty of the mind by which it distinguishes truth from falsehood, good from evil, and which enables the pos-sessor to deduce inferences from facts or from propositions, webster. Also an inducement, motive, or ground for action, as in the phrase “reasons for an appeal.” See Nelson v. Clongland, 15 wis. 393; Miller v. Miller, 8 Johns. (N. Y.) 77

title: Reasonable
body: Agreeable to reason; just; proper, ordinary or usual

title: Reassurance
body: This is where an insurer procures the whole or a part of the sum which he has insured (i. e., contracted to pay in case of loss, death, etc.) to be insured again to him by another person. Sweet

title: Reattachment
body: A second attach-ment of him who was formerly attached, and dismissed the court without day, by the not coinlng of the justlces, or some such casualty. Reg. orlg. 35

title: Rebate
body: Discount; reducing the Interest of money ln consideration of prompt payment. Also a deduction from a stlpulat-ed premium on a policy of insurance, in pursuance of an antecedent contract. Also a deduction or drawback from a stipulated payment, charge, or rate, (as, a rate for the transportation of freight by a railroad,) not taken ont ln advance of payment, but hand-ed back to the payer after he has paid tbe fnll stipulated sum

title: Rebel
body: The name of rebels is given to all subjects who unjustly take up arms against the ruler of the society, [or the law-ful and constitutional government,] whether their view be to deprive him of the supreme authority or to resist his lawful commands ln some particular instance, nnd to impose conditions on him. Vatt. Law Nat bk. 3, t 288

title: Rebellion
body: Deliberate, organized re-sistance, by force and arms, to the laws or operations of the government, committed by a subject See Hubbard v. Hamden Exp. Co., 10 R. I. 247; State v. McDonald, 4 Port. (Ala.) 455; Crashley v. Press Pub. Co., 74 App. Dlv. 118, 77 N. Y. Supp. 711

title: Rebellious Assembly
body: In Eng-lish law. A gathering of twelve persons or more, intending, going about, or practicing unlawfully and of their own authority to change any laws of the realm; or to destroy the inclosure of any park or ground inclosed, hanks of fish-ponds, pools, conduits, eic., to the intent the same shall remain void; or that they shall have way in any of the said grounds; or to destroy the deer in any park, fish ln ponds, coneys in any warren, dove-houses, etc.; or to burn sacks of corn; or to abate rents or prices of victuals, etc. See Cowell

title: Rebouter
body: To repel or bar. The ac-tion of the heir by the warranty of his ancestor is called “to rebut or repel.” 2 Co. Litt. 247

title: Rebus Sic Stantibus
body: Lat At

title: Rebut
body: In pleading and evidence. To rehut ls to defeat or take away the effect of something. Thus, when a plaintiff in an action produces evidence which raises a pre-sumption of the defendant’s liability, and the defendant adduces evidence which shows that the presumption is ill-founded, he is said to “rebut it” Sweet

title: Rebuttable Presumption
body: In

title: Rebuttal
body: The introduction of rebut-ting evidence; the stage of a trial at which such evidence may be introduced; also the rebutting evidence ltself. Lux v. Haggin, 60 Cal. 255, 10 Pac. 674

title: Rebutter
body: In pleadlng. A defend* ant’s answer of fact to a plalntlfTs surre-jolnder; the third pleadlng ln the series op

title: Rebutting Evidence
body: See Evi-DINCK

title: Recall
body: In International law. To summon a diplomatic minister back , to his home court, at the same time depriving him of his office and functions

title: Recall A Judgment
body: To revoke, cancel, vacate, or reverse a judgment for matters of fact; when it is annulled by rea-son of errors of law, it is said to be “re-versed.”

title: Recaption
body: A retaking, or taking back. A species of remedy by the mere act of the party injured, (otherwise termed “re-prisal,”) which happens wben any one has deprived another of his property in goods or chattels personal, or wrongfully detains one’s wife, child, or servant. In this case, the owner of the goods, and the husband, parent, or master may lawfully clalm and retake them, wherever he happens to find them, so it be not In a riotous manner, or attended with a breach of tbe peace. 3 Inst 134; 3 Rl. Comm. 4; 3 Stepb. Comm. 358; Prigg v. Pennsylvania, 16 Pet. 612, 10 L. Ed. 1060

title: Recapture
body: The taking from an en-emy, by a friendly force, a vessel previously taken for prize by such enemy

title: Receipt
body: PT. A receipt is the written ac-knowledgment of the receipt of money, or a thing of value, without containing any affirmative obligation upon either party to It; a mere admission of a fact, ln writing. Krutz v. Craig, 53 Ind. 574

title: Receuptor
body: OR. A name given in some of the states to a person who receives from the sheriff goods which the latter has seized under process of garnishment, on giving to the sheriff a bond conditioned to have the property forthcoming when demanded or when execution issues. Story, Bailm. § 124

title: Receiver
body: VER. A receiver is an indifler-ent person between the parties appointed by the court to collect and receive the rents, issues, and profits of land, or the produce ot persoual estate, or other things which it does not Beem reasonable to the court that either party should do; or where a party is lncom-petent to do so, as iu the case of an infant The remedy of the appointment of a receiver is one of the very oldest ln the court of chan-cery, and ls founded on the inadequacy of the remedy to be obtained in the court of ordinary jurisdiction. Bisp. Eq. | 576. See Hay ▼. McDaniel, 26 Ind. App. 683, 60 N. B. 729; Hale v. Hardon, 95 Fed. 773, 37 O. O

title: Receiving Stolen Goods
body: The short name usually given to the offense of

title: Reoens Insecutio
body: In old Engllsh law. Fresh suit; fresh pursuit Pursuit of a thief immediately after the discovery of the robbery. 1 Bl. Comm. 297

title: Receptus
body: Lat In the civil law. The name sometimes given to an arbitrator, because he had been received or chosen to set-tie the differences between the parties. Dig. 4, 8; Cod. 2, 56

title: Recess
body: In the practice of the courts, a recess is a short interval or period of time during which the court suspends business, but without adjourning. See In re Gannon, 69 Cal. 541, 11 Pac. 240. In legislative prac* tice, a recess is the ‘interval, occurring in consequence of an adjournment, between the sessions of the same continuous legislative body; not tbe interval between the final ad-journment of one body and the convening of another at the next regular session. See Tip-ton v. Parker, 71 Ark. 193, 74 S. W. 298. ■

title: Recession
body: The act of ceding back; the restoration of the title and dominion of a territory, by the government which now holds it, to the government from which it was obtained by cession or otherwise. 2 white, Recop. 516

title: Recessus Maris
body: Lat. In old English law. A going back; reliction or retreat of the sea

title: Recht
body: Ger. Right; justice; equity; the whole body of law; unwritten law; law; also a right

title: Reciprocal Contract
body: A con-tract, the partles to whlch enter lnto mutual engagements. A mutual or bilateral con-tract

title: Reciprogal Wills
body: wills made by two or more persons ln which they make reciprocal testamentary provlslons in favor of each other, whether they unite in one will or each executes a separate one. In re Caw-ley’s Estate, 136 Pa. 628, 20 Atl. 567, 10 L

title: Regiprocity
body: Mutuality. The term is used in international law to denote the relatlon existing between two states when each of them gives the subjects of the other cer-tain privileges, on condition that its own subjects shall enjoy similar privileges at the hands of the latter state. Sweet

title: Recital
body: The formal statement or set-ting forth of some matter of fact, ln any deed or wrltlng, ln order to explain the reasons upon which the transaction is founded. The recitals are situated ln the premises of a deed, that is, in that part of a deed be-tween the date and the habendum, and they usually commence with the formal word “whereas." Brown

title: Recite
body: To state in a written Instrn ment facts connected with Its inception, or reasons for Its being made. Also to quote or set forth the words or the contents of some other instrument or document; as, to “re-cite” a statute. See Hart v. Baltimore & 0. R. Co., 6 W. Va. 348

title: Recklessness
body: Rashness; heedless-ness; wanton conduct. The state of mind accompanying an act. which either pays no regard to its probably or possibly injurious

title: Reclaim
body: To claim or demand back; to ask for tbe return or restoration of a thing; to Insist upon one’s right to recover that which was one’s own, but was parted with conditionally or mistakenly; as, to reclaim goods which were obtained from one nnder false pretenses

title: Reclaimed Animals
body: Those that are made tame by art, lndustry, or education, whereby a qualified property may be acquired ln them

title: Reclaiming Bill
body: In Scotch law. A petitlon of appeal or review of a judgment of the lord ordlnary or other Inferior court. Bell

title: Reclamation District
body: A subdivision of a state created by legislative authority, for the purpose of reclaiming swamp, marshy, or desert lands within Its boundaries and rendering them fit for habitation or cultivation, generally with funds raised by local taxation or the issue of bonds, and sometimes with authority to make rules or ordinances for the regulation of the work in hand

title: Reclusion
body: In French law and in Louisiana. Incarceration as a punlshment for crime; a temporary, afflictlve, and infamous punishment, consisting in belng con

title: Recognition
body: Ratlficatlon; confirmation; an acknowledgment that something done hy another person in one’s name had one’s authority

title: Recognitions Adnullanda Per Vim Et Duritiem Facta
body: A writ to the justices of the common bench for send-ing a record touching a recognizance, which the recognizor suggests was acknowledged by force and duress; that lf lt so appear the recognizance may be annulled. Reg. orlg. 183

title: Recognitors
body: In Engllsh law. The name by which the jurors impaneled on an assize are known. See Rbcoonitior

title: Recognizance
body: An obllgation of record, entered into before some court of record, or magistrate duly authorized, with condition to do some particular act; as to appear at the assizes, or crlminal court, to keep the peace, to pay a debt, or the llke. It resembles a bond, but differs from lt ln being an acknowledgment of a former debt npon record. 2 Rl. Comm. 341. See U. S. v. Insley (C. C.) 49 Fed. 778; State v. walker, 56 N

title: Recognize
body: To try; to examine ln order to determlne the truth of a matter. Also to enter into a recognizance

title: Recognizee
body: He to whom one ls bound ln a recognizance

title: Recognizor
body: He who enters into a recognizance

title: Recolement
body: In French law. This ls the process by which a witness, who has

title: Recommendation
body: In feudal law. A method of converting allodial land into feudal property. The owner of the allod surrendered it to the king or a lord, doing homage, and received it back as a benefice or feud, to hold to hlmself aud such of hls heirs as he had previously nominated to the superior

title: Recommendatory
body: Precatory, advisory, or directory. Recommendatory words ln a will are such as do not express the testator's command in a peremptory form, but advise, counsel, or suggest that a certain course be pursued or disposition made

title: Recompensation
body: In Scotland, where a party sues for a debt, and the de-fendant pleads compensation, i. e., set-ofT, the plaintiff may allege a compensation on his part; and this is called a “recompensation.” BelL

title: Recompense
body: A reward for services; remuneration for goods or other property

title: Recompense Or Recovery In Value
body: That part of the judgment in a "common recovery” by which the tenant ls declared entltled to recover lands of equal value with those which were warranted to him and lost by the default of the vouchee. See 2 Bl. Comm. 358-359

title: Reconciliation
body: The renewal of amicable relations between two persons who had been at enmity or variance; usually implying forgiveness of injuries on one or both sides. It is sometimes used iu the law of divorce as a term synonymous or analogous to "condonation

title: Reconduction
body: In the civil law. A repewing of a former lease; relocation. Dig. 19, 2, 13, 11; Code Nap. arts. 1737-1740

title: Reconstruction
body: The name commonly given to the process of reorganizing

title: Reconvenire
body: Lat In the canon and dvil law. To make a cross-demand up-on the actor, or plaintiff. 4 Reeve, Eng. Law, 14, and note, (r

title: Reconvention
body: In the civil law. An action by a defendant against a plaintiff in a former action; a cross-bill or litigation

title: Regonversion
body: That Imaginary pro-cess by which a prior constructive conversion is annulled, and the converted property restored in contemplation of law to its original state

title: Recopilacion De Indian
body: A collection of Spanish colonial law, promulgated A. D. 1680. See Schm. Clvil Law, Introd. 94

title: Recordare
body: In Amerlcan practlce. A writ to bring up judgments of justices of the peace. Holcombe v. Loudermilk, 48 N

title: Recordari Facias Loquelam
body: In English practice. A writ by which a suit or plaint in replevin may be removed from a county court to one of the courts of west-minster Hall. 3 Bl. Comm. 149; 3 Steph. PI 522, 666. So termed from the emphatic words of the old writ, by which the sheriff was commanded to cause the plaint to be recorded, and to have the record before the «ur perior court. Reg. Orig. 5b.

title: Recordatur
body: In old English practice. An entry made upon a record, in order te

title: Recorder Of London
body: one of the

title: Recording Acts
body: Statutes enacted in the several states relative to the oflicial recording of deeds, mortgages, bills of sale, chattel mortgages, etc., aud the effect of such records as notice to creditors, purchasers, incumbrancers, aud others Interested

title: Recoupe
body: or RECOUPE. To deduct, defalk, discount, set off, or keep back; to withhold part of a demand

title: Recoupment
body: In practice. Defalca-tion or discount from a demand. A keepiug back something which is due, because there is an equitable reuson to withhold it. Tomlins

title: Recourse
body: The phrase "without recourse” is used ln the form of muking a qual-ified or restrictive indorsement of n bill or note. By these words the indorser signifies that, while he transfers his proiierty In the Instrument, he does not assume the responsibility of an indorser. See Lyons v. Fitzpatrick, 52 La. Ann. 697, 27 South. 111

title: Recousse
body: Fr. In French law. Recapture. Emerig. TraitG des Assur. c. 12, 8 23

title: Recoveree
body: In old conveyancing. The party who suffered a common recovery

title: Recoverer
body: The demandant in a common recovery, after judgment has been given in his favor

title: Recovery
body: In its most extensive sense, a recovery is the restoration or vindication of a right existing in a person, by the formal judgment or decree of a competent court, at his instance and suit, or the obtaining, by such judgment, of some right or property which has been taken or withheld from him. This is also called a "true'’ recovery, to dis

title: Recreant
body: Coward or craven. The word pronounced by a combatant in the trial by battel, when he acknowledged himself beaten. 3 Bl. Comm. 340

title: Recrimination
body: A charge made by an accused person against the accuser; in particular a counter-charge of adultery or cruelty made by one charged with the same offense in a suit for divorce, against the per-son who has charged him or her. wharton

title: Recruit
body: A newly-enlisted soldier

title: Recta Prisa Regis
body: In old English law. The kiug’s right to prisage, or taking of one butt or pipe of wine before and an-other behind the mast, as a custom for every ship laden with wines. Cowell

title: Rectification
body: Reotifloation of instrument. In English law. To rectify is to correct or define something which ls erroneous or doubtful. Thus, where the par-ties to an agreement have determined to em-body Its terms in the appropriate and con-elusive form, but the instrument meant to efTect this purpose (e. g., a conveyance, set-tlement, etc.) is, by mutual mistake, so framed as not to express the real intention of the parties, an action may be brought in the chancery division of the high court to have it rectified. Sweet

title: Rectifier
body: As used ln the United States Internal revenue laws, this term is not confined to a person who runs spirits through charcoal, but ls applied to any one who rectifies or purifies spirits In any manner what-ever, or wbo makes a mixture of spirits with anything else, and sells it under any name. Quantity of Distilled Spirits, 3 Ben. 73, Fed. Cos. No. 11,494

title: Rectitudo
body: Lat Right or justice; legal dues; tribute or payment Cowell

title: Recto, Breve De
body: A writ of right, which was of so high a nature that as other writs in real actions were only to recover the possession of the land, etc., in question, this aimed to recover the seisin and the property, and thereby both the rights of possession and property were tried together. CowelL

title: Recto De Advocatione Ec-Clesue
body: A writ which lay at common law, where a man had rlght of advowson of a church, and, the parson dying, a stranger had presented. Fitzh. Nat Brev. 30

title: Recto De Custodia Terrs Et Hsredis
body: A writ of right of ward of the land and helr. Abolished

title: Recto De Dote
body: A writ of right of dower, which lay for a widow who had re-ceived part of her dower, aud demanded the residue, against the heir of the husband or his guardian. Abolished. See 23 & 24 Vict. c. 126, | 26

title: Recto De Dote Unde Nihil Habet
body: A writ of right of dower whereof the widow had nothing, which lay where her deceased husband, having divers lands or tenements, had assured no dower to his wife, and she thereby was driven to sue for her thirds against the heir or his guardian. Abol-ished

title: Recto Sur Disclaimer
body: An abol-ished writ on disclaimer

title: Rector
body: In English law. Be that has full possession of a parochial church. A rector (or parson) has, for the most part, the whole right to all the ecclesiastical dues in hls parish; while a vicar has an appropri-ator over hlm, entitled to the best part of the profits, to whom the vicar is, in effect, per-petual curate, with a standing salary. 1 Bl. Comm. 384, 388. See Bird v. Bt Mark's Church, 62 Iowa, 567, 17 N. W. 747

title: Regtor Provincue
body: Lat In Ro

title: Regtor Sinecure
body: A rector of a parish who has not the cure of souls. 2 Steph. Cqmm. 683

title: Rectorial Tithes
body: Great or pre-dial tithes

title: Rectory
body: An entire parish chnrch, with all its rights, glebes, tithes, and other profits whatsoever; otherwise commonly call-el a “benefice.” See Gibson v. Brockway, 8 N. H. 470, 31 Am. Dec. 200; Pawlet v. Clark, • Cranch, 326, 3 L. Ed. 735

title: Rectum
body: UM. Lat Right;. also a trial or accusation. Bract; CowelL ^-Reotnm ease. To be right in court.—Reotnm rogam. To ask for right; to petition, the judge to do right.—Reotnm, stare ad. To stand trial or abide by the sentence of the court

title: Rectus In Curia
body: Lat. Right in court The condition of one who stands at the bar, against whom no one objects any offense, when a person outlawed has revers-ed hls outlawry, so that he can have the benefit of the law, he ls 6ald to be "rectus in curia.” Jacob

title: Reouperatio
body: Lat. In old English |aw. Recovery; restitution by the sentence ot a judge of a thing that has been wrong* fully taken or detained. Co. Litt 154a

title: Recuperatores
body: In Roman law. A specles of judges first appointed to decide controversies between Roman citizens and strangers concerning rights requiring speedy fernedy, but whose jurisdiction was gradual’ ly extended to questions which might be brought before ordinary judges. Mackeld. Rom. Law, S 204

title: Recusants
body: In English law. Persons who willfully absent themselves from thelr parish church, and on whom penalties were imposed by various statutes passed durlng the relgns of Ellzaheth and James I. wharton

title: Recusatio Testis
body: lat In the

title: Recusation
body: In the clvll law. A specles of exception or plea to the Jurisdiction, to the effect that the particular judge ls disqualified from hearing the cause by reason of Interest or prejudice. Poth. Proc. Civile, pt 1, c. 2, | 5

title: Rede
body: RAED, or REDE. Sax. Advice; counsel

title: Red Book Of The Exchequer
body: An ancient record, wherein are registered the holders of lands per baroniatn in the time of Henry II., the number of hldes of land In certain counties before the Conquest, and the ceremonies on the coronation of Eleanor, wife of Henry III. Jacob; CowelL

title: Red Tape
body: In a derivative sense, or-der carried to fastidious excess; system run out into trivial extremes, webster v. Thompson, 55 Ga. 434

title: Reddendo Singula Singulis
body: Lat By referring each to each; referring each phrase or expression to Its appropriate object. A rule of construction.

title: Reddendum
body: Lat. In conveyancing. Rendering; yielding. The technlcal name of that clause ln a conveyance by whlch the grantor creates or reserves some new thing to himself, out of what he had before grant-ed; as "rendering therefor yearly the sum of ten shillings, or a pepper-corn,” etc. That clause in a lease in which a rent is reserved to the lessor, and which commences with the word "yielding” 2 Bl. Comm. 299

title: Reddens Causam Scientls
body: Lat

title: Reddidit Se
body: Lat. He has rendered himself

title: Redditarius
body: In old records. A renter; a tenant Cowell

title: Redditarium
body: In old records. A rental, or rent-roll. Cowell

title: Reddition
body: A surrendering or re-storing; also a Judlclal acknowledgment that the thing ln demand belongs to the demand-ant, and not to the person surrendering Cowell

title: Redeem
body: To buy back. To liberate an qstate or article from mortgage or pledge by paying the debt for which it stood as secu-rity. To repurchase ln a literal sense; as, to redeem one's land from a tax-sale. See Max-well v. Foster, 67 S. C. 877, 45 8. E. 927; Mlller v. Ratterman, 47 Ohlo St 141, 24 N. E. 496; Swearingen ▼. Roberts, 12 Neb. 833, 11 N. W. 825; Pace ▼. Bartles, 47 N. J. Eq. 170, 20 Ati. 352

title: Redeemable
body: 1. Subject to an obll-gation of redemption; embodying, or conditioned upon, a promise or obligation of redemption; convertible Into coin; as, a “re deemable currency." See U. 8. v. North Carolina, 136 U. S. 211, 10 Sup. Ct 920, 84 L. Ed. 336

title: Redemise
body: A regranting of land demised or leased

title: Redemptio Operis
body: Lat In Roman law, a contract for the hlrlng or letting of services, or for the performance of a certain work ln consideration of the pay* ment of a stipulated price. It is the same contract as "locatio operis" but regarded from the standpoint of tbe one who ls to do the work, and who is called "redemptor operis,” while the hirer ls called "locator operis." See Mackeld. Rom. Law, § 408

title: Redemption
body: A repurchase; a huy-ing back. The act of a vendor of property in buying it back again from the purchaser at the same or an enhanced price

title: Redemptiones
body: In old English law. Heavy fines. Distinguished from misericor-dia, (which see

title: Redeundo
body: Lat Returning; ln re4 turning; while returnlng. 2 Strange, 965

title: Redevance
body: In old French and Cana-dian law. Dues payable by a tenant to hls lord, not necessarily ln money

title: Redhibere
body: Lat In the civil law, To have again; to have back; to cause a seller to have again wbat he had before

title: Redhibition
body: In tbe civil law. The avoidance of a sale on acconnt of some vice or defect ln the thing sold, whlch renders it either absolutely' useless or its use so in-convenient and imperfect that it must be supposed that the buyer would not have pur-chased it had he known of the vice. Civ; Code La. art 2520

title: Redhibitory Agtion
body: In the civil law. An action for redhibition. An action to avoid a sale on account of some vice or defect ln the thing Bold, which renders its use Impossible, or so Inconvenient and imperfect that it must be supposed the buyer would not have purchased it had be known of the vice. Civ. Code La. art. 2520

title: Redisseisin
body: In old English law. A second disseisin of a person of the same tenements, and by the same disseisor, by whom he was before disseised. 3 Bl. Comm. 188

title: Reditus
body: Lat A revenue or return; Income or profit; specifically, rent

title: Redmans
body: NS. In feudal law. Men who, by the tenure or custom of their lands, were to ride with or for the lord of the manor,< about his business. Domesday

title: Redobatores
body: In old English law

title: Redress
body: The receiving satisfaction for an injury sustained

title: Redubbers
body: In criminal law. Those Who bought stolen cloth and dyed lt of an-other color to prevent its belng Identified were anciently so called. Cowell; 3 InsL 134

title: Reduce
body: In Scotch law. To rescind or annul

title: Reductio Ad Absurdum
body: Lat In

title: Redugtion
body: In Sootob law. An ac

title: Reduction Into Possession
body: The act of exerclsing the right conferred by a chose ln action, so as to convert lt into a chose in possession; thus, a debt is reduced into possession by payment Sweet.

title: Redundancy
body: This is the fault of introducing superfluous matter into a legal instrument; particularly the insertion in a pleading of matters foreign, extraneous, and Irrelevant to tljat which it ls intended to answer. See Carpenter v. Reynolds, 58 wis. 666, 17 N. W. 300; Carpenter v. west, 5 How. Prac. (N. Y.) 55; Bowman v. Sheldon, 6 Sandf. (N. Y.) 660

title: Re-Entry
body: The entering again Into or resuming possession of premises. Thus in leases there is a proviso for re-entry of the lessor on the tenant’s failure to pay tiie rent or perform the covenants contained in the leaser and by virtue of such proviso the lessor may take the premises Into hls own hands again lf the rent he not paid or cove-nants performed; and this resumption of possession ls termed "re-entry.” 2 Cruise, Dig. 8; Cowell. And see Michaels v. Fishel, 169 N. Y. 381, 62 N. E. 425; Earl orchard Co. v. Fava, 138 Cal. 76, 70 Pac. 1073

title: Re-Examination
body: An examlnatlon of a witness after a cross-examination, upon matters arising out of such cross-examination. See Examination

title: Re-Exchange
body: The damages or expenses caused by the dishonor and protest of a bill of exchange ln a foreign country, where lt was payable, and hy lts return to the place where lt was drawn or Indorsed, and its being there taken up. Bangor Bank V. Hook, 5 Me. 175

title: Re-Extent
body: In English practice. A second extent made upon lands or tenements, upon complaint made that the former extent was partially performed. Cowell

title: Reeve
body: VE. In old English law. A minis* terial officer of justice. His duties seem to have combined many of those now confided to the sheriff or constable and to the justlce of the peace. He was also called, in Saxon, "gcrefa

title: Refalo
body: LO. A word composed of the three initial syllables “re.” "fa.” "lo.,” for "re-cordari facias loquelam," (q. v.) 2 Sell. Pr. 160

title: Refare
body: Tq bereave, take away, rob. CoweU

title: Refection
body: In the civil law. Rep-aration; re-establishment of a building. Dig. 19, 1, 6» L

title: Refer
body: 1. when a case or action involves matters of account or other intricate details which require minute examination, and for that reason are not fit to be brought before a Jury, it is usual to refer the whole case, or some part of lt, to the decislon of an auditor or referee, and the case is then said to be referred

title: Referee
body: In practice. A person to whom a cause pending in a conrt Is referred hy the court, to take testimony, hear the par-ties, and report thereon to the court See Refer. And see In re Hathaway, 71 N. Y. 243; Betts v. Letcher, 1 8. D. 182, 46 N. W. 193; Central Trust Co. v. Wabash, etc., R Co. (C. 0.) 32 Fed. 685

title: Reference
body: In oontraots. An

title: Referendarius
body: An officer by whom the order of causes was laid before the Roman emperor, the desires of petitioners made known, and answers returned to them. Vicat, Voc. Jur.; Calvin

title: Referendary
body: In Saxon law. A master of requests; an officer to whom petitions to the king were referred. Spelman

title: Referendo Singula Singulis
body: Lat Referring Individual or separate words to separate subjects; making a distributive reference of words in an lnstrument; a rule of construction.

title: Referendum
body: In international law. A communication sent by a diplomatic rep-resentatlve to his home government, in re-gard to matters presented to him which he is unable or unwilling to decide without fur-ther instructions

title: Refinement
body: A term sometimes em-ployed to describe verbiage inserted in a pleading or indictment, over and above what is necessary to he set forth; or an objection to a plea or indictment on the ground of its failing to include such superfluous matter. See State v. Galllmon, 24 N. C. 377; State v. Peak, 130 N. C. 711, 41 S. E. 887

title: Reform
body: To correct, rectify, amend, remodel. Instruments inter partes may be reformed, when defective, by a court of equi-ty. By thls is meant that the court, after ascertaining the real and original intention of the parties to a deed or other Instrument, (which intention they failed to sufficiently express, through some error, mistake of fact, or inadvertence,) will decree that the in strument be held and construed as if lt ful-ly and technically expressed that Intention See Sullivan ▼. Haskin, 70 Vt 487, 41 AU

title: Reform Acts
body: A name bestowed on the statutes 2 wm. IV. c. 45, and 30 & 31 Vict c. 102, passed to amend the representation of the people ln England and wales; which Introduced extended amendments into the system of electing members of the house of commons

title: Reformation
body: See Refobm

title: Reformatory
body: This term ls of too wlde and uncertaln slgnlficatlon to support a bequest for the bulldlug of a “boys’ re-formatory.” It includes all places and in-stitutions in which efforts are made either to cultivate the Intellect, instruct the con-science, or improve the conduct; places iu which persons voluntarily assemble, receive lnstructlon, and submit to discipline, or are detained therein for either of these purposes by force. Hughes v. Daly, 49 Conn. 35. But see McAndrews v. Hamilton County, 105 Tenn. 399, 58 S. W. 483

title: Reformatory Schools
body: In English law. Schools to which convicted juvenile offenders (under sixteen) may be sent by order of the court before which they are tried, If the offense be punishable with pe-nal servitude or imprisonment, and the sentence be to imprisonment for ten days or more, wharton

title: Refresher
body: In English law. A fur* ther or additional fee to counsel ln a long 'case, which may be, but Is not necessarily, allowed on taxation

title: Refreshing The Memory
body: The

title: Refund
body: To repay or restore; to return money bad by one party of another See-Rackliff v. Greenbush, 93 Me. 99, 44 Atl. 375; Maynard v. Mechanics’ Nat Bank, 1 Brewst. (Pa.) 484; Gutch v. Fosdlck, 48 N. J. Eq. 353, 22 Atl. 590, 27 Am. St. Rep. 473

title: Refusal
body: The act of one who has, by law, a right and power of having or doing something of advantage, and declines it Also, the declination of a request or demand, or the omission to comply with some re-qulrement of law, as the reeult of a positive intention to disobey. In the latter sense, the word ie often coupled wlth “neglect,” as. if a party shall “neglect or refuse" to pay a tax, file an official bond, obey an order of court, etc. But “neglect” signifies a mere omlsslon of a duty, whlch may happen through inattention, dilatoriness, mistake, or inability to perform, while “refusal" lmplies the posltive denial of an appllcatlon or command, or at least a mental determlnatlon not to comply. See Thompson v. Tlnkcom, 15 Mlnn. 299 (Gll. 226); People ▼. Perkins, 86 Cal. 509, 26 Pac. 245; Kimball v. Rowland, 6 Gray (Mass.) 225; Davis v. Lumpkin, 106 Ga. 582, 32 S. E. 626; Burns v. Fox, 113 Ind. 205, 14 N. E. 541; Cape Elizabeth v. Boyd, 86 Me. 317, 29 Atl. 1062; Taylor v. Mason, 9 wheat 344, 6 L. Ed. 101

title: Reg. Gen
body: An abbreviation of “Regula Generalis,” a general rule, (of court

title: Reg. Jud
body: An abbreviation of “Regis-trum Judiciale,” the register of judicial writs

title: Reg. Lib
body: An abbreviation of “Reg-istrarii Liber,” the register's book in chancery, containing all decrees

title: Reg. Orig
body: An abbreviation of “Reg-istrum Originale," the register of original writs

title: Reg. Pl
body: An abbreviation of “Reguto Placitandi,” rule of pleading

title: Regale
body: In old French law. A payment made to the seigneur of a fief, on the election of every bishop or other ecclesiastical feudatory, corresponding with the relief paid by a lay feudatory. Steph. Lect 235

title: Regale Episooporum
body: The temporal rights and privileges of a bishop. Cowell

title: Regalia Facere
body: To do homage or fealty to the sovereign by a bishop when he ls invested with the regalia

title: Regality
body: A territorial Jurisdiction in Scotland conferred by the crown. The lands were sald to be given in liberam regali-tatem, and the persons receiving the right were termed “lords of regality.” Bell

title: Regard
body: In old English law. Inspection; supervision. Also a reward, fee, or perquisite

title: Regardant
body: A term which was applied, in feudal law, to a villein annexed to a manor, and having charge to do all base services within the same, and to see the same freed from all thlngs that mlght annoy his lord. Such a villein regardant waa thus opposed to a villein en groe, who was transferable by deed from one owner to another. Cowell; 2 Bl. Comm. 93

title: Regarder Of A Forest
body: An an

title: Rege Inconsulto
body: Lat In English law. A writ issued from the sover-eign to the judges, not to proceed ln a cause which may prejudice the crown, until advised. Jenk. Cent 97

title: Regency
body: Rule; government; king-ship. The man or body of men intrusted with the vicarious government of a kingdom during the minority, absence, insanity, or other disability of the king

title: Regent
body: A governor or ruler, one who vicariously administers the government of a kingdom, in the name of the king, dur-ing the latter’s minority or other disability. ■ A: master, governor, director, or superin

title: Regia Via
body: Lat Ih old Engllsh law. The royal way; the klng's highway. Co. Lltt. 56a

title: Regiam Majestatem
body: A collection of the ancient laws of Scotland. It is said to have been compiled by order of David I., klng of Scotland, who reigned from A. D. 1124 to 1153. Hale, Com. Law, 271

title: Regicide
body: The murder of a soverelgn; also the person who commits such murder

title: Regidor
body: In Spanish law. one of a body, never exceeding twelve, who formed a part of the ayuntamtento. The office of re-gidor was held for llfe; that is to say, during the pleasure of the supreme authority. In most places the office was purchased; in some cltles, however, they were elected by persons of the district, called “capitula res.” 12 Pet. 442, note

title: Regime
body: In French lnw. A system of rules or regulations

title: Regimiento
body: In Spanish law. The body of regldores, who never exceeded twelve, forming a part of the municipal coun-cil, or ayuntamicnto, in every capital of a jurisdiction. 12 Pet. 442, note

title: Regina
body: Lat. The queen

title: Regio Assensu
body: A writ whereby the sovereign gives his assent to the election of a bishop. Reg. orig. 294

title: Register
body: An oflicer authorized by law to keep e W»td. called a “register” ot;“re£

title: Registered
body: Entered or recorded In some official register or record or list

title: Register'S Court
body: In American law. A court in the state of Pennsylvania which has jurisdiction in matters of probate

title: Registrar
body: An officer who has the custody or keeping of a registry or register. This word ls used in England; “register” is more common In America

title: Registrarius
body: In old Engllsh law. A notary; a registrar or register

title: Registration
body: Recording; Inserting In an official register; the act of making a list, catalogue, schedule, or register, particu-larly of an official character, or of making entries therein. In re Supervisors of Election (C. C.) 1 Fed. 1

title: Registrum Brevium
body: The register of writs, (q. v

title: Registry
body: A register, or book author-lzed or recognized by law, kept for the recording or registration of facts or documents

title: Regius Professor
body: A royal professor or reader of lectures founded in the English universities by the king. Henry VIII. founded in each of the universities five professorships, viz., of divinity, Greek, Hebrew, law, and physic. Cowell

title: Reglamento
body: In Spanish colonial law. A written instruction given by a com-petent authority, without the observance of any peculiar form. Schm. Civil Law, Introd. 93, note

title: Regnal Years
body: Statutes of the British parliament are usually cited by the name and year of the sovereign in whose reign they were enacted, and the successive years of the reign of any king or queen are denominated the “regnal years.”

title: Regnant
body: One having authority as a king; one in the exercise of royal authority

title: Regni Populi
body: A name given to the people of Surrey and Sussex, and on the seacoasts of Hampshire. Blount

title: Regnum Ecclesiastigum
body: The

title: Regulje Generales
body: Lat. General rules, whlch the courts promulgate from time to time for the regulation of their practice

title: Regular
body: According to rule; as dls-tinguished from that which violates the rule or follows no rule

title: Regulars
body: Those who profess and follow a certain rule of life, (regula,) be-long to a religious order, and observe the three approved vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience, wharton

title: Regrant
body: In the English law of real property, when, after a person has made a grant, the property granted comes back to him, (e. g., by escheat or forfeiture,) and he grants lt again, he is said to regrant it. The phrase is chiefly used in the law of copy-holds

title: Regrating
body: In old English law. The offense of buying or getting into one’s hands at a fair or market any provisions, corn, or other dead victual, with the inten-tlon of selling the same again in the same fair or market, or in some other within four ' miles thereof, at a higher price. The offend-er was termed a “regrator3 Inst. 195. See Forsyth Mfg. Co. v. Castlen, 112 Ga. 190

title: Regula
body: Lat. In practice. A rule. Regula generalia, a general rule; a standing rule or order of a court Frequently ab-brevlated, “Reg. Gen.”

title: Regulate
body: The power to regulate commerce, vested ln congress, ls the power to preserlbe the rules by which lt shall be governed, that ls, the condltlons upon whlch lt shall be conducted, to determlne when lt shall be free, and when subject to duties or other exactions. Tbe power also embraces within lts control all the instrumentalltles hy which that commerce may be carrled on, and the means by whlch lt may be aided and en-couraged. Gloucester Ferry Co. v. Pennsyl-vania, 114 U. S. 196, 5 Sup. Ct. 826, 29 L. Ed. 158. And see Gibbons v. ogden, 9 wheat. 227, 6 L. Ed. 23 ; Gilman v. Phlladelphla, 3 wall. 724, 18 L. Ed. 96; welton v. Mlssourl. 91 U. S. 279, 23 L. Ed. 347; Leisy v. Hardin, 135 U. S. 100, 10 Sup. Ct 681, 34 L. Ed. 128; Kavanaugh v. Southern R. Co., 120 Ga. 62, 47 S. E. 526

title: Regulation
body: The act of regulating, a rule or order prescribed for management ,or government; a regulatlng prlnclple; a precept. See Curry v. Marvin, 2 Fla. 415; Ames v. Unlon Pac. Ry. Co. (C. C.) 64 Fed. 178; Hunt v. Lambertville, 45 N. J. Law, 282

title: Regulus
body: Lat. In Saxon law. A tltle sometlmes glven to the earl or come8, in old charters. Spelman

title: Rehabere Facias Seisinam
body: when a sheriff in the “habere facias sei-sinam" had delivered seisin of more than he ought, this judicial writ lay to make him re-store seisin of the excess. Reg. Jud. 18, 51, 54.

title: Rehabilitate
body: In Scotch and French criminal law. To reinstate a crimlnal in his personal rights which he has lost by a judicial sentence. Brande

title: Rehabilitation
body: In French and Sootob oriminal law. The reinstatement of a' criminal in hls personal rights which be has lost by a judicial sentence. Brande

title: Rehearing
body: In equity practice. A second hearing of a cause, for which a party who is dissatisfied with the decree entered on the former hearing may apply by petition. 3 Bl. Comm. 453. See Belmont v. Erie R. Co., 62 Barb. (N. Y.) 651; Emerson v. Davies, 8 Fed. Cas. 626; Read v. Patterson, 44 N. J. Eq. 211, 14 Atl. 490, 6 Am. SL Rep. 877

title: Rei Interventus
body: Lat Thlngs in-tervening; that ls, things done by one of the partles to a contract, ln the falth of Its va-lldity, and with the assent of the other par-ty, and whlch have so affected his situation that the other will not be allowed to repudi-ate his obligation, although originally lt was imperfect, and he might have renounced it. 1 Bell, Comm. 328, 329

title: Reif
body: A robbery. CoweU

title: Reimburse
body: The primary, meaning of this word is “to pay back." Philadelphia Trust, etc., Co. v. Audenreid, 83 Pa. 264. It means to make return or restoration of an equivalent for something paid, expended, or lost; to indemnify, or make whole

title: Reinstate
body: To place again in a former state, condition, or office; to restore to a state or position from which the object or person had been removed. See Collins v

title: Reinsurance
body: A contract of rein-sura nee is one by which an Insurer procures a third person to insure him against ioss or liability hy reason of such original Insurance. Civ. Code Cal. 8 2646. And see People v. Miller, 177 N. Y. 515, 70 N. E. 10; Iowa L

title: Reissuable Notes
body: Bank-note®

title: Rejoin
body: In pleading. To answer a plaintiff's replication ln an action at law, by some matter of fact

title: Rejoinder
body: In common-law plead-ing. The second pleadlng on the part of the defendant, being hls answer of matter of fact to the plalntlff*s replication

title: Rejoining Gratis
body: Rejoining vol-untarlly, or wlthout being required to do so by a rule to rejoin, when a defendant was under terms to rejoin gratis, he had to de-liver a rejolnder, without putting the plain-tiff to the necesslty and expense of obtaining a rule to rejoin. 10 Mees. & W. 12; Lush, Pr. 396; Brown

title: Relation
body: 1. A relative or kinsman; a person connected by consanguinity or affln-ity

title: Relations
body: A term which, ln its widest sense, lncludes all the kindred of the person spoken of. 2 Jarm. wills, 66L

title: Relative
body: A kinsman; a person con-nected with another by blood or affinity

title: Relator
body: The person upon whose complaint, or at whose instance, an information or writ of quo warranto is filed, and who is quasi the plaintiff in the proceeding

title: Relatrix
body: X. In practice. A female relator or petitioner

title: Relaxare
body: In oid conveyancing. To release. Relaxavi, relaxasse, have released. IAtt | 445

title: Relaxatio
body: In old conveyancing. A release; an Instrument by which a person relinquishes to another his right in anything

title: Relaxation
body: In old Scotch practice. Letters passlng the signet by whlch a debtor was relaxed [released] from the horn; that ls, from personal diligence. Bell

title: Release
body: 1. Liberation, discharge, or setting free from restraint or confinement. Thus, a man unlawfully imprisoned may obtain his release on habeas corpus. Parker v

title: Releasee
body: The person to whom a re-lease is made

title: Releasor
body: or RELEASOR. The maker of a release

title: Relegatio
body: Lat. A kind of banish-ment known to the civil law, which differed from “deportatio" in leaving to the person his rights of citizenship

title: Relegation
body: In old English lnw. Banishment for a time only. Co. Litt. 133

title: Relevancy
body: As a quallty of evidence, “relevancy" means appllcabillty to the lssue jolned. Relevancy ls that which conduces to the proof of a pertinent hypothesis; a per-tlnent hypothesis being one which, if sus-tained, would logically lnfluence the Issue, whart Ev. $ 20

title: Relevant
body: Applying to the matter in question; affording something to the purpose

title: Relict
body: This term is applied to the survivor of a pair of married people, whether the survivor ls the husband or the wife; it means the relict of the united pair, (or of the marriage union,) not the relict of the deceas-ed Individual. Spltler v. Heeter, 42 ohio St. 10L

title: Relicta Verhtcatione
body: L. Lat

title: Reliction
body: An Increase of the land by the sudden withdrawal or retrocessiou of the sea or a river. Hammond v. Shepard, 186 111. 235, 57 N. E. 867, 78 Am. St Rep. 274; Sapp v. Frazier, 51 La. Ann. 1718, 26 South. 378, 72 Am. St Rep. 493

title: Relief
body: 1. In feudal law. A sum pay-able hy the new tenant, the duty heing inci-dent to every feudal tenure, by way of fine or composition with the lord for taking np the estate w'hich was lapsed or fallen in hy the death of the last tenant At oue time the amount was arbitrary, but afterwards the re-lief of a knight's fee became fixed at one hundred shillings. 2 Bl. Comm. 65

title: Relieve
body: In feudal law, relieve is to depend; thus, the seigulory of a tenant in capite relieves of the crown, meaning that the tenant holds of the crown. The term is not common in English writers. Sweet

title: Religion
body: As used ln constitutional provisions forblddlng the “establlshment of religion," the term means a partlcular system of faith and worship recognized and practised by a particular church, sect, or deuom-ination. See Reynolds v. U. S., 98 U. S. 149

title: Religious
body: when religious books, or reading are spoken of, those which tend to promote the religion taught by the Christian dispensation must be considered as referred to, unless the meaning ls so limited by associated words or circumstances as to show that the speaker er writer had reference to some other mode of worship. Simpson v. Welcome, 72 Me. 500, 39 Am. Rep. 349

title: Relinquishment
body: In practice. A forsaking, abandoning, renouncing, or giving over a right

title: Reliqua
body: UA. The remainder or debt which a person finds himself debtor iu upon the balancing or liquidation of an account. Hence reliquary, the debtor of a reliqua; as also a person who only pays piece-meal. Enc. Lond

title: Reliques
body: Remains; such as the bones, etc., of saints, preserved with great veneration as sacred memorials. Th^y hnve been forbidden to be used or brought into England. St 3 Jac. I. c. 26

title: Relocatio
body: Lat ln the civil law. A renewal of a lease on Its determination. It may be either express or tacit; the latter is when the tenant holds over with the knowl-edge and withont objection of the landlord. Mackeld. Rom. Law, f 412

title: Relocation
body: In Sootob law. A re

title: Remainder
body: The remnant of an estate in land, depending upon a particular prior estate created at the same time and by the same instrument, and limited to arise im-mediately on the determination of that es-tate, and not ln abridgment of it. 4 Kent, Comm. 197

title: Remainder-Man
body: One who is entitled to the remainder of the estate after a partlcular estate carved out of lt has expired

title: Remand
body: To remand a prisoner, after a preliminary or partial hearing before a court or magistrate, ls to send him back to custody, to be kept until the hearing is resumed or the trial comes on

title: Remanent Pro Defectu Emp-Torum
body: In practice. The return made by the sheriff to a writ of execution when he has not been able to sell the property seized, that the same remains unsold for want of buyers

title: Remanentia
body: In old English law. A remainder. Spelman. A perpetuity, or perpetual estate. Glan. llb. 7, & 1

title: Remanet
body: A remnant; that which remains. Thus the causes of which the trial is deferred from one term to another, or from one sitting to another, are termed “rema-nets.” 1 Archb. Pr. 375

title: Remedial
body: 1. Affording a remedy; giving the means of obtaining redress

title: Remedy
body: Remedy is the means by which the violation of a right is prevented, redressed, or compensated. Remedies are of four kinds: (1) By act of tbe party injured, the principal of which are defense, recaption, distress, entry, abatement, and seizure; (2) by operation of law, as ln the case of retalner and remitter; (3) by agreement between the parties, e. g., by accord and satisfaction and arbitration; and (4) by judicial remedy, e. g., action or suit Sweet See Knapp ▼. McCaffrey, 177 U. S. 638, 20 Sup. CL 824, 44 L. Ed. 921; Missionary Soc. v. Ely, 56 ohio St 405, 47 N. E. 537; U. S. v. Lyman, 26 Fed. Cas. 1,024; Frost v. witter, 132 CaL 421, 64 Pac. 705, 84 Am. St. Rep. 53

title: Remembrancer
body: The remembrancer of the city of London is parliamentary solicitor to the corporation, and is bound to attend ail courts of aldermen aud common council when required. Pull. Laws & Cust. Lond. 122

title: Remembrancers
body: In English law. officers of the exchequer, whose duty It le to put in remembrance the lord treasurer and the justlces of that court of such things as are to be called and dealt in for the benefit of the crown. Jacob

title: Remise
body: To remit or give up. A form-al word in deeds of release and quitclaim; the usual phrase being “remise, release, and forever quitclaim.” See American Mortg

title: Remise De La Dettb
body: In French law. The release of a debt

title: Remission
body: In tbe civil Uw. A release of a debt lt is conventional, when it is expressly granted to the debtor by a cred-itor having a capacity to alienate; or tacit, when the creditor voluntarily surrenders to his debtor the original title, under private signature constituting the obligation. Civ. Code La. art. 2195

title: Remissness
body: This term imports the doing of the act in question in a tardy, neg-ligent, or careless manner; hut it does not apply to the entire omission or forbearance of the act. Baldwin v. United States Tel. Co., 6 Abb. Prac. N. S. (N. I.) 423

title: Remit
body: To send or transmit; as to remit money. Potter v. Morland, 3 Cush. (Mass.) 388; Hollowell v. Life Ins. Co., 126 N. C. 398, 35 S. E. 610

title: Remitment
body: Tbe act of sending hack to custody; an annulment, wharton

title: Remittance
body: Money sent by one per-son to another, either in specie, bill of ex-change, check, or otherwise

title: Remittee
body: A person to whom a re-mittance is made. Story, Bailm. $ 75

title: Remitter
body: The relation back of a later defective title to an earlier valid title. Remitter ls where he who has the true property or jus proprietatis in lands, but is out of possession thereof, and has no right to enter without recovering possession in an action, has afterwards the freehold cast upon him by some subsequent and of course defective title. In this case he ls remitted, or sent back by operation of law, to his ancient and more cer-tain title.
